We can eliminate, in our estimate of <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16-eq217.png\"></span>, at least the uncertainty in the mass-metallicity relation (Eq. (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#FD4\">4</a>)) by considering only the few objects with direct gas-phase metallicity measurements (encircled data points in Fig. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#F11\">11</a>). Nevertheless, the mean <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>f</i><sub>molgas</sub></span> at <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i> =  [ 2.7,3.6 ]</span>, in that case, still remains above that of the <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i> =  [ 1,1.6 ]</span> and <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i> =  [ 2,2.5 ]</span> bins, but with the same large standard deviation. Interestingly, the new <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>f</i><sub>molgas</sub></span> measurement as high as 60&#8211;79% obtained in MACSJ0032-arc, which is the highest redshift object with a CO measure, favors a steady increase in <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>f</i><sub>molgas</sub></span> with redshift irrespective of the <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#945;</i><sub>CO</sub></span> employed. </p>\n<p>Finally, we would like to note that all the CO measurements at <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i>&gt; 2.5</span> (except one, the non-encircled triangle in Fig. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#F11\">11</a>) come from lensed galaxies with low stellar masses (<span class=\"simple-math\">log&#8201;(<i>M</i><sub>&#8727;</sub>/<i>M</i><sub>&#8857;</sub>) &lt; 10.4</span>), whereas CO is most commonly measured in massive galaxies at <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i>&lt; 2.5</span>. Similarly, all the molecular gas mass estimates from the FIR dust continuum are derived for massive galaxies. Given the expected increase in <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>f</i><sub>molgas</sub></span> with decreasing <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>M</i><sub>&#8727;</sub></span>  (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#R7\">Bouch&#233; et al. 2010</a>; <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#R21\">Dav&#233; et al. 2011</a>), the possible trend for an increase in <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>f</i><sub>molgas</sub></span> beyond <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i> ~ 2.5</span> may reflect the higher <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>f</i><sub>molgas</sub></span>  expected to be found in low-mass galaxies (see <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#R24\">Dessauges-Zavadsky et al. 2015</a>) if the mass dependence of <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>f</i><sub>molgas</sub></span> is stronger than its dependence on redshift. </p>\n<h2 class=\"sec\">\n<a name=\"S19\"></a>6. Summary and conclusions</h2>\n<p>For the first time, we can simultaneously characterize the stellar, dust, and molecular gas properties in a normal star-forming galaxy at a redshift as high as <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i><sub>CO</sub> = 3.6314</span>. MACSJ0032-arc has a fairly low stellar mass <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16-eq164.png\"></span> and a star formation rate <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16-eq315.png\"></span> when corrected for the lensing magnification <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#956;</i> = 62 &#177; 6</span>, placing it relatively close to the main sequence at <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i> ~ 4</span> with an offset <span class=\"simple-math\">&#8818;</span><span class=\"simple-math\">+ 0.3 dex</span> depending on the MS definition (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#R96\">Tacconi et al. 2013</a>; <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#R90\">Speagle et al. 2014</a>; <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#R99\">Tomczak et al. 2016</a>). Moreover, it follows the tight correlation between IR and CO(1&#8211;0) luminosities (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#R24\">Dessauges-Zavadsky et al. 2015</a>; <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#R85\">Scoville et al. 2016</a>). MACSJ0032-arc shows no weakening of its <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16-eq131.png\"></span> (see <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#R97\">Tan et al. 2013</a>) compared to the expectations based on the <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>L</i><sub>IR</sub></span>&#8211;<span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16-eq131.png\"></span>  relation satisfied by MS SFGs at <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i> &#8818; 2.5</span>. Our findings for MACSJ0032-arc can be summarized as follows: </p>\n<p>\n        <ul style=\"list-style-type: none;\">\n          <li>\n            1. \n            <p class=\"ligne\"> About 90% of the total<span class=\"simple-math\"><i>SFR</i><sub>UV + IR</sub></span> of MACSJ0032-arc is inaccessible at rest-frame UV wavelengths, but is detected through thermal dust emission in the FIR regime. </p>\n          </li>\n          <li>\n            2. \n            <p class=\"ligne\"> In HST images, MACSJ0032-arc is resolved into two UV-bright knots, separated by <span class=\"simple-math\">1.14 &#177; 0.28 kpc</span>. The bulk of the molecular gas mass and star formation of the lensed galaxy is, however, decoupled from the rest-frame UV emission and comes from between these two UV knots, i.e., from a region too dusty to be detected at rest-frame UV wavelengths, shown to also host the 2 mm cold dust emission. </p>\n          </li>\n          <li>\n            3. \n            <p class=\"ligne\"> With the detection of the CO(1&#8211;0), CO(4&#8211;3), and CO(6&#8211;5) emission lines, whose fluxes have been corrected against the CMB, we can constrain the CO luminosity correction factors for the high <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>J</i> = 4</span> and <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>J</i> = 6</span> CO transitions in a normal SFG at <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i> ~ 3.6</span>. The derived values of <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>r</i><sub>4,1</sub> = 0.60 &#177; 0.17</span> and <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>r</i><sub>6,1</sub> = 0.28 &#177; 0.08</span> describe a CO SLED featuring a slightly more highly excited CO than found in lower-redshift SFGs, but in line with CO excitation levels observed in high-redshift SMGs even though the IR luminosity, <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16-eq181.png\"></span>, of MACSJ0032-arc is 10 times lower than typically observed in SMGs. The high CO excitation is likely due to the compactness of MACSJ0032-arc, that could result from the general fact that galaxies are more compact at higher redshifts because of their smaller sizes. These results are of particular interest in the context of high-redshift normal star-forming galaxies and their molecular gas mass estimates as only high CO rotational transitions (<span class=\"simple-math\"><i>J</i> &#8805; 4</span>) are accessible beyond <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i> ~ 4</span>  with the NOrthern Extended Millimeter Array (NOEMA) and ALMA. </p>\n          </li>\n          <li>\n            4. \n            <p class=\"ligne\"> We interpret the morphology of MACSJ0032-arc as indicative of it being a single system whose molecular gas and intense dusty star formation resides and occurs primarily in its center, surrounded by two UV-bright star-forming regions, possibly in rotation. This configuration may also be the result of a recent merger or accretion event, albeit not one big enough to completely disrupt the kinematic state of the galaxy, as we still observe double-peaked CO(4&#8211;3) and CO(6&#8211;5) line profiles. </p>\n          </li>\n          <li>\n            5. \n            <p class=\"ligne\"> Measurements of both the dust mass and the CO(1&#8211;0) luminosity of MACSJ0032-arc enable us to estimate its CO-to-H<span class=\"simple-math\"><sub>2</sub></span> conversion factor, <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#945;</i><sub>CO</sub></span>, using several independent methods. First, we consider the redshift-dependent mass-metallicity relation and metallicity-dependent <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16-eq217.png\"></span> function adopted by <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#R37\">Genzel et al. (2015)</a>. This method yields a metallicity of <span class=\"simple-math\">12 + log&#8201;(O / H)<sub>PP04</sub> = 8.0 &#177; 0.2</span> and a value of <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16-eq232.png\"></span>. Alternatively, assuming the metallicity-dependent dust-to-gas mass ratio from <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#R49\">Leroy et al. (2011)</a>, we obtain the markedly different value of <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16-eq259.png\"></span>. Part of the discrepancy may be due to the uncertainty on the metallicity &#8211; we get a metallicity as high as <span class=\"simple-math\">12 + log&#8201;(O / H)<sub>FMR</sub> = 8.5 &#177; 0.2</span>  when using the FMR calibrated for low-<span class=\"simple-math\"><i>M</i><sub>&#8727;</sub></span> galaxies &#8211; and/or the high CO excitation observed in the arc, which may imply an additional correction factor to <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16-eq217.png\"></span> on the order of <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#945;</i><sub>CO,MW</sub>/<i>&#945;</i><sub>CO,ULIRG</sub> ~ 5</span>. When this high CO excitation state is accounted for, the discrepancy between <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16-eq217.png\"></span> and <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16-eq260.png\"></span> falls to a factor between 1.3 and 2 depending on the adopted metallicity. We thus assume the CO-to-H<span class=\"simple-math\"><sub>2</sub></span> conversion factor for MACSJ0032-arc to lie between <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16-eq265.png\"></span> along with the <span class=\"simple-math\">12 + log&#8201;(O / H)<sub>PP04</sub></span> metallicity and <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16-eq264.png\"></span> along with the <span class=\"simple-math\">12 + log&#8201;(O / H)<sub>FMR</sub></span> metallicity. </p>\n          </li>\n          <li>\n            6. \n            <p class=\"ligne\"> Adopting the above <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#945;</i><sub>CO</sub></span> interval, we derive a depletion time for the molecular gas in this <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i> ~ 3.6</span> star-forming galaxy of <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>t</i><sub>depl</sub> = 0.14 &#8722; 0.35 Gyr</span>. Along with that of other high-redshift MS SFGs, generally limited to <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i> &#8818; 2.5</span> because of the scarce number of CO measurements existing beyond this redshift, our analysis confirms the decrease in <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>t</i><sub>depl</sub></span> with cosmic time, although to a lesser degree than predicted by galaxy evolution models. </p>\n          </li>\n          <li>\n            7. \n            <p class=\"ligne\"> For the same <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#945;</i><sub>CO</sub></span> interval, we find the molecular gas fraction of MACSJ0032-arc to lie in the range <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>f</i><sub>molgas</sub> = 0.60 &#8722; 0.79</span>. When combined with the results obtained previously for the few <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i> &#8819; 2.7</span> MS SFGs with available CO measurements, the corresponding <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>f</i><sub>molgas</sub></span> mean supports the continued increase in <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>f</i><sub>molgas</sub></span> with redshift; however, its large standard deviation does not enable us to exclude the possible flattening of <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>f</i><sub>molgas</sub></span> beyond <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i> ~ 2</span>. More CO measurements in MS SFGs at <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i>&gt; 2.5</span> are clearly needed to confirm the redshift evolution of <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>f</i><sub>molgas</sub></span>. </p>\n          </li>\n        </ul>\n      </p>\n    <hr width=\"30%\" align=\"left\">\n<div><div>\n<a name=\"FN20\"></a><sup>1</sup> <p class=\"ligne\"> The <i>Herschel </i>beam varies in size from <span class=\"simple-math\">18&#8242;&#8242;</span> at 250 <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#956;</i></span>m to <span class=\"simple-math\">37&#8242;&#8242;</span> at 500 <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#956;</i></span>m.</p>\n</div></div>\n<div><div>\n<a name=\"FN21\"></a><sup>2</sup> <p class=\"ligne\">\n          <a href=\"http://herschel.esac.esa.int/hcss-doc-16.0/load/spire_drg/html/ch06s09.html\" target=\"_blank\">http://herschel.esac.esa.int/hcss-doc-16.0/load/spire_drg/html/ch06s09.html</a>\n        </p>\n</div></div>\n<div><div>\n<a name=\"FN22\"></a><sup>3</sup> <p class=\"ligne\"> This correction, derived by propagating the CO(6&#8211;5)&#8211;<i>F814W </i>color properly measured in image C over the counter-image E, represents a total CO(6&#8211;5) line integrated flux decrease of 10%.</p>\n</div></div>\n<div><div>\n<a name=\"FN23\"></a><sup>4</sup> <p class=\"ligne\"> We find a slightly lower <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>r</i><sub>6,1</sub> = 0.25</span>, but still within the <span class=\"simple-math\">1<i>&#963;</i></span> uncertainty, when using the robust CO(1&#8211;0) and CO(6&#8211;5) line detections of the counter-image C alone (see Fig. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#F2\">2</a>).</p>\n</div></div>\n<div><div>\n<a name=\"FN24\"></a><sup>5</sup> <p class=\"ligne\"> Defined as <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#963;</i><sub>position</sub> &#8776; beam<sub>FWHM</sub>/ (2 &#215; <i>S</i>/<i>N</i>)</span> with the beam full width half maximum (<span class=\"simple-math\">beam<sub>FWHM</sub></span>) in arcseconds and the signal-to-noise ratio (S/N) of the detection (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#R15\">Condon 1997</a>).</p>\n</div></div>\n<div><div>\n<a name=\"FN25\"></a><sup>6</sup> <p class=\"ligne\"> Not detected down to the <span class=\"simple-math\">5<i>&#963;</i></span> magnitude limit of 27.4 as measured in a <span class=\"simple-math\">0.2&#8242;&#8242;</span> diameter aperture in the HST/ACS <i>F814W </i>filter.</p>\n</div></div>\n<div><div>\n<a name=\"FN26\"></a><sup>7</sup> <p class=\"ligne\"> We do not include the very tentative CO measurement from <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#R52\">Livermore et al. (2012)</a> obtained in a strongly lensed galaxy at <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i> ~ 4.9</span>.</p>\n</div></div>\n<div><div>\n<a name=\"FN27\"></a><sup>8</sup> <p class=\"ligne\"> Equivalent to <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>X</i><sub>CO,MW</sub> = 2 &#215; 10<sup>20</sup> cm<sup>-2</sup>/ (K km s<sup>-1</sup>)</span>.</p>\n</div></div>\n<div><div>\n<a name=\"FN28\"></a><sup>9</sup> <p class=\"ligne\">\n          <a href=\"http://www.arcetri.astro.it/metallicity/calibrazioni.pl\" target=\"_blank\">http://www.arcetri.astro.it/metallicity/calibrazioni.pl</a>\n        </p>\n</div></div>\n<div><div>\n<a name=\"FN29\"></a><sup>10</sup> <p class=\"ligne\"> Except for the Cosmic Eye at <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i> = 3.074</span>, where the gas-phase metallicity is determined from the <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>R</i>23</span> metallicity calibration.</p>\n</div></div>\n<div><div>\n<a name=\"FN30\"></a><sup>11</sup> <p class=\"ligne\"> At high redshift, it is generally assumed that <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>M</i><sub>H<sub>2</sub></sub> &#8811; <i>M</i><sub>H I</sub></span>, or equivalently <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>M</i><sub>H<sub>2</sub> + H I</sub> &#8771; <i>M</i><sub>molgas</sub> = <i>M</i><sub>dust</sub>/<i>&#948;</i><sub>DGR</sub></span>.</p>\n</div></div>\n    <h2 class=\"sec\">\n<a name=\"ack\"></a>Acknowledgments</h2>\n<p>We thank the IRAM staff of both the Plateau de Bure Interferometer and the 30 m telescope for the high-quality data acquired and for their support during observations and data reduction. We are, in particular, grateful to M&#233;lanie Krips, Jan Martin Winters, and Nicolas Billot. This work was supported by the Swiss National Science Foundation. </p>\n    <h2 class=\"sec\">\n<a name=\"ref\"></a>References</h2>\n    <div id=\"content\">\n        <ol class=\"references\">\n                    <li>\n                <a name=\"R1\"></a>Aravena, M., Spilker, J. target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Table 1</span></a><p>From optical to radio photometry and CO line integrated fluxes of MACSJ0032-arc.</p>\n<div class=\"in-txt\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#T1\">In the text</a></div>\n</div></div>\n<div class=\"inset\"><div class=\"ligne\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/T2.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Table 2</span></a><p>Physical properties of MACSJ0032-arc.</p>\n<div class=\"in-txt\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#T2\">In the text</a></div>\n</div></div>\n<h2 class=\"sec\">\n<a name=\"figs\"></a>All Figures</h2>\n<div class=\"inset\"><table>\n<tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/F1.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16-fig1_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/F1.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig. 1</span></a><p>Color-composite image of MACSJ0032-arc obtained using the HST/ACS <i>F606W </i>and <i>F814W </i>filters (<i>left panel</i>). The studied galaxy at <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i><sub>CO</sub> = 3.6314</span>, strongly lensed by the galaxy cluster MACS&#8201;J0032.1+1808, is composed of six multiple images well resolved in the HST image, labeled A, B, C, D, E, and F and encircled in white. They form a giant arc extending over <span class=\"simple-math\">42.4&#8242;&#8242;</span>. The <i>right panels </i>show, respectively, the zoom-in color-composite image obtained using the <i>Spitzer</i>/IRAC 3.6 and <span class=\"simple-math\">4.5 <i>&#956;</i></span>m bands over the multiple images B, C, D, E, and F (<i>top</i>) and the zoom-out color-composite image obtained using the <i>Herschel</i>/SPIRE 250, 350, and <span class=\"simple-math\">500 <i>&#956;</i></span>m bands; the white box represents a <span class=\"simple-math\">40&#8242;&#8242; &#215; 40&#8242;&#8242;</span> area.</p>\n</td>\n</tr>\n<tr><td colspan=\"2\"><a href=\"http://dexter.edpsciences.org/applet.php?pdf_id=1&amp;DOI=10.1051/0004-6361/201628513\" target=\"DEXTER\">Open with DEXTER</a></td></tr>\n<tr><td colspan=\"2\" class=\"in-txt\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#F1\">In the text</a></td></tr>\n</table></div>\n<div class=\"inset\"><table>\n<tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/F2.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16-fig2_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/F2.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig. 2</span></a><p><i>Herschel</i>/SPIRE <span class=\"simple-math\">250 <i>&#956;</i></span>m, <i>Spitzer</i>/IRAC <span class=\"simple-math\">3.6 <i>&#956;</i></span>m, PdBI 2 mm continuum, JVLA 5 GHz continuum, PdBI CO(6&#8211;5) line emission, and JVLA CO(1&#8211;0) line emission contours (in red) overlaid, <i>from left to right and from top to bottom</i>, on the HST/ACS <i>F814W </i>multiple images B, C, D, and E of MACSJ0032-arc. The contribution of the counter-image F is negligible. X refers to a galaxy member of the lensing cluster. Contour levels start at <span class=\"simple-math\">2<i>&#963;</i></span> and are spaced in steps of <span class=\"simple-math\">1<i>&#963;</i></span>, expect for IRAC <span class=\"simple-math\">3.6 <i>&#956;</i></span>m where the contours are in steps of 9, 16, 25, 36, <span class=\"simple-math\">49<i>&#963;</i></span>, etc. The SPIRE detection extends beyond the multiple images B, C, D, and E, as shown in Fig. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#F1\">1</a>, but peaks at <span class=\"simple-math\">4<i>&#963;</i></span> over B, C, D, and E. The rms levels of the 2 mm, 5 GHz, CO(6&#8211;5), and CO(1&#8211;0) data are 57 <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#956;</i></span>Jy, 1.7 <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#956;</i></span>Jy, 93 <span class=\"simple-math\">mJy km s<sup>-1</sup></span>, and 6.2 <span class=\"simple-math\">mJy km s<sup>-1</sup></span>, respectively. The size and orientation of the beam are indicated by the dotted (PdBI) or filled (JVLA) red ellipse in the bottom right corner. </p>\n</td>\n</tr>\n<tr><td colspan=\"2\"><a href=\"http://dexter.edpsciences.org/applet.php?pdf_id=2&amp;DOI=10.1051/0004-6361/201628513\" target=\"DEXTER\">Open with DEXTER</a></td></tr>\n<tr><td colspan=\"2\" class=\"in-txt\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#F2\">In the text</a></td></tr>\n</table></div>\n<div class=\"inset\"><table>\n<tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/F3.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16-fig3_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/F3.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig. 3</span></a><p>Observed HST/ACS <i>F814W </i>optical image of the multiple images B, C, D, E, and F of MACSJ0032-arc with the critical line in red (<i>left panel</i>); simulated observation of MACSJ0032-arc resulting from the best lens model when accounting for the PSF of the HST image (<i>middle panel</i>); and source plane reconstruction of MACSJ0032-arc obtained by simulating the morphology of the source as the combination of three elliptical Gaussian light profiles (<i>right panel</i>). The two bright knots, resolved in the HST rest-frame UV images, are separated by <span class=\"simple-math\">1.14 &#177; 0.28 kpc</span> in the source plane. The simulated HST observation includes a constant Gaussian noise background matched to the <i>F814W </i>noise level.</p>\n</td>\n</tr>\n<tr><td colspan=\"2\"><a href=\"http://dexter.edpsciences.org/applet.php?pdf_id=3&amp;DOI=10.1051/0004-6361/201628513\" target=\"DEXTER\">Open with DEXTER</a></td></tr>\n<tr><td colspan=\"2\" class=\"in-txt\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#F3\">In the text</a></td></tr>\n</table></div>\n<div class=\"inset\"><table>\n<tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/F4.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16-fig4_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/F4.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig. 4</span></a><p>Observed SED of MACSJ0032-arc at <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i><sub>CO</sub> = 3.6314</span>. Overlaid are the best-fit stellar SED (solid cyan line) obtained with the energy-conserving model and constant SFR SFH, as well as the best-fit FIR and mm SED obtained with the <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#R101\">Vega et al. (2008)</a> empirical template (solid red line) and the MBB with a <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#946;</i></span>-slope fixed at 2 (dashed black line).</p>\n</td>\n</tr>\n<tr><td colspan=\"2\"><a href=\"http://dexter.edpsciences.org/applet.php?pdf_id=4&amp;DOI=10.1051/0004-6361/201628513\" target=\"DEXTER\">Open with DEXTER</a></td></tr>\n<tr><td colspan=\"2\" class=\"in-txt\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#F4\">In the text</a></td></tr>\n</table></div>\n<div class=\"inset\"><table>\n<tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/F5.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16-fig5_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/F5.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig. 5</span></a><p>CMB corrected CO SLED of MACSJ0032-arc at <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i><sub>CO</sub> = 3.6314</span> (red stars) compared to the average CO SLEDs of the Milky Way (black crosses), the local (U)LIRGs (green circles), the <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i> ~ 1 &#8722; 4</span> SMGs (blue squares), and the <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i> ~ 1.5</span> BzK galaxies (magenta triangles). All SLEDs are normalized to the CO(1&#8211;0) flux of the average SLED for BzK galaxies, except the Milky Way normalized using CO(2&#8211;1).</p>\n</td>\n</tr>\n<tr><td colspan=\"2\"><a href=\"http://dexter.edpsciences.org/applet.php?pdf_id=5&amp;DOI=10.1051/0004-6361/201628513\" target=\"DEXTER\">Open with DEXTER</a></td></tr>\n<tr><td colspan=\"2\" class=\"in-txt\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#F5\">In the text</a></td></tr>\n</table></div>\n<div class=\"inset\"><table>\n<tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/F6.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16-fig6_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/F6.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig. 6</span></a><p>Comparison of the observed JVLA CO(1&#8211;0) line emission, PdBI CO(6&#8211;5) line emission, JVLA 5 GHz continuum, and PdBI 2 mm continuum contours, overlaid on the HST/ACS <i>F814W </i>multiple images B, C, D, and E of MACSJ0032-arc (<i>left panels</i>), with the respective simulated beam-convolved emission maps in the image plane (yellow contours in the <i>middle and right panels</i>) obtained for two different combinations of elliptical Gaussian light profiles in the source plane: one extended Gaussian component placed between the two HST UV-bright knots (yellow contours in the <i>top middle panel</i>) and two Gaussian components with locations and shapes following the two UV-bright knots (yellow contours in the <i>top right panel</i>). Noise realizations based on the data are added to the simulated maps, and the absolute flux scaling is obtained by matching the observed flux at the peak of the emission in the counter-image C in each of the CO(1&#8211;0), CO(6&#8211;5), 5 GHz, and 2 mm simulated maps. The critical line is in red. The size and orientation of the beams are indicated by the dashed green ellipses. Contour levels start at <span class=\"simple-math\">2<i>&#963;</i></span> and are spaced in steps of <span class=\"simple-math\">1<i>&#963;</i></span> (as in Fig. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#F2\">2</a>).</p>\n</td>\n</tr>\n<tr><td colspan=\"2\"><a href=\"http://dexter.edpsciences.org/applet.php?pdf_id=6&amp;DOI=10.1051/0004-6361/201628513\" target=\"DEXTER\">Open with DEXTER</a></td></tr>\n<tr><td colspan=\"2\" class=\"in-txt\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#F6\">In the text</a></td></tr>\n</table></div>\n<div class=\"inset\"><table>\n<tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/F7.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16-fig7_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/F7.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig. 7</span></a><p>Spectra of the CO(6&#8211;5), CO(4&#8211;3), and CO(1&#8211;0) emission lines detected in MACSJ0032-arc binned in steps of <span class=\"simple-math\">40.16 km s<sup>-1</sup></span>, expect for the CO(1&#8211;0) line where channels have a resolution of <span class=\"simple-math\">144.54 km s<sup>-1</sup></span>. The cyan-shaded regions indicate channels where positive emission is detected. These channels are used to derive the CO line integrated fluxes and the velocity-integrated and velocity-averaged maps shown in Figs. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#F2\">2</a> and <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#F8\">8</a>, respectively. The solid red lines show the single or double Gaussian profiles that best fit the observed CO line profiles. The zero velocity is set to <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i><sub>CO</sub> = 3.6314</span>.</p>\n</td>\n</tr>\n<tr><td colspan=\"2\"><a href=\"http://dexter.edpsciences.org/applet.php?pdf_id=7&amp;DOI=10.1051/0004-6361/201628513\" target=\"DEXTER\">Open with DEXTER</a></td></tr>\n<tr><td colspan=\"2\" class=\"in-txt\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#F7\">In the text</a></td></tr>\n</table></div>\n<div class=\"inset\"><table>\n<tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/F8.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16-fig8_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/F8.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig. 8</span></a><p>Velocity-averaged maps of the CO(6&#8211;5) emission of the counter-images E (<i>left panel</i>), C+D (<i>middle panel</i>), and B (<i>right panel</i>) of MACSJ0032-arc. Overlaid are the CO(6&#8211;5) contours integrated over, respectively, the channels that define the blue component (blue contours) and the red component (red contours) of the double-peaked CO(6&#8211;5) line profile shown in Fig. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#F7\">7</a>. The color-coding is in units of integrated flux <span class=\"simple-math\">Jy km s<sup>-1</sup></span> and starts at <span class=\"simple-math\">2<i>&#963;</i></span>. Contour levels also start at <span class=\"simple-math\">2<i>&#963;</i></span> and are spaced in steps of <span class=\"simple-math\">1<i>&#963;</i></span>. A clear spatial offset between the blue and red contours is observed. The corresponding PdBI beam size of <span class=\"simple-math\">1.94&#8242;&#8242; &#215; 1.62&#8242;&#8242;</span> is about the size of the individual counter-images themselves.</p>\n</td>\n</tr>\n<tr><td colspan=\"2\"><a href=\"http://dexter.edpsciences.org/applet.php?pdf_id=8&amp;DOI=10.1051/0004-6361/201628513\" target=\"DEXTER\">Open with DEXTER</a></td></tr>\n<tr><td colspan=\"2\" class=\"in-txt\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#F8\">In the text</a></td></tr>\n</table></div>\n<div class=\"inset\"><table>\n<tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/F9.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16-fig9_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/F9.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig. 9</span></a><p>Dependence of the metallicity-dependent CO-to-H<span class=\"simple-math\"><sub>2</sub></span> conversion function, computed from Eqs. (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#FD2\">2</a>)&#8211;(<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#FD4\">4</a>), on stellar mass and redshift. The lines are the iso-redshift curves, color-coded as a function of redshift, for <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i> = 0.5</span> to <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i> = 3.5</span> in steps of <span class=\"simple-math\">&#916;<i>z</i> = 0.5</span>: the solid sections correspond to <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16-eq225.png\"></span>, the dashed segments to <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16-eq226.png\"></span>, and the dotted portions to <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16-eq227.png\"></span>. The horizontal black line marks the Milky Way CO-to-H<span class=\"simple-math\"><sub>2</sub></span> conversion factor. Small symbols represent the computed <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16-eq217.png\"></span> values for MACSJ0032-arc (red star) as well as the compilation of MS SFGs with CO measurements from the literature (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#R24\">Dessauges-Zavadsky et al. 2015</a>). Large symbols correspond to the few MS SFGs for which gas-phase metallicities have been measured from rest-frame optical nebular lines. The symbols are color-coded according to galaxy redshift and their shapes indicate <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16-eq228.png\"></span> ratios (<span class=\"simple-math\">&lt;</span>1.5: circles, 1.5<span class=\"simple-math\">&#8722;</span>2: triangles, and <span class=\"simple-math\">&gt;</span>2: squares and star).</p>\n</td>\n</tr>\n<tr><td colspan=\"2\"><a href=\"http://dexter.edpsciences.org/applet.php?pdf_id=9&amp;DOI=10.1051/0004-6361/201628513\" target=\"DEXTER\">Open with DEXTER</a></td></tr>\n<tr><td colspan=\"2\" class=\"in-txt\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#F9\">In the text</a></td></tr>\n</table></div>\n<div class=\"inset\"><table>\n<tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/F10.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16-fig10_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/F10.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig. 10</span></a><p>Molecular gas depletion timescale as a function of redshift for our compilation of CO-detected MS SFGs from the literature (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#R24\">Dessauges-Zavadsky et al. 2015</a>) and MACSJ0032-arc at <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i><sub>CO</sub> = 3.6314</span> (star). The encircled data points correspond to MS SFGs with measured gas-phase metallicities. Five redshift bins are considered: <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i> ~ 0</span>, <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i> =  [ 0.055,0.4 ]</span>, <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i> =  [ 1,1.6 ]</span>, <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i> =  [ 2,2.5 ]</span>, and <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i> =  [ 2.7,3.6 ]</span>. The corresponding mean values of <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>t</i><sub>depl</sub></span> are shown as large black crosses with the associated <span class=\"simple-math\">1<i>&#963;</i></span> dispersion as standard deviation. Magenta crosses represent <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>t</i><sub>depl</sub></span> values from <a name=\"InR5\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#R5\">B&#233;thermin et al. (2015)</a> derived from the FIR dust continuum and by adopting the same mass-metallicity relation (Eq. (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#FD4\">4</a>)). The observed evolution of <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>t</i><sub>depl</sub></span> with redshift is parametrized by a power law; the best fit, <span class=\"simple-math\">1.15(1 + <i>z</i>)<sup>-0.85</sup></span>, is shown as a solid line.</p>\n</td>\n</tr>\n<tr><td colspan=\"2\"><a href=\"http://dexter.edpsciences.org/applet.php?pdf_id=10&amp;DOI=10.1051/0004-6361/201628513\" target=\"DEXTER\">Open with DEXTER</a></td></tr>\n<tr><td colspan=\"2\" class=\"in-txt\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#F10\">In the text</a></td></tr>\n</table></div>\n<div class=\"inset\"><table>\n<tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/F11.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16-fig11_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/F11.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig. 11</span></a><p>Same as Fig. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#F10\">10</a>, but for the molecular gas fraction. A clear evolution of <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>f</i><sub>molgas</sub></span> with redshift is observed, in good agreement with <span class=\"simple-math\">1 / (1 + (0.12(1 + <i>z</i>)<sup>1.95</sup>)<sup>-1</sup>)</span> (solid line).</p>\n</td>\n</tr>\n<tr><td colspan=\"2\"><a href=\"http://dexter.edpsciences.org/applet.php?pdf_id=11&amp;DOI=10.1051/0004-6361/201628513\" target=\"DEXTER\">Open with DEXTER</a></td></tr>\n<tr><td colspan=\"2\" class=\"in-txt\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#F11\">In the text</a></td></tr>\n</table></div>\n</div>\n\n\r\n</div>\r\n\r\n    <div id=\"metrics-tabs\" data-doi=\"10.1051/0004-6361/201628513\" data-edps_ref=\"aa28513-16\">\n<nav class=\"toolbar\">\n\t<button class=\"toolbar-item\" id=\"metrics-siq\">Current usage metrics</button>\n\t<button class=\"toolbar-item\" id=\"info\">About article metrics</button>\n    \n\t\n\t<button class=\"toolbar-item\" id=\"return\">Return to article</button>\n</nav>\n\n<div class=\"panel\" data-for=\"metrics-siq\">\n</div>\n\n<div class=\"panel\" data-for=\"metrics-alm\"></div>\n\n<div class=\"panel\" data-for=\"info\">\n\t\n\n\t<p>Current usage metrics show cumulative count of Article Views (full-text article views including HTML views, PDF and ePub downloads, according to the available data)  and Abstracts Views on Vision4Press platform.</p>\n\n\t<p>Data correspond to usage on the plateform after 2015. The current usage metrics is available 48-96 hours after online publication and is updated daily on week days.</p>\n\n\t<div class=\"msg msg-info\">\n\t\t<span class=\"ico Walth\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_author_institution\" content=\"University of California, Center for Astrophysics and Space Sciences, 9500 Gilman Drive, San Diego, CA 92093, USA\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_title\" content=\"Molecular gas properties of a lensed star-forming galaxy at z ~ 3.6: a case study\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_online_date\" content=\"2017/09/14\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_publication_date\" content=\"2017/09/01\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_volume\" content=\"605\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_firstpage\" content=\"A81\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_doi\" content=\"10.1051/0004-6361/201628513\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_bibcode\" content=\"2017A%26A...605A..81D\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_abstract_html_url\" content=\"https://www.aanda.org/articles/aa/abs/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_fulltext_html_url\" content=\"https://www.aanda.org/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_pdf_url\" content=\"https://www.aanda.org/articles/aa/pdf/2017/09/aa28513-16.pdf\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_issn\" content=\"0004-6361\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_issn\" content=\"1432-0746\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_language\" content=\"en\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_keyword\" content=\"cosmology: observations\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_keyword\" content=\"gravitational lensing: strong\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_keyword\" content=\"galaxies: high-redshift\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_keyword\" content=\"ISM: molecules\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_keyword\" content=\"galaxies: evolution\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_article_type\" content=\"Research Article\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_abstract\" lang=\"en\" content=\"We report on the galaxy MACSJ0032-arc at &lt;i&gt;z&lt;i/&gt;&lt;sub&gt;CO&lt;sub/&gt; = 3.6314 discovered during the &lt;i&gt;Herschel &lt;i/&gt;Lensing snapshot Survey of massive galaxy clusters, and strongly lensed by the cluster MACS\u2009J0032.1+1808. The successful detections of its rest-frame ultraviolet (UV), optical, far-infrared (FIR), millimeter, and radio continua, and of its CO emission enable us to characterize, for the first time at such a high redshift, the stellar, dust, and molecular gas properties of a compact star-forming galaxy with a size smaller than 2.5 kpc, a fairly low stellar mass of 4.8&lt;sup&gt;+ 0.5&lt;sup/&gt;&lt;sub&gt;-1.0&lt;sub/&gt; \u00d7 10&lt;sup&gt;9&lt;sup/&gt;&lt;i&gt;M&lt;i/&gt;&lt;sub&gt;\u2299&lt;sub/&gt;, and a moderate IR luminosity of 4.8&lt;sup&gt;+ 1.2&lt;sup/&gt;&lt;sub&gt;-0.6&lt;sub/&gt; \u00d7 10&lt;sup&gt;11&lt;sup/&gt;&lt;i&gt;L&lt;i/&gt;&lt;sub&gt;\u2299&lt;sub/&gt;. By combining the stretching effect of the lens with the high angular resolution imaging of the CO(1\u20130) line emission and the radio continuum at 5 GHz, we find that the bulk of the molecular gas mass and star formation seems to be spatially decoupled from the rest-frame UV emission. About 90% of the total star formation rate is undetected at rest-frame UV wavelengths because of severe obscuration by dust, but is seen through the thermal FIR dust emission and the radio synchrotron radiation. The observed CO(4\u20133) and CO(6\u20135) lines demonstrate that high-&lt;i&gt;J&lt;i/&gt; transitions, at least up to &lt;i&gt;J&lt;i/&gt; = 6, remain excited in this galaxy, whose CO spectral line energy distribution resembles that of high-redshift submm galaxies, even though the IR luminosity of MACSJ0032-arc is ten times lower. This high CO excitation is possibly due to the compactness of the galaxy. We find evidence that this high CO excitation has to be considered in the balance when estimating the CO-to-H&lt;sub&gt;2&lt;sub/&gt; conversion factor. Indeed, the respective CO-to-H&lt;sub&gt;2&lt;sub/&gt; conversion factors as derived from the correlation with metallicity and the FIR dust continuum can only be reconciled if excitation is accounted for. The inferred depletion time of the molecular gas in MACSJ0032-arc supports the decrease in the gas depletion timescale of galaxies with redshift, although to a lesser degree than predicted by galaxy evolution models. Instead, the measured molecular gas fraction as high as 60\u201379% in MACSJ0032-arc favors the continued increase in the gas fraction of galaxies with redshift as expected, despite the plateau observed between &lt;i&gt;z&lt;i/&gt; ~ 1.5 and &lt;i&gt;z&lt;i/&gt; ~ 2.5.\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_reference\" content=\"citation_author=M. function (request, callback) {\n\t        var term = request.term;\n            $.ajax({\n                url: '/index.php',\n                dataType: 'json',\n                method: 'GET',\n                data: {\n                    option: 'com_solr',\n                    task: 'auto_complete',\n                    query: term\n                },\n                success: function (data) {\n                    var suggestions = [];\n                    try {\n                        data.suggest.default[term].suggestions.forEach(function (s) { suggestions.push(s.term)}) } catch (e) {\n                    }\n\n                    callback(suggestions);\n                },\n                error: function (err) {\n                    callback([]);\n                }\n            });\n        };\n\n\t\t$('#search').find('input[name=q]').autocomplete({\n\t\t\tsource: source\n\t\t});\n\t});\n</script>\n\n                          <div class=\"header-cover\">\n                <div href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/T1.html#TFN4\">&#8224;</a></sup></td>\n                <td align=\"right\"> 0.035 <span class=\"simple-math\">&#177;</span></td>\n                <td align=\"left\"> 0.018<sup><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/T1.html#TFN4\">&#8224;</a></sup></td>\n                <td align=\"right\">0.21 <span class=\"simple-math\">&#177;</span></td>\n                <td align=\"left\"> 0.06<sup><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/T1.html#TFN6\">b</a></sup>, <sup><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/T1.html#TFN10\">f</a></sup></td>\n              </tr>\n            </table>\n      </div>\n      <div class=\"history\">\n              <p><b>Notes.</b> Observed (not lensing-corrected) continuum fluxes and CO line integrated fluxes, all with <span class=\"simple-math\">1<i>&#963;</i></span> uncertainties. The &#8220;total&#8221; refers to the sum of the signal coming from the multiple images B, C, D, and E, the contribution of the counter-image F being negligible.        </p>\n              <div><a name=\"TFN4\" id=\"TFN4\"></a><sup>(&#8224;)</sup> <p class=\"ligne\">Tentative detections below <span class=\"simple-math\">3<i>&#963;</i></span>.</p></div>\n              <div><a name=\"TFN5\" id=\"TFN5\"></a><sup>(a)</sup> <p class=\"ligne\">Estimated by propagating the IRAC&#8211;<i>F814W </i>colors properly measured in the counter-image B over the sum of multiple images B, C, D, and E (&#8220;total&#8221;).</p></div>\n              <div><a name=\"TFN6\" id=\"TFN6\"></a><sup>(b)</sup> <p class=\"ligne\">Obtained by integrating the flux over the same apertures as those used for the CO(6&#8211;5) emission detected over all multiple images B, C, D, and E.</p></div>\n              <div><a name=\"TFN7\" id=\"TFN7\"></a><sup>(c)</sup> <p class=\"ligne\">By applying the 2 mm&#8211;<i>F814W </i>color conservation over the multiple images, we get a higher total 2 mm continuum flux of 0.9 mJy.</p></div>\n              <div><a name=\"TFN8\" id=\"TFN8\"></a><sup>(d)</sup> <p class=\"ligne\">The color conservation is not satisfied, the measured flux is in excess.</p></div>\n              <div><a name=\"TFN9\" id=\"TFN9\"></a><sup>(e)</sup> <p class=\"ligne\">All the multiple images B, C, D, and E contribute to the observed CO(4&#8211;3) line integrated flux given the IRAM 30 m telescope half power beam width of <span class=\"simple-math\">24&#8242;&#8242;</span> at the redshifted frequency of the CO(4&#8211;3) line.</p></div>\n              <div><a name=\"TFN10\" id=\"TFN10\"></a><sup>(f)</sup> <p class=\"ligne\">By applying the CO(1&#8211;0)&#8211;<i>F814W </i>color conservation over the multiple images, we get a similar total CO(1&#8211;0) line integrated flux of 0.20 Jy km s<span class=\"simple-math\"><sup>-1</sup></span>.</p></div>\n            </div>\n    </div>\n  \n\r\n</div>\r\n\r\n    <div id=\"metrics-tabs\" data-doi=\"10.1051/0004-6361/201628513\" data-edps_ref=\"aa28513-16\">\n<nav class=\"toolbar\">\n\t<button class=\"toolbar-item\" Nyland\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_author_institution\" content=\"National Radio Astronomy Observatory, 520 Edgemont Rd, Charlottesville, VA 22903, USA\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_author\" content=\"G. Walth\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_author_institution\" content=\"University of California, Center for Astrophysics and Space Sciences, 9500 Gilman Drive, San Diego, CA 92093, USA\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_title\" content=\"Molecular gas properties of a lensed star-forming galaxy at z ~ 3.6: a case study\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_online_date\" content=\"2017/09/14\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_publication_date\" content=\"2017/09/01\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_volume\" content=\"605\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_firstpage\" content=\"A81\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_doi\" content=\"10.1051/0004-6361/201628513\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_bibcode\" content=\"2017A%26A...605A..81D\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_abstract_html_url\" content=\"https://www.aanda.org/articles/aa/abs/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_fulltext_html_url\" content=\"https://www.aanda.org/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_pdf_url\" content=\"https://www.aanda.org/articles/aa/pdf/2017/09/aa28513-16.pdf\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_issn\" content=\"0004-6361\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_issn\" content=\"1432-0746\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_language\" content=\"en\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_keyword\" content=\"cosmology: observations\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_keyword\" content=\"gravitational lensing: strong\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_keyword\" content=\"galaxies: high-redshift\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_keyword\" content=\"ISM: molecules\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_keyword\" content=\"galaxies: evolution\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_article_type\" content=\"Research Article\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_abstract\" lang=\"en\" content=\"We report on the galaxy MACSJ0032-arc at &lt;i&gt;z&lt;i/&gt;&lt;sub&gt;CO&lt;sub/&gt; = 3.6314 discovered during the &lt;i&gt;Herschel &lt;i/&gt;Lensing snapshot Survey of massive galaxy clusters, and strongly lensed by the cluster MACS\u2009J0032.1+1808. The successful detections of its rest-frame ultraviolet (UV), optical, far-infrared (FIR), millimeter, and radio continua, and of its CO emission enable us to characterize, for the first time at such a high redshift, the stellar, dust, and molecular gas properties of a compact star-forming galaxy with a size smaller than 2.5 kpc, a fairly low stellar mass of 4.8&lt;sup&gt;+ 0.5&lt;sup/&gt;&lt;sub&gt;-1.0&lt;sub/&gt; \u00d7 10&lt;sup&gt;9&lt;sup/&gt;&lt;i&gt;M&lt;i/&gt;&lt;sub&gt;\u2299&lt;sub/&gt;, and a moderate IR luminosity of 4.8&lt;sup&gt;+ 1.2&lt;sup/&gt;&lt;sub&gt;-0.6&lt;sub/&gt; \u00d7 10&lt;sup&gt;11&lt;sup/&gt;&lt;i&gt;L&lt;i/&gt;&lt;sub&gt;\u2299&lt;sub/&gt;. By combining the stretching effect of the lens with the high angular resolution imaging of the CO(1\u20130) line emission and the radio continuum at 5 GHz, we find that the bulk of the molecular gas mass and star formation seems to be spatially decoupled from the rest-frame UV emission. About 90% of the total star formation rate is undetected at rest-frame UV wavelengths because of severe obscuration by dust, but is seen through the thermal FIR dust emission and the radio synchrotron radiation. The observed CO(4\u20133) and CO(6\u20135) lines demonstrate that high-&lt;i&gt;J&lt;i/&gt; transitions, at least up to &lt;i&gt;J&lt;i/&gt; = 6, remain excited in this galaxy, whose CO spectral line energy distribution resembles that of high-redshift submm galaxies, even though the IR luminosity of MACSJ0032-arc is ten times lower. This high CO excitation is possibly due to the compactness of the galaxy. We find evidence that this high CO excitation has to be considered in the balance when estimating the CO-to-H&lt;sub&gt;2&lt;sub/&gt; conversion factor. Indeed, the respective CO-to-H&lt;sub&gt;2&lt;sub/&gt; conversion factors as derived from the correlation with metallicity and the FIR dust continuum can only be reconciled if excitation is accounted for. The inferred depletion time of the molecular gas in MACSJ0032-arc supports the decrease in the gas depletion timescale of galaxies with redshift, although to a lesser degree than predicted by galaxy evolution models. Instead, the measured molecular gas fraction as high as 60\u201379% in MACSJ0032-arc favors the continued increase in the gas fraction of galaxies with redshift as expected, despite the plateau observed between &lt;i&gt;z&lt;i/&gt; ~ 1.5 and &lt;i&gt;z&lt;i/&gt; ~ 2.5.\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_reference\" content=\"citation_author=M. function (request, callback) {\n\t        var term = request.term;\n            $.ajax({\n                url: '/index.php',\n                dataType: 'json',\n                method: 'GET',\n                data: {\n                    option: 'com_solr',\n                    task: 'auto_complete',\n                    query: term\n                },\n                success: function (data) {\n                    var suggestions = [];\n                    try {\n                        data.suggest.default[term].suggestions.forEach(function (s) { suggestions.push(s.term)}) } catch (e) {\n                    }\n\n                    callback(suggestions);\n                },\n                error: function (err) {\n                    callback([]);\n                }\n            });\n        };\n\n\t\t$('#search').find('input[name=q]').autocomplete({\n\t\t\tsource: source\n\t\t});\n\t});\n</script>\n\n                          <div class=\"header-cover\">\n                <div            </tr>\n            </table>\n      </div>\n      <div class=\"history\">\n              <p>\n                <b>Notes.</b>\n              </p>\n              <div><a name=\"TFN11\" id=\"TFN11\"></a><sup>(&#8224;)</sup> <p class=\"ligne\">Lensing-corrected values divided by <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#956;</i></span>.</p></div>\n              <div><a name=\"TFN12\" id=\"TFN12\"></a><sup>(a)</sup> <p class=\"ligne\">Total magnification factor of the multiple images B+C+D+E.</p></div>\n              <div><a name=\"TFN13\" id=\"TFN13\"></a><sup>(b)</sup> <p class=\"ligne\">IR luminosity obtained by integrating the [8, 1000] <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#956;</i></span>m interval of the best-fit FIR SED.</p></div>\n              <div><a name=\"TFN14\" id=\"TFN14\"></a><sup>(c)</sup> <p class=\"ligne\">Star formation rate as derived from the 5 GHz continuum and the SFR&#8211;1.4 GHz calibration from <a name=\"InR4\" id=\"InR4\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#R4\">Bell (2003)</a>. The total 5 GHz flux (Table <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#T1\">1</a>) is first corrected for the flux excess observed in image E by propagating the 5 GHz&#8211;<i>F814W </i>color properly measured in images B, C, and D over the counter-image E.</p></div>\n              <div><a name=\"TFN15\" id=\"TFN15\"></a><sup>(d)</sup> <p class=\"ligne\">Dust temperature and dust mass obtained from the MBB fit to the FIR and 2 mm data (Table <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#T1\">1</a>) with a <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#946;</i></span>-slope fixed at 2 and Eq. (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#FD1\">1</a>).</p></div>\n              <div><a name=\"TFN16\" id=\"TFN16\"></a><sup>(e)</sup> <p class=\"ligne\">CO luminosities inferred from the CO line integrated fluxes (<span class=\"simple-math\"><i>F</i><sub>CO</sub></span>) in <span class=\"simple-math\">Jy km s<sup>-1</sup></span> (Table <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#T1\">1</a>) that have been beforehand corrected against the CMB (Sect. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#S12\">4.3</a>), and derived using the <a name=\"InR89\" id=\"InR89\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#R89\">Solomon et al. (1997)</a> formula: <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16-eq128.png\" width=\"270\" height=\"18\" /></span>, where <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#957;</i><sub>obs</sub></span> is the observed CO line frequency in GHz, and <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>D</i><sub><i>L</i></sub></span> is the luminosity distance of the galaxy in Mpc.</p></div>\n              <div><a name=\"TFN17\" id=\"TFN17\"></a><sup>(f)</sup> <p class=\"ligne\">The total CO(6&#8211;5) line integrated flux (Table <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#T1\">1</a>) is first corrected for the flux excess observed in image E by propagating the CO(6&#8211;5)&#8211;<i>F814W </i>color properly measured in image C over the counter-image E.</p></div>\n              <div><a name=\"TFN18\" id=\"TFN18\"></a><sup>(g)</sup> <p class=\"ligne\">CO-to-H<span class=\"simple-math\"><sub>2</sub></span> conversion factor as computed in Sect. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#S16\">5.1</a>.</p></div>\n              <div><a name=\"TFN19\" id=\"TFN19\"></a><sup>(h)</sup> <p class=\"ligne\">Molecular gas mass obtained from <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16-eq131.png\" width=\"42\" height=\"17\" /></span> and the <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#945;</i><sub>CO</sub></span> quoted above.</p></div>\n            </div>\n    </div>\n  \n\r\n</div>\r\n\r\n    <div id=\"metrics-tabs\" data-doi=\"10.1051/0004-6361/201628513\" data-edps_ref=\"aa28513-16\">\n<nav Walth\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_author_institution\" content=\"University of California, Center for Astrophysics and Space Sciences, 9500 Gilman Drive, San Diego, CA 92093, USA\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_title\" content=\"Molecular gas properties of a lensed star-forming galaxy at z ~ 3.6: a case study\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_online_date\" content=\"2017/09/14\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_publication_date\" content=\"2017/09/01\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_volume\" content=\"605\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_firstpage\" content=\"A81\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_doi\" content=\"10.1051/0004-6361/201628513\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_bibcode\" content=\"2017A%26A...605A..81D\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_abstract_html_url\" content=\"https://www.aanda.org/articles/aa/abs/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_fulltext_html_url\" content=\"https://www.aanda.org/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_pdf_url\" content=\"https://www.aanda.org/articles/aa/pdf/2017/09/aa28513-16.pdf\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_issn\" content=\"0004-6361\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_issn\" content=\"1432-0746\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_language\" content=\"en\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_keyword\" content=\"cosmology: observations\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_keyword\" content=\"gravitational lensing: strong\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_keyword\" content=\"galaxies: high-redshift\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_keyword\" content=\"ISM: molecules\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_keyword\" content=\"galaxies: evolution\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_article_type\" content=\"Research Article\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_abstract\" lang=\"en\" content=\"We report on the galaxy MACSJ0032-arc at &lt;i&gt;z&lt;i/&gt;&lt;sub&gt;CO&lt;sub/&gt; = 3.6314 discovered during the &lt;i&gt;Herschel &lt;i/&gt;Lensing snapshot Survey of massive galaxy clusters, and strongly lensed by the cluster MACS\u2009J0032.1+1808. The successful detections of its rest-frame ultraviolet (UV), optical, far-infrared (FIR), millimeter, and radio continua, and of its CO emission enable us to characterize, for the first time at such a high redshift, the stellar, dust, and molecular gas properties of a compact star-forming galaxy with a size smaller than 2.5 kpc, a fairly low stellar mass of 4.8&lt;sup&gt;+ 0.5&lt;sup/&gt;&lt;sub&gt;-1.0&lt;sub/&gt; \u00d7 10&lt;sup&gt;9&lt;sup/&gt;&lt;i&gt;M&lt;i/&gt;&lt;sub&gt;\u2299&lt;sub/&gt;, and a moderate IR luminosity of 4.8&lt;sup&gt;+ 1.2&lt;sup/&gt;&lt;sub&gt;-0.6&lt;sub/&gt; \u00d7 10&lt;sup&gt;11&lt;sup/&gt;&lt;i&gt;L&lt;i/&gt;&lt;sub&gt;\u2299&lt;sub/&gt;. By combining the stretching effect of the lens with the high angular resolution imaging of the CO(1\u20130) line emission and the radio continuum at 5 GHz, we find that the bulk of the molecular gas mass and star formation seems to be spatially decoupled from the rest-frame UV emission. About 90% of the total star formation rate is undetected at rest-frame UV wavelengths because of severe obscuration by dust, but is seen through the thermal FIR dust emission and the radio synchrotron radiation. The observed CO(4\u20133) and CO(6\u20135) lines demonstrate that high-&lt;i&gt;J&lt;i/&gt; transitions, at least up to &lt;i&gt;J&lt;i/&gt; = 6, remain excited in this galaxy, whose CO spectral line energy distribution resembles that of high-redshift submm galaxies, even though the IR luminosity of MACSJ0032-arc is ten times lower. This high CO excitation is possibly due to the compactness of the galaxy. We find evidence that this high CO excitation has to be considered in the balance when estimating the CO-to-H&lt;sub&gt;2&lt;sub/&gt; conversion factor. Indeed, the respective CO-to-H&lt;sub&gt;2&lt;sub/&gt; conversion factors as derived from the correlation with metallicity and the FIR dust continuum can only be reconciled if excitation is accounted for. The inferred depletion time of the molecular gas in MACSJ0032-arc supports the decrease in the gas depletion timescale of galaxies with redshift, although to a lesser degree than predicted by galaxy evolution models. Instead, the measured molecular gas fraction as high as 60\u201379% in MACSJ0032-arc favors the continued increase in the gas fraction of galaxies with redshift as expected, despite the plateau observed between &lt;i&gt;z&lt;i/&gt; ~ 1.5 and &lt;i&gt;z&lt;i/&gt; ~ 2.5.\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_reference\" content=\"citation_author=M. function (request, callback) {\n\t        var term = request.term;\n            $.ajax({\n                url: '/index.php',\n                dataType: 'json',\n                method: 'GET',\n                data: {\n                    option: 'com_solr',\n                    task: 'auto_complete',\n                    query: term\n                },\n                success: function (data) {\n                    var suggestions = [];\n                    try {\n                        data.suggest.default[term].suggestions.forEach(function (s) { suggestions.push(s.term)}) } catch (e) {\n                    }\n\n                    callback(suggestions);\n                },\n                error: function (err) {\n                    callback([]);\n                }\n            });\n        };\n\n\t\t$('#search').find('input[name=q]').autocomplete({\n\t\t\tsource: source\n\t\t});\n\t});\n</script>\n\n                          <div class=\"header-cover\">\n                <div class=\"item-369\"><a href=\"/for-authors/latex-issues/the-preamble-of-your-tex-file\" >The preamble of your TEX file</a></li><li class=\"item-371\"><a href=\"/for-authors/latex-issues/the-manuscript-header\" >The manuscript header</a></li><li class=\"item-391\"><a href=\"/for-authors/latex-issues/including-author-names-using-non-roman-alphabets\" >Including author names using non-Roman alphabets</a></li><li class=\"item-372\"><a href=\"/for-authors/latex-issues/the-main-text\" >The main text</a></li><li class=\"item-373\"><a article</a></li></ul></li><li class=\"item-440\"><a href=\"/component/journal_price/\" >Subscriber information</a></li><li class=\"item-437\"><a href=\"/component/services/\" >Reader's services</a></li><li class=\"item-127\"><a href=\"/news\" >News</a></li></ul>\n\n                        </nav>\n                                            \n                      \n<div id=\"system-message-container\">\n</div>\n                      \n\n                      \n                                              <div class=\"flexme flexme-article\">\n                        <div class=\"article-content\">\n                                <div>\r\n    \n<div class=\"special_article green\">Free Access</div>\n    \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\r\n</div>\r\n\r\n \r\n    <div class=\"summary full\" >\n\t<table>\n\t\t\n\t\n\t\t<tr>\n\t\t<th valign=\"top\">\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\tIssue\n\t\t\t\t\t</th>\n\t\t<td width=\"10\"></td>\n\t\t<td>\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t<div>\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\tA&A\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t</div>\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t<div><strong>Volume </strong>605, September 2017\t\t\t\t</div>\n\t\t\t\t\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t</td>\n\t<tr><td colspan=\"3\" ></td></tr>\n\t<tr><td colspan=\"3\" class=\"sep_issue\"></td></tr>\n\t</tr>\n\t\n\t\t\t\t\t\t<tr>\n\t\t\t\t<th>\n\t\t\t\t\tArticle Number\n\t\t\t\t\t</th>\n\t\t\t\t<td></td>\n\t\t\t\t<td>A81</td>\n\t\t\t</tr>\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t<tr>\n\t\t\t\t<th>\n\t\t\t\t\tNumber of page(s)\n\t\t\t\t\t</th>\n\t\t\t\t<td></td>\n\t\t\t\t<td>18</td>\n\t\t\t</tr>\n\t\t\t\t\n\t\t\t<tr>\n\t\t\t<th>Section</th>\n\t\t\t<td></td>\n\t\t\t<td>Extragalactic astronomy</td>\n\t\t</tr>\n\t\t\n\t\t\t<tr>\n\t\t\t<th>DOI</th>\n\t\t\t<td></td>\n\t\t\t<td>\n\t\t\t\t<a href=\"https://doi.org/10.1051/0004-6361/201628513\">\n\t\t\t\t\thttps://doi.org/10.1051/0004-6361/201628513\n\t\t\t\t</a>\n\t\t\t</td>\n\t\t</tr>\n\t\t\n\t\t\t<tr>\n\t\t\t<th>Published online</th>\n\t\t\t<td></td>\n\t\t\t<td>\n\t\t\t\t14 September 2017\n\t\t\t</td>\n\t\t</tr>\n\t\t\n\t\t</table>\n</div>\n\r\n\r\n\r\n<div id=\"article\">\r\n    <!DOCTYPE html PUBLIC \"-//W3C//DTD XHTML 1.0 Transitional//EN\">\n\n<div class=\"menu\" id=\"bloc\"><ul>\n<li><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#top_full\">Top</a></li>\n<li><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#abs\">Abstract</a></li>\n<li><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#S1\">1. Introduction</a></li>\n<li><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#S2\">2. The target: MACSJ0032-arc</a></li>\n<li><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#S3\" title=\"Observations, data reduction, and flux estimates\">3. Observations, data ...</a></li>\n<li><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#S9\">4. Analysis and results</a></li>\n<li><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#S15\">5. Discussion</a></li>\n<li><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#S19\">6. Summary and conclusions</a></li>\n<li><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#ack\">Acknowledgments</a></li>\n<li><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#ref\">References</a></li>\n<li><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#tabs\">List of tables</a></li>\n<li><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#figs\">List of figures</a></li>\n</ul></div>\n<div id=\"contenu\">\n<a name=\"top_full\"></a><div id=\"head\">A&amp;A 605, A81 (2017)<h2 class=\"title\">Molecular gas properties of a lensed star-forming galaxy at <i>z </i><span class=\"simple-math\">~</span> 3.6: a case study<sup><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#FN1\">&#8902;</a></sup>\n</h2>\n<div class=\"article-authors\"><p class=\"bold\"><span id=\"aa28513-16-author-1\" data-url=\"/component/author/?dkey=10.1051/0004-6361/201628513&amp;n=1\" class=\"author\">M. Dessauges-Zavadsky</span><sup>1</sup>, <span id=\"aa28513-16-author-2\" data-url=\"/component/author/?dkey=10.1051/0004-6361/201628513&amp;n=2\" class=\"author\">M. Zamojski</span><sup>1</sup><sup>,<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#FN2\">&#8902;&#8902;</a></sup>, <span id=\"aa28513-16-author-3\" data-url=\"/component/author/?dkey=10.1051/0004-6361/201628513&amp;n=3\" class=\"author\">W. Rujopakarn</span><sup>2</sup><sup>,3</sup>, <span id=\"aa28513-16-author-4\" data-url=\"/component/author/?dkey=10.1051/0004-6361/201628513&amp;n=4\" class=\"author\">J. Richard</span><sup>4</sup>, <span id=\"aa28513-16-author-5\" data-url=\"/component/author/?dkey=10.1051/0004-6361/201628513&amp;n=5\" class=\"author\">P. Sklias</span><sup>1</sup>, <span id=\"aa28513-16-author-6\" data-url=\"/component/author/?dkey=10.1051/0004-6361/201628513&amp;n=6\" class=\"author\">D. Schaerer</span><sup>1</sup><sup>,5</sup>, <span id=\"aa28513-16-author-7\" data-url=\"/component/author/?dkey=10.1051/0004-6361/201628513&amp;n=7\" class=\"author\">F. Combes</span><sup>6</sup>, <span id=\"aa28513-16-author-8\" data-url=\"/component/author/?dkey=10.1051/0004-6361/201628513&amp;n=8\" class=\"author\">H. Ebeling</span><sup>7</sup>, <span id=\"aa28513-16-author-9\" data-url=\"/component/author/?dkey=10.1051/0004-6361/201628513&amp;n=9\" class=\"author\">T. D. Rawle</span><sup>8</sup>, <span id=\"aa28513-16-author-10\" data-url=\"/component/author/?dkey=10.1051/0004-6361/201628513&amp;n=10\" class=\"author\">E. Egami</span><sup>9</sup>, <span id=\"aa28513-16-author-11\" data-url=\"/component/author/?dkey=10.1051/0004-6361/201628513&amp;n=11\" class=\"author\">F. Boone</span><sup>5</sup>, <span id=\"aa28513-16-author-12\" data-url=\"/component/author/?dkey=10.1051/0004-6361/201628513&amp;n=12\" class=\"author\">B. Cl&#233;ment</span><sup>4</sup>, <span id=\"aa28513-16-author-13\" data-url=\"/component/author/?dkey=10.1051/0004-6361/201628513&amp;n=13\" class=\"author\">J.-P. Kneib</span><sup>10</sup><sup>,11</sup>, <span id=\"aa28513-16-author-14\" data-url=\"/component/author/?dkey=10.1051/0004-6361/201628513&amp;n=14\" class=\"author\">K. Nyland</span><sup>12</sup> and <span id=\"aa28513-16-author-15\" data-url=\"/component/author/?dkey=10.1051/0004-6361/201628513&amp;n=15\" class=\"author\">G. Walth</span><sup>13</sup></p></div>\n<p class=\"aff\"><sup>1</sup> Observatoire de Gen&#232;ve, Universit&#233; de Gen&#232;ve, 51 Ch. des Maillettes,  1290 Versoix,  Switzerland \n<br>\n            e-mail: miroslava.dessauges@unige.ch\n          <br><sup>2</sup> Department of Physics, Faculty of Science, Chulalongkorn University, 254 Phayathai Road, Pathumwan,  10330   Bangkok,  Thailand \n<br><sup>3</sup> Kavli Institute for the Physics and Mathematics of the Universe (WPI), University of Tokyo Institutes for Advanced Study, Kashiwa,  277-8583   Chiba,  Japan \n<br><sup>4</sup> Universit&#233; Lyon, Universit&#233; Lyon 1, ENS de Lyon, CNRS, Centre de Recherche Astrophysique de Lyon UMR 5574,  69230   Saint-Genis-Laval,  France \n<br><sup>5</sup>  CNRS, IRAP, 14 Avenue E. Belin,  31400   Toulouse,  France \n<br><sup>6</sup> Observatoire de Paris, LERMA,  61 Avenue de l&#8217;Observatoire,  75014   Paris,  France \n<br><sup>7</sup> Institute for Astronomy, University of Hawaii,  2680 Woodlawn Drive,  Honolulu,  HI   96822,  USA \n<br><sup>8</sup>  ESA/Space Telescope Science Institute (STScI),  3700 San Martin Drive,  Baltimore,  MD   21218,  USA \n<br><sup>9</sup> Steward Observatory, University of Arizona,  933 North Cherry Avenue,  Tucson,  AZ   85721,  USA \n<br><sup>10</sup> Laboratoire d&#8217;Astrophysique, &#201;cole Polytechnique F&#233;d&#233;rale de Lausanne (EPFL),  1290   Versoix,  Switzerland \n<br><sup>11</sup> Aix Marseille Universit&#233;, CNRS, LAM, UMR 7326,  13388   Marseille,  France \n<br><sup>12</sup>  National Radio Astronomy Observatory,  520 Edgemont Rd,  Charlottesville,  VA   22903,  USA \n<br><sup>13</sup> University of California, Center for Astrophysics and Space Sciences,  9500 Gilman Drive,  San Diego,  CA   92093,  USA \n<br></p>\n<p class=\"history\"><span class=\"bold\">Received: </span>14 March 2016<br><span class=\"bold\">Accepted: </span>12 June 2017</p>\n<p class=\"bold\"><a name=\"abs\"></a>Abstract</p>\n        <p>We report on the galaxy MACSJ0032-arc at <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i><sub>CO</sub> = 3.6314</span> discovered during the <i>Herschel </i>Lensing snapshot Survey of massive galaxy clusters, and strongly lensed by the cluster MACS&#8201;J0032.1+1808. The successful detections of its rest-frame ultraviolet (UV), optical, far-infrared (FIR), millimeter, and radio continua, and of its CO emission enable us to characterize, for the first time at such a high redshift, the stellar, dust, and molecular gas properties of a compact star-forming galaxy with a size smaller than 2.5 kpc, a fairly low stellar mass of <span class=\"simple-math\">4.8<sup>+ 0.5</sup></span><span class=\"simple-math\"><sub>-1.0</sub> &#215; 10<sup>9</sup><i>M</i><sub>&#8857;</sub></span>, and a moderate IR luminosity of <span class=\"simple-math\">4.8<sup>+ 1.2</sup></span><span class=\"simple-math\"><sub>-0.6</sub> &#215; 10<sup>11</sup><i>L</i><sub>&#8857;</sub></span>. By combining the stretching effect of the lens with the high angular resolution imaging of the CO(1&#8211;0) line emission and the radio continuum at 5 GHz, we find that the bulk of the molecular gas mass and star formation seems to be spatially decoupled from the rest-frame UV emission. About 90% of the total star formation rate is undetected at rest-frame UV wavelengths because of severe obscuration by dust, but is seen through the thermal FIR dust emission and the radio synchrotron radiation. The observed CO(4&#8211;3) and CO(6&#8211;5) lines demonstrate that high-<span class=\"simple-math\"><i>J</i></span> transitions, at least up to <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>J</i> = 6</span>, remain excited in this galaxy, whose CO spectral line energy distribution resembles that of high-redshift submm galaxies, even though the IR luminosity of MACSJ0032-arc is ten times lower. This high CO excitation is possibly due to the compactness of the galaxy. We find evidence that this high CO excitation has to be considered in the balance when estimating the CO-to-H<span class=\"simple-math\"><sub>2</sub></span> conversion factor. Indeed, the respective CO-to-H<span class=\"simple-math\"><sub>2</sub></span> conversion factors as derived from the correlation with metallicity and the FIR dust continuum can only be reconciled if excitation is accounted for. The inferred depletion time of the molecular gas in MACSJ0032-arc supports the decrease in the gas depletion timescale of galaxies with redshift, although to a lesser degree than predicted by galaxy evolution models. Instead, the measured molecular gas fraction as high as 60&#8211;79% in MACSJ0032-arc favors the continued increase in the gas fraction of galaxies with redshift as expected, despite the plateau observed between <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i> ~ 1.5</span> and <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i> ~ 2.5</span>. </p>\n      <div class=\"kword\"><p><span class=\"bold\">Key words: </span>cosmology: observations / gravitational lensing: strong / galaxies: high-redshift / ISM: molecules / galaxies: evolution</p></div>\n<div class=\"note\">\n<hr width=\"30%\" align=\"left\">\n<div>\n<a name=\"FN1\"></a><sup>&#8902;</sup> <p class=\"ligne\">Based on observations carried out with the IRAM Plateau de Bure Interferometer, the IRAM 30 m telescope, and the NRAO Karl G. Jansky Very Large Array. The Institut de Radioastronomie Millim&#233;trique (IRAM) is supported by CNRS/INSU (France), the MPG (Germany), and the IGN (Spain). The National Radio Astronomy Observatory (NRAO) is a facility of the National Science Foundation operated under cooperative agreement by Associated Universities, Inc.</p>\n</div>\n<div>\n<a name=\"FN2\"></a><sup>&#8902;&#8902;</sup> <p class=\"ligne\">Independent researcher, New York, NY, USA.</p>\n</div>\n</div>\n</div>\n<p><i>&#169; ESO, 2017</i></p>\n<h2 class=\"sec\">\n<a name=\"S1\"></a>1. Introduction</h2>\n<p>In order to track the star formation in galaxies and understand how gas is converted into stars, it is essential to study the prevalence and distribution of molecular gas across cosmic time. In recent years, molecular gas mass measurements have finally become feasible for normal galaxies, that is star-forming galaxies (SFGs) lying on the main sequence (MS) at redshifts <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i>&lt; 2.5</span> and featuring stellar masses of <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>M</i><sub>&#8727;</sub>&gt; 2.5 &#215; 10<sup>10</sup><i>M</i><sub>&#8857;</sub></span>  (e.g., <a name=\"InR19\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#R19\">Daddi et al. 2010</a>; <a name=\"InR34\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#R34\">Genzel et al. 2010</a>; <a name=\"InR32\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#R32\">Geach et al. 2011</a>; <a name=\"InR95\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#R95\">Tacconi et al. 2010</a>, <a name=\"InR96\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#R96\">2013</a>). These galaxies, following the fairly tight relation between <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>M</i><sub>&#8727;</sub></span> and star formation rate (SFR) with a dispersion of <span class=\"simple-math\">&#177; 0.3 dex</span>, contribute <span class=\"simple-math\">~</span>80<span class=\"simple-math\">&#8722;</span>90% of the cosmic SFR density at redshifts <span class=\"simple-math\">0 &lt;<i>z</i>&lt; 3</span>  (<a name=\"InR18\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#R18\">Daddi et al. 2007</a>; <a name=\"InR73\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#R73\">Rodighiero et al. 2011</a>; <a name=\"InR108\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#R108\">Wuyts et al. 2011</a>; <a name=\"InR74\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#R74\">Rodighiero et al. 2015</a>; <a name=\"InR84\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#R84\">Schreiber et al. 2015</a>). </p>\n<p>\n        \n        <a name=\"F1\"></a><div class=\"inset\"><table>\n<tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/F1.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16-fig1_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/F1.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig. 1</span></a><p>Color-composite image of MACSJ0032-arc obtained using the HST/ACS <i>F606W </i>and <i>F814W </i>filters (<i>left panel</i>). The studied galaxy at <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i><sub>CO</sub> = 3.6314</span>, strongly lensed by the galaxy cluster MACS&#8201;J0032.1+1808, is composed of six multiple images well resolved in the HST image, labeled A, B, C, D, E, and F and encircled in white. They form a giant arc extending over <span class=\"simple-math\">42.4&#8242;&#8242;</span>. The <i>right panels </i>show, respectively, the zoom-in color-composite image obtained using the <i>Spitzer</i>/IRAC 3.6 and <span class=\"simple-math\">4.5 <i>&#956;</i></span>m bands over the multiple images B, C, D, E, and F (<i>top</i>) and the zoom-out color-composite image obtained using the <i>Herschel</i>/SPIRE 250, 350, and <span class=\"simple-math\">500 <i>&#956;</i></span>m bands; the white box represents a <span class=\"simple-math\">40&#8242;&#8242; &#215; 40&#8242;&#8242;</span> area.</p>\n</td>\n</tr>\n<tr><td colspan=\"2\"><a href=\"http://dexter.edpsciences.org/applet.php?pdf_id=1&amp;DOI=10.1051/0004-6361/201628513\" target=\"DEXTER\">Open with DEXTER</a></td></tr>\n</table></div>\n      </p>\n<p>\n        \n        <a name=\"F2\"></a><div class=\"inset\"><table>\n<tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/F2.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16-fig2_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/F2.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig. 2</span></a><p><i>Herschel</i>/SPIRE <span class=\"simple-math\">250 <i>&#956;</i></span>m, <i>Spitzer</i>/IRAC <span class=\"simple-math\">3.6 <i>&#956;</i></span>m, PdBI 2 mm continuum, JVLA 5 GHz continuum, PdBI CO(6&#8211;5) line emission, and JVLA CO(1&#8211;0) line emission contours (in red) overlaid, <i>from left to right and from top to bottom</i>, on the HST/ACS <i>F814W </i>multiple images B, C, D, and E of MACSJ0032-arc. The contribution of the counter-image F is negligible. X refers to a galaxy member of the lensing cluster.
