Contour levels start at <span class=\"simple-math\">2<i>&#963;</i></span> and are spaced in steps of <span class=\"simple-math\">1<i>&#963;</i></span>, expect for IRAC <span class=\"simple-math\">3.6 <i>&#956;</i></span>m where the contours are in steps of 9, 16, 25, 36, <span class=\"simple-math\">49<i>&#963;</i></span>, etc. The SPIRE detection extends beyond the multiple images B, C, D, and E, as shown in Fig. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#F1\">1</a>, but peaks at <span class=\"simple-math\">4<i>&#963;</i></span> over B, C, D, and E. The rms levels of the 2 mm, 5 GHz, CO(6&#8211;5), and CO(1&#8211;0) data are 57 <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#956;</i></span>Jy, 1.7 <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#956;</i></span>Jy, 93 <span class=\"simple-math\">mJy km s<sup>-1</sup></span>, and 6.2 <span class=\"simple-math\">mJy km s<sup>-1</sup></span>, respectively. The size and orientation of the beam are indicated by the dotted (PdBI) or filled (JVLA) red ellipse in the bottom right corner. </p>\n</td>\n</tr>\n<tr><td colspan=\"2\"><a href=\"http://dexter.edpsciences.org/applet.php?pdf_id=2&amp;DOI=10.1051/0004-6361/201628513\" target=\"DEXTER\">Open with DEXTER</a></td></tr>\n</table></div>\n      </p>\n<p>With the increasing number of CO measurements obtained for MS SFGs, we are starting to highlight the significant role that the molecular gas plays in galaxies in general and in the implementation of the MS itself. Indeed, in the local Universe it has now been established that the location of a galaxy in the SFR&#8211;<span class=\"simple-math\"><i>M</i><sub>&#8727;</sub></span> plane is primarily governed by its supply of molecular gas, whereas variations in the star formation efficiency (<span class=\"simple-math\"><i>SFE</i></span>) only play a secondary role (<a name=\"InR76\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#R76\">Saintonge et al. 2012</a>). Similar conclusions have been reached for high-redshift galaxies (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#R96\">Tacconi et al. 2013</a>; <a name=\"InR24\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#R24\">Dessauges-Zavadsky et al. 2015</a>), although <a name=\"InR37\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#R37\">Genzel et al. (2015)</a> find equal contributions from the <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>SFE</i></span> and the molecular gas content for the offset of galaxies from the MS. Likewise, the observed evolution of the MS with redshift that results in the increase in the specific star formation rate (sSFR) with cosmic time (<a name=\"InR79\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#R79\">Schaerer &amp; de Barros 2009</a>; <a name=\"InR72\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#R72\">Rodighiero et al. 2010</a>; <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#R84\">Schreiber et al. 2015</a>) is closely linked to the behavior of the molecular gas. Current observations convincingly show that the rapid rise in the sSFR of galaxies up to <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i> ~ 2</span> can be explained by the comparable rise in their molecular gas fraction (<span class=\"simple-math\"><i>f</i><sub>molgas</sub></span>) with cosmic time and their slowly varying molecular gas depletion timescale (<span class=\"simple-math\"><i>t</i><sub>depl</sub></span>) (<a name=\"InR31\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#R31\">Geach et al. 2009</a>, <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#R32\">2011</a>; <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#R34\">Genzel et al. 2010</a>, <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#R37\">2015</a>; <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#R19\">Daddi et al. 2010</a>; <a name=\"InR3\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#R3\">Bauermeister et al. 2013</a>; <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#R95\">Tacconi et al. 2010</a>, <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#R96\">2013</a>). Beyond <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i> &#8819; 2</span>, it remains a subject of debate whether <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>f</i><sub>molgas</sub></span> continues to increase or whether, instead, the decrease in <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>t</i><sub>depl</sub></span> is steepening (<a name=\"InR77\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#R77\">Saintonge et al. 2013</a>; <a name=\"InR97\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#R97\">Tan et al. 2013</a>; <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#R24\">Dessauges-Zavadsky et al. 2015</a>), primarily due to the lack of molecular gas mass measurements available so far for MS SFGs at <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i>&gt; 2.5</span>. </p>\n<p>While determining the molecular gas content in individual MS SFGs at <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i>&gt; 2.5</span> is challenging, it is feasible with the help of strong gravitational lensing, which enables us to push beyond current instrumental sensitivity thresholds. Indeed, of the five CO measurements performed to date for <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i>&gt; 2.5</span> MS SFGs, four were obtained in strongly lensed SFGs, and the fifth was obtained in a very massive (<span class=\"simple-math\"><i>M</i><sub>&#8727;</sub> = 10<sup>11</sup><i>M</i><sub>&#8857;</sub></span>) unlensed SFG (<a name=\"InR69\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#R69\">Riechers et al. 2010</a>; <a name=\"InR42\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#R42\">Johansson et al. 2012</a>; <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#R97\">Tan et al. 2013</a>; <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#R77\">Saintonge et al. 2013</a>). Indirect estimates of the molecular gas masses in some 53 massive MS galaxies at <span class=\"simple-math\">2.7 &lt;<i>z</i>&lt; 4</span> with <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>M</i><sub>&#8727;</sub>&gt; 2 &#215; 10<sup>10</sup><i>M</i><sub>&#8857;</sub></span> were recently reported by <a name=\"InR85\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#R85\">Scoville et al. (2016)</a> and <a name=\"InR82\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#R82\">Schinnerer et al. (2016)</a> based on 1 mm dust continuum emissions detected with the Atacama Large Millimeter Array (ALMA). </p>\n<p>We report here on the CO(6&#8211;5), CO(4&#8211;3), and CO(1<span class=\"simple-math\">&#8722;</span>0) line detections for a newly discovered star-forming galaxy at <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i><sub>CO</sub> = 3.6314</span>, strongly lensed by the galaxy cluster MACS&#8201;J0032.1+1808 (<a name=\"InR27\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#R27\">Ebeling et al. 2001</a>), hereafter denoted MACSJ0032-arc. Featuring the highest redshift at which an estimate of the molecular gas mass has been obtained from CO in a normal low-mass SFG, this galaxy is of particular interest for a detailed study aimed at addressing key questions: What are the <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>f</i><sub>molgas</sub></span> and <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>t</i><sub>depl</sub></span>  evolutionary trends at very high redshift? Is the CO-to-H<span class=\"simple-math\"><sub>2</sub></span> conversion factor significantly different at <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i> ~ 3.6</span>? Does the CO spectral line energy distribution (SLED) vary with respect to the SLEDs of lower redshift MS SFGs? Is the cold gas CO emission spatially correlated with the stellar UV emission? </p>\n<p>Our paper is organized as follows. In Sect. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#S2\">2</a> we introduce our target, and in Sect. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#S3\">3</a> we describe the multiwavelength observations performed from the optical through the infrared, far-infrared, and millimeter to the radio regime. The analysis of the data including the gravitational lens modeling and the inferred stellar, dust, and CO molecular gas properties of MACSJ0032-arc can be found in Sect. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#S9\">4</a>. We discuss these results in the context of MS SFGs with CO measurements and explore the redshift evolution of both the molecular gas depletion timescale and the molecular gas fraction in Sect. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#S15\">5</a>. We also estimate the CO-to-H<span class=\"simple-math\"><sub>2</sub></span> conversion factor using two different methods and highlight their respective strengths and weaknesses. A summary and conclusions follow in Sect. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#S19\">6</a>. Throughout the paper, we assume a <span class=\"simple-math\">&#923;</span>CDM cosmology with <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>H</i><sub>0</sub> = 70 km s<sup>-1</sup> Mpc<sup>-1</sup></span>, <span class=\"simple-math\">&#937;<sub>M</sub> = 0.29</span>, and <span class=\"simple-math\">&#937;<sub>&#923;</sub> = 0.71</span>, and the <a name=\"InR12\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#R12\">Chabrier (2003)</a> initial mass  function. </p>\n<h2 class=\"sec\">\n<a name=\"S2\"></a>2. The target: MACSJ0032-arc</h2>\n<p>We report on a newly discovered galaxy, MACSJ0032-arc, identified as a bright FIR emitter in the <i>Herschel </i>Lensing snapshot Survey (HLS-snapshot; Egami et al., in prep.). Designed to find strongly lensed sources at high redshift, the survey used <i>Herschel</i>/SPIRE to image the fields around more than 300 massive galaxy clusters. Located at <span class=\"simple-math\">RA = 00</span>:32:07.776, <span class=\"simple-math\">Dec =  + 18</span>:06:47.80, MACSJ0032-arc is strongly lensed by the galaxy cluster MACS&#8201;J0032.1+1808 at <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i> = 0.377</span> (Ebeling &amp; Repp, in prep.). The redshift of the lensed system was first accessed from weak rest-frame UV interstellar medium (ISM) lines and the Ly<span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#945;</i></span> break detected in absorption in the spectrum we obtained with LRIS on the Keck&#8201;I telescope, <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i><sub>ISM</sub> = 3.626 &#177; 0.001</span> (Richard et al., in prep.). It was then confirmed with our firm detections of the CO(4&#8211;3) and CO(6&#8211;5) emission lines at <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i><sub>CO</sub> = 3.6314 &#177; 0.0005</span> with the IRAM 30 m telescope. Very recently, we also detected the nebular [O&#8201;<span class=\"smallcaps\">iii</span>]&#8201;<span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#955;</i></span>5007 and H<span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#946;</i></span> emission lines at <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i><sub>neb</sub> = 3.633 &#177; 0.003</span>, redshifted in the near-IR, with LUCI on the LBT (Walth et al., in prep.). The systemic redshift of MACSJ0032-arc is hence well constrained by both <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i><sub>CO</sub></span> and <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i><sub>neb</sub></span>, which agree within their <span class=\"simple-math\">1<i>&#963;</i></span>  errors. The ISM absorption lines at <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i><sub>ISM</sub></span> appear blueshifted with respect to the systemic redshift of the galaxy by <span class=\"simple-math\">&#8722; 350 &#177; 65 km s<sup>-1</sup></span>. </p>\n<p>MACSJ0032-arc was also observed in the infrared (IR) as part of the <i>Spitzer</i>/IRAC Lensing Survey, and in the optical regime in ongoing efforts to image strong-lensing clusters with the <i>Hubble </i>Space Telescope (HST). It has been detected at all these wavelengths, as is shown in Fig. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#F1\">1</a>. These observations combined with millimeter (mm) and radio data obtained with the Plateau de Bure Interferometer (PdBI) and the Jansky Very Large Array (JVLA), respectively, enable us to derive the stellar, dust, and molecular gas properties of this <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i> ~ 3.6</span> galaxy. </p>\n<p>The high-quality, high-resolution rest-frame UV images obtained with HST reveal six images of this high-redshift galaxy, labeled A, B, C, D, E, and F throughout the paper, as illustrated in Fig. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#F1\">1</a>. The counter-image F is very faint and barely visible, located very close to a lensing cluster galaxy member. A seventh counter-image exists, but is de-amplified and hence invisible. All of these images originate from the same background galaxy, amplified by different magnification factors, and form a giant arc extending over <span class=\"simple-math\">42.4&#8242;&#8242;</span>. Moreover, the lensed galaxy is resolved into two compact, UV-bright knots, separated by <span class=\"simple-math\">~</span><span class=\"simple-math\">0.8&#8242;&#8242;</span> in the most amplified multiple images B, C, D, and E, plus a tail attached to the brightest knot. The high-resolution JVLA observations enable us to resolve the CO(1&#8211;0) line emission and the 5 GHz radio continuum as well within the multiple images B, C, D, and E, and to compare the location of the molecular gas and dust-obscured star formation with respect to the rest-frame UV emission. </p>\n<p>In what follows, we focus our analysis only on the brightest multiple images B, C, D, and E, covered by all our data and detected in most of them, as shown and discussed in Sect. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#S3\">3</a>. </p>\n<h2 class=\"sec\">\n<a name=\"S3\"></a>3. Observations, data reduction, and flux estimates</h2>\n<h3 class=\"sec2\">\n<a name=\"S4\"></a>3.1. HST, Spitzer, and Herschel data</h3>\n<p>The lensing cluster has been observed in two HST/ACS passbands, <i>F606W </i>and <i>F814W</i>. The astrometry of the two HST images has been adjusted to the astrometry of the interferometric JVLA 5 GHz continuum image by cross-matching positions of seven bright point-like sources detected in both the HST/ACS <i>F606W+F814W </i>images and in the JVLA image at more than <span class=\"simple-math\">10<i>&#963;</i></span> and <span class=\"simple-math\">8<i>&#963;</i></span>, respectively. Median corrections of <span class=\"simple-math\">+ 0.06&#8242;&#8242;</span> in right ascension and <span class=\"simple-math\">&#8722; 0.17&#8242;&#8242;</span> in declination were applied to the HST astrometry. The resulting absolute positional error is about 45 mas for the two HST passbands. </p>\n<p>In these high-resolution HST optical images, the multiple images of MACSJ0032-arc and the associated substructure are all resolved, and are generally unblended with foreground galaxy light in the cluster field. The sole exception is the elliptical galaxy, a cluster member labeled X, which affects the photometry of the very faint counter-image F and marginally affects image D (see Figs. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#F1\">1</a> and <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#F2\">2</a>). We fit and subtracted the light profile of galaxy X using <tt>GALFIT </tt>(<a name=\"InR64\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#R64\">Peng et al. 2002</a>). To measure the flux of each counter-image, we first created segmentation maps by selecting, in the <i>F814W </i>image convolved with a 3-pixel full width half maximum (FWHM) Gaussian, all pixels above <span class=\"simple-math\">1<i>&#963;</i></span>. We separate counter-images C and D, that form a continuous arc, at the location of the critical line (see Fig. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#F1\">1</a>). We use these segments to integrate the flux in the <i>F814W </i>band and in the properly aligned <i>F606W </i>image. We hence obtain clean rest-frame UV-photometry individually for each of the multiple images B, C, D, and E. </p>\n<p>\n          <a name=\"T1\"></a><div class=\"inset\"><div class=\"ligne\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/T1.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Table 1</span></a><p>From optical to radio photometry and CO line integrated fluxes of MACSJ0032-arc.</p>\n</div></div>\n        </p>\n<p>Because of the much coarser resolution of the <i>Spitzer</i>/IRAC IR images available in the 3.6 and 4.5 <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#956;</i></span>m passbands, the multiple images C, D, E, and F are blended with each other, as well as with the cluster member X mentioned above. This can be clearly seen in Fig. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#F2\">2</a>, where we overlay the IRAC 3.6 <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#956;</i></span>m contours on the HST <i>F814W </i>image. The IRAC flux even seems to peak at the position of galaxy X. Therefore, we derive the rest-frame optical photometry only for the well-resolved and unblended counter-image B. For this purpose, we performed prior-based photometry, as in <a name=\"InR87\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#R87\">Sklias et al. (2014)</a>. We used the reddest HST band to produce the so-called stamp image of the counter-image B. This stamp image includes only pixels within the SExtractor aperture. The pixels define the prior shape of the image B that is then convolved with the IRAC point-spread function (PSF) and scaled in flux. The photometry of the other images C, D, and E, and of the multiple images B, C, D, and E taken together, are then recovered by equally applying the IRAC <span class=\"simple-math\">3.6 <i>&#956;</i></span>m&#8211;<i>F814W</i> and IRAC <span class=\"simple-math\">4.5 <i>&#956;</i></span>m&#8211;<i>F814W</i> colors measured in B. This is fully justified, since color is conserved from one counter-image to another, which is a well-established property of gravitational lensing. In the three <i>Herschel</i>/SPIRE FIR images at 250, 350, and 500 <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#956;</i></span>m, the multiple images B, C, D, E, and F are all blended within a single <i>Herschel </i>beam, with the exception of the counter-image A which falls outside the beam<sup><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#FN20\">1</a></sup>. Since MACSJ0032-arc is otherwise unblended with other SPIRE-detected sources (see Fig. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#F1\">1</a>, bottom right panel), simple aperture photometry with the standard SPIRE color and aperture corrections<sup><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#FN21\">2</a></sup> yields a robust FIR flux measurement for the sum of the multiple images B, C, D, E, and F. We are confident that the contribution of the cluster member X to the <i>Herschel </i>flux is negligible. Indeed, at the redshift of the MACS&#8201;J0032.1+1808 cluster, very few cluster galaxies besides the brightest cluster galaxies (BCGs) are likely to be detected in the SPIRE bands (<a name=\"InR67\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#R67\">Rawle et al. 2012</a>) and the galaxy X is not a BCG. Moreover, if the contribution of the galaxy X were significant, then one would expect the combined dust peak to be wider than observed (see Fig. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#F4\">4</a>). To get the observed 250/350 <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#956;</i></span>m color, any cluster galaxy contribution at 250 <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#956;</i></span>m has to be small and thus its contribution to the total FIR flux negligible. Other cluster members are more than 5<span class=\"simple-math\">&#8722;</span>10<span class=\"simple-math\">&#8242;&#8242;</span> away from the MACSJ0032-arc; their contribution, if any, to the <i>Herschel </i>flux would yield some elongation in the SPIRE point source, which is not observed. </p>\n<p>The resulting multiwavelength photometry for the individual counter-images (when available) and the B, C, D, and E images taken together is summarized in Table <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#T1\">1</a>. Because the <i>Herschel</i>/SPIRE photometry for the multiple images B, C, D, and E cannot be deblended (the very faint counter-image F can be neglected), we note that we are forced to work on the total B+C+D+E emission in all available bands, including the CO data, in order to get a coherent global picture. </p>\n<h3 class=\"sec2\">\n<a name=\"S5\"></a>3.2. 30 m telescope data</h3>\n<p>The IRAM 30 m telescope observations of MACSJ0032-arc were conducted on March 28 and 29, 2012, as part of a blind CO line search program in the 3 mm band aimed at identifying the redshifts of bright HLS-snapshot FIR emitters. For this purpose, we used the Eight MIxer Receiver (EMIR) combined with the 32 GHz IF system, which includes 24 fast Fourier Transform Spectrometers (FTS) working at a spectral resolution of 200 kHz. A first redshift solution of <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i><sub>ISM</sub> = 3.626 &#177; 0.008</span> was obtained for MACSJ0032-arc from ISM absorption lines detected in the KeckI/LRIS spectrum (see Sect. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#S2\">2</a>). Therefore, the 32 GHz bandwidth of our EMIR observation was distributed in two 8 GHz wide IF outputs centered on the E090 band (3 mm) and the E150 band (2 mm) each, in dual polarization. The two bands were tuned to the redshifted frequencies of the CO(4<span class=\"simple-math\">&#8722;</span>3) and CO(6&#8211;5) lines at 99.663 GHz and 149.475 GHz, respectively. The corresponding half-power beam widths are <span class=\"simple-math\">24&#8242;&#8242;</span> and <span class=\"simple-math\">16&#8242;&#8242;</span>, respectively. All multiple images B, C, D, E, and F contribute to the observed CO(4<span class=\"simple-math\">&#8722;</span>3) and CO(6&#8211;5) fluxes, with the exception of the counter-image A which falls outside the 30 m beam (see Fig. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#F1\">1</a>). The observations were conducted in wobbler-switching mode with a frequency of 0.5 Hz and a symmetrical azimuthal wobbler throw of <span class=\"simple-math\">50&#8242;&#8242;</span> to maximize the baseline stability. The total on-source integration time was 1.4 h. </p>\n<p>Data reduction was performed with the IRAM <tt>GILDAS </tt>software package CLASS. Since the FTS suffers from severe platforming effects, corrections were applied using a dedicated script provided by the IRAM 30 m observatory. This correction was applied individually to each scan and led to baseline-subtracted spectra. All the scans obtained with the FTS backends tuned on the CO(4&#8211;3) line and those tuned on the CO(6&#8211;5) line were averaged independently, using the temporal scan length as weight. The resulting CO(4&#8211;3) and CO(6&#8211;5) spectra were then Hanning smoothed to a resolution of <span class=\"simple-math\">40.16 km s<sup>-1</sup></span>. They reach an rms noise level of 2.4 mJy in 13.335 MHz channels and 2.2 mJy in 20 MHz channels, respectively, and reveal firm CO(4&#8211;3) and CO(6&#8211;5) emission line detections at <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i><sub>CO</sub> = 3.6314 &#177; 0.0005</span> (see Fig. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#F7\">7</a>). The CO(4&#8211;3) line integrated flux listed in Table <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#T2\">2</a> is derived from a double Gaussian fit applied to the observed CO(4<span class=\"simple-math\">&#8722;</span>3) line profile. </p>\n<h3 class=\"sec2\">\n<a name=\"S6\"></a>3.3. PdBI data</h3>\n<p>The IRAM PdBI observations of MACSJ0032-arc were carried out on November 11 and 16, 2013, in the C-configuration and in the 2 mm band, tuned to the redshifted frequency of the CO(6<span class=\"simple-math\">&#8722;</span>5) transition at 149.300 GHz, as computed from the arc CO redshift <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i><sub>CO</sub> = 3.6314 &#177; 0.0005</span>. We used the WideX correlator that provides a continuous frequency coverage of 3.6 GHz in dual polarization with a fixed channel spacing of 1.95 MHz resolution. A total of 3840 visibilities were obtained during 3.2 hours of on-source integration time. </p>\n<p>Standard data reduction was performed with the IRAM <tt>GILDAS </tt>software packages CLIC and MAPPING, with flux, bandpass, and phase calibration performed using the calibrators most suitable for our target. The data were mapped with the CLEAN procedure using the HOGBOM deconvolution algorithm and combined with &#8220;natural&#8221; weighting, thus giving priority to mapping sensitivity rather than angular resolution. The resulting synthesized beam size is <span class=\"simple-math\">1.94&#8242;&#8242; &#215; 1.62&#8242;&#8242;</span>  (<span class=\"simple-math\">PA =  + 27.3&#176;</span>). We reach an rms noise per beam of 57 <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#956;</i></span>Jy in the continuum after averaging the PdBI data over the full 3.6 GHz spectral range and having excluded the channels where CO emission is detected. The resulting 2 mm continuum is then subtracted from the UV table in order to obtain the UV table for the CO(6&#8211;5) line only. </p>\n<p>\n          <a name=\"T2\"></a><div class=\"inset\"><div class=\"ligne\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/T2.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Table 2</span></a><p>Physical properties of MACSJ0032-arc.</p>\n</div></div>\n        </p>\n<p>To improve the mapping accuracy for the CO(6&#8211;5) line emission, we added the short spacings from the IRAM 30 m single-dish data over the CO(6&#8211;5) detection channel interval using the UVSHORT procedure in MAPPING. This yielded an improvement of approximately 10% and an rms noise per beam of 0.7 mJy when resampling the PdBI+30 m data to a bandwidth of 20 MHz (<span class=\"simple-math\">40.16 km s<sup>-1</sup></span>). Using the GO MOMENT procedure, we determine the CO(6&#8211;5) first moment map (velocity-integrated map) of the cleaned, weighted images over the nine velocity channels where the CO(6&#8211;5) emission is detected. </p>\n<p>The resulting CO(6&#8211;5) velocity-integrated contours overlaid on the HST/ACS <i>F814W </i>image are shown in Fig. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#F2\">2</a>. The CO(6<span class=\"simple-math\">&#8722;</span>5) emission is successfully detected in the four most strongly amplified multiple images of MACSJ0032-arc, namely images B, C, D, and E, with a signal-to-noise ratio (S/N) varying between <span class=\"simple-math\">4<i>&#963;</i></span> and <span class=\"simple-math\">6<i>&#963;</i></span>. Counter-images A and F remain undetected in CO(6&#8211;5) because of their much lower magnification factors (see Sect. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#S10\">4.1</a>). We derive the CO(6&#8211;5) line integrated fluxes of the individual images B, C, D, and E, and of their sum, using custom apertures over the velocity-integrated map, large enough to include, for each counter-image, all the signal above the background. The inferred CO(6&#8211;5) line integrated fluxes are listed in Table <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#T1\">1</a>. </p>\n<p>The 2 mm continuum emission is detected at <span class=\"simple-math\">5.8<i>&#963;</i></span> in the most strongly amplified counter-image C only, as shown in Fig. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#F2\">2</a> where the 2 mm contours are overlaid on the HST/ACS <i>F814W </i>image. The other images B, D, and E remain undetected. Although this is surprising, we note that their fluxes are expected to reach at most the <span class=\"simple-math\">3<i>&#963;</i></span> level when scaling the observed flux in image C by the respective B, D, and E magnification factors (see Fig. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#F6\">6</a>). Emissions at this low confidence level may stochastically happen to be cancelled out, in large part by noise. Therefore, we derive a direct 2 mm continuum flux for the counter-image C, and estimate the total B+C+D+E flux by integrating the 2 mm continuum map over the same apertures as those used for the CO(6&#8211;5) emission detected over all multiple images B, C, D, and E. We find this estimate to be smaller by 38% than the total flux derived when applying the 2 mm&#8211;<i>F814W </i>color conservation over the multiple images of MACSJ0032-arc (see Table <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#T1\">1</a>). We thus set the error on the total 2 mm continuum flux in order to match the two flux estimates within <span class=\"simple-math\">1<i>&#963;</i></span> uncertainty. </p>\n<h3 class=\"sec2\">\n<a name=\"S7\"></a>3.4. JVLA data</h3>\n<p>The NRAO JVLA 5 GHz continuum observations of MACSJ0032-arc were conducted on February 9, 2014, and August 27, 2015, in the most extended A and BnA configurations (program IDs VLA/13B-358 and VLA/15A-215). The half-power beam width is <span class=\"simple-math\">260&#8242;&#8242;</span>, ensuring that all the multiple images are within the central area of the primary beam. We used the WIDAR correlator and the C-band receiver with the 8-bit samplers tuned to <span class=\"simple-math\">4.20 &#8722; 6.20 GHz</span> (<span class=\"simple-math\">1024 &#215; 2 MHz</span> channel, 2.0 GHz total bandwidth) to maximize the bandwidth unaffected by strong radio frequency interferences (RFI) at <span class=\"simple-math\">4.0 &#8722; 4.2 GHz</span>. The total on-source time was 4.5 h. </p>\n<p>The raw data were Hanning smoothed, calibrated by the <tt>CASA </tt>pipeline provided by NRAO with appropriate calibrators used for the flux, bandpass, and phase calibration, and manually flagged to exclude any remaining strong RFI. We imaged the data using the CLEAN procedure opting for the Multi-Scale Multi-Frequency Synthesis algorithm (MS-MFS) deconvolution algorithm (<a name=\"InR66\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#R66\">Rau &amp; Cornwell 2011</a>), the Cottom-Schwab PSF mode, the Briggs weighting with a robust parameter of 0.5, and the tapering of baselines beyond 100 k<span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#955;</i></span> to facilitate the detection of any extended components. The resulting map has a synthesized beam size of <span class=\"simple-math\">0.87&#8242;&#8242; &#215; 0.62&#8242;&#8242;</span> (<span class=\"simple-math\">PA =  + 68.0&#176;</span>) and an rms noise per beam of <span class=\"simple-math\">1.7 <i>&#956;</i></span>Jy. </p>\n<p>The detected 5 GHz continuum contours overlaid on the HST/ACS <i>F814W </i>image are shown in Fig. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#F2\">2</a>. All four individual counter-images B, C, D, and E are detected at <span class=\"simple-math\">3<i>&#963;</i></span> and more. The corresponding 5 GHz fluxes, and that of their sum are listed in Table <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#T1\">1</a>. They were derived using the <tt>PyBDSM </tt>software, performing multi two-dimensional Gaussian fits. </p>\n<p>We observed the CO(1&#8211;0) line emission of MACSJ0032-arc on June 6, 12, 23, and 25, 2015, in the C configuration with a half-power beam width of <span class=\"simple-math\">99&#8242;&#8242;</span> (program ID VLA/13A-385). We used the WIDAR correlator and the K-band receiver with the 8-bit samplers tuned to two frequencies at 24.962 GHz and 24.986 GHz (<span class=\"simple-math\">1024 &#215; 2 MHz</span>  channel, 2.0 GHz total bandwidth; the 24 MHz gap helps mitigate the effect of the lower sensitivity at the 128 MHz bandpass edges) to cover the redshifted frequency of the CO(1&#8211;0) transition at 24.889 GHz. The total on-source time was 9.0 h. </p>\n<p>Except for adopting no Hanning smoothing, the raw data were processed in the same way as the <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>C</i></span>-band data described above. We then used the CLEAN procedure to create an image cube and the IMCONTSUB procedure to subtract continuum emission. The resulting map has a synthesized beam size of <span class=\"simple-math\">0.90&#8242;&#8242; &#215; 0.79&#8242;&#8242;</span> (<span class=\"simple-math\">PA =  &#8722; 53.7&#176;</span>). </p>\n<p>The CO(1&#8211;0) line emission is reliably detected only in the counter-image C in two velocity channels, each <span class=\"simple-math\">144.54 km s<sup>-1</sup></span> wide. By summing over the two velocity channels using the IMMOMENTS procedure, we achieve a <span class=\"simple-math\">4.7<i>&#963;</i></span> CO(1&#8211;0) detection in image C, and <span class=\"simple-math\">2 &#8722; 3<i>&#963;</i></span>  detections in the other images B, D, and E, as shown in Fig. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#F2\">2</a>. The CO(1&#8211;0) line integrated flux of image C, as well as the total B+C+D+E CO(1&#8211;0) line integrated flux obtained by integrating the velocity-integrated map over the same apertures as those used for the CO(6&#8211;5) emission detected over all multiple images B, C, D, and E, can be found in Table <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#T1\">1</a>. The latter perfectly matches the total integrated flux derived by propagating the CO(1&#8211;0)&#8211;<i>F814W </i>color properly measured in image C over the sum of multiple images B, C, D, and E (see Table <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#T1\">1</a>). </p>\n<p>\n          \n          <a name=\"F3\"></a><div class=\"inset\"><table>\n<tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/F3.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16-fig3_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/F3.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig. 3</span></a><p>Observed HST/ACS <i>F814W </i>optical image of the multiple images B, C, D, E, and F of MACSJ0032-arc with the critical line in red (<i>left panel</i>); simulated observation of MACSJ0032-arc resulting from the best lens model when accounting for the PSF of the HST image (<i>middle panel</i>); and source plane reconstruction of MACSJ0032-arc obtained by simulating the morphology of the source as the combination of three elliptical Gaussian light profiles (<i>right panel</i>). The two bright knots, resolved in the HST rest-frame UV images, are separated by <span class=\"simple-math\">1.14 &#177; 0.28 kpc</span> in the source plane. The simulated HST observation includes a constant Gaussian noise background matched to the <i>F814W </i>noise level.</p>\n</td>\n</tr>\n<tr><td colspan=\"2\"><a href=\"http://dexter.edpsciences.org/applet.php?pdf_id=3&amp;DOI=10.1051/0004-6361/201628513\" target=\"DEXTER\">Open with DEXTER</a></td></tr>\n</table></div>\n        </p>\n<h3 class=\"sec2\">\n<a name=\"S8\"></a>3.5. Flux anomalies</h3>\n<p>A critical inspection of the fluxes measured for the individual counter-images B, C, D, and E, found in Table <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#T1\">1</a> shows that the 5 GHz continuum flux of the image E is a factor of 3 higher with respect to the expected flux from the color conservation that is supposed to hold over multiple images of a lensed object. We have carefully verified that image E is not affected by sidelobes from any bright cluster galaxy, and this is not the case. A similar failure in the color conservation is also observed for the CO(6<span class=\"simple-math\">&#8722;</span>5) emission in image E, although this is true to a smaller extent given the lower excess of a factor of 1.6. </p>\n<p>We have no satisfying explanation for what can induce such an excess in both the 5 GHz JVLA and CO(6&#8211;5) PdBI data. We can only speculate on two phenomena. One possible phenomenon, which can possibly break the color conservation in a single counter-image, is the micro-lensing effect, which may very locally increase the flux of a specific region of the source. If this scenario is correct, it suggests that the radio continuum and the high-<span class=\"simple-math\"><i>J</i></span> CO(6&#8211;5) transition have to be emitted from co-located regions of the MACSJ0032-arc galaxy. This is not true for either the CO(1&#8211;0) line emission or the 2 mm dust continuum; if it were true, their respective flux in image E would also be higher and this is not observed (see Table <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#T1\">1</a>). Another phenomenon that may also be considered is the lensing time-delay, where the light travel time or path length for each counter-image differs. If a variable AGN were present, it is possible that image E could be boosted at a given time in comparison to the other images. The continuum may also vary differently to the line emission, such that the resulting color varies in time. Even if the AGN had an optical contribution, the variations at these wavelengths are not expected to be synchronous. However, the absence of Ly<span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#945;</i></span> and any other ISM lines in emission (especially C&#8201;<span class=\"smallcaps\">iv</span>) in the near-UV/optical Keck I/LRIS spectrum (Richard et al., in prep.) argues quite strongly against an AGN in MACSJ0032-arc. </p>\n<p>To overcome the anomalous flux excess in the 5 GHz continuum and the CO(6&#8211;5) line emission in image E, we consider in subsequent analyses the expected total B+C+D+E flux derived by assuming the color conservation and the fluxes measured in counter-images unaffected by the excess (see Table <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#T2\">2</a>). </p>\n<h2 class=\"sec\">\n<a name=\"S9\"></a>4. Analysis and results</h2>\n<h3 class=\"sec2\">\n<a name=\"S10\"></a>4.1. Gravitational lens model</h3>\n<p>We optimize a parametric mass model of the lensing cluster MACS&#8201;J0032.1+1808 based on strong-lensing constraints detected in the HST/ACS optical images. We use the positions of the five brightest multiple images A, B, C, D, and E forming the giant arc, including for each image the centroids of the two knots observed in the HST images (see Fig. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#F1\">1</a>). In addition, two triply imaged systems that we spectroscopically confirmed (Richard et al., in prep.) provide additional constraints on the large-scale mass distribution within the cluster lens. Our mass model considers components on two complementary scales: on large scales, we include two cluster-scale dark-matter haloes, parametrized by double pseudo-isothermal elliptical (dPIE) potentials (e.g., <a name=\"InR51\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#R51\">Limousin et al. 2012</a>); and on galaxy scales, we model each member of the lensing cluster as a smaller-scale dPIE potential following a fixed scaling relation with its luminosity. We use the Lenstool software (<a name=\"InR43\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#R43\">Jullo &amp; Kneib 2009</a>) to optimize the lens parameters with a Bayesian Markov chain Monte Carlo (MCMC) sampler, which provides the best model by minimizing the distance between the predicted and observed locations of the counter-images, as well as a range of models sampling the parameter space of the potentials. Overall our best-fit models reproduce the location of all images with an rms of <span class=\"simple-math\">0.17&#8242;&#8242;</span>. </p>\n<p>Deviating from the modeling prescription applied to all other cluster galaxies, we give special treatment to one bright cluster member, marked X in Fig. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#F2\">2</a>. As its presence splits the giant arc into multiple images C to F, additional constraints ensue that allow us to model galaxy X separately from the scaling relation. Its effect on the shape of the critical line at <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i> &#8771; 3.63</span> is very noticeable in Fig. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#F3\">3</a> (left and middle panels). A counter-image F is predicted and indeed observed next to image D on the other side of the lensing galaxy X. By contrast, a seventh central counter-image is demagnified and, consequently, is not observed in our HST images. The combination of the potentials of the cluster and galaxy X leads to a very high magnification factor. To assess the value of the total magnification for the sum of the multiple images B, C, D, and E, which will be used in the rest of the paper (see Sect. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#S4\">3.1</a>), we need to properly simulate the merging pair of counter-images C and D, which experience the strongest magnification. </p>\n<p>We simulate the morphology of the source as the combination of three elliptical Gaussian light profiles (right panel of Fig. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#F3\">3</a>) and match their flux and shape to the photometry of the observed HST images (Table <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#T1\">1</a>). This was performed by inverting the location of flux peaks in the image plane to the source plane, and producing for each component a grid of elliptical Gaussians with FWHM within 100 pc to 1 kpc in each direction and varying the orientation by steps of 10 degrees. We select for each component the source model that best matches the image plane morphology once lensed and convolved by the HST PSF. The morphology is well constrained along the shear direction, but is an upper limit in the direction perpendicular to it. The simulated observation of MACSJ0032-arc, corrected for the PSF of the HST/ACS <i>F814W </i>image, is shown in the middle panel of Fig. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#F3\">3</a> and globally reproduces the observed locations, shapes, and flux ratios of each counter-image, shown in the left panel of Fig. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#F3\">3</a>. We derive the total magnification of the sum of B, C, D, and E from the ratio between the total flux in the simulated image and the corresponding flux in the model image in the source plane (right panel of Fig. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#F3\">3</a>), and we get a value of <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#956;</i> = 62 &#177; 6</span>, where the quoted uncertainty represents the statistical error from the MCMC models. </p>\n<p>Although the respective sizes of each of the three components in our source plane model are only constrained through upper limits because they are observed as compact sources after magnification, the separation between the two brighter knots is well-constrained. We derive a physical distance of <span class=\"simple-math\">1.14 &#177; 0.28 kpc</span>, taking into account both the statistical error from the MCMC models and systematic uncertainties assessed by comparing the distances for each of the counter-images B, C, D, and E in the source plane. MACSJ0032-arc is thus found to be a compact galaxy in the source plane with a global size <span class=\"simple-math\">&lt;</span><span class=\"simple-math\">2.5 kpc</span>, after adding the three components used in our source model, each of which features a size of <span class=\"simple-math\">&lt;</span><span class=\"simple-math\">500 pc</span>. This is a typical size for SFGs at <span class=\"simple-math\">3 &lt;<i>z</i>&lt; 4</span>, whose stellar effective radii range from 0.4 kpc to 3 kpc with a median at <span class=\"simple-math\">1.3 kpc</span> (<a name=\"InR86\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#R86\">Shibuya et al. 2015</a>). </p>\n<h3 class=\"sec2\">\n<a name=\"S11\"></a>4.2. Stellar and dust content</h3>\n<p>The combination of the available rest-frame UV, optical, and FIR photometry (see Table <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#T1\">1</a>) enables constraints to be obtained on both the stellar and thermal dust spectral energy distributions (SEDs) of MACSJ0032-arc. We only consider the total photometry of the sum of the multiple images B, C, D, and E, as motivated in Sect. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#S4\">3.1</a>. The fits to these SEDs determine the physical parameters of the galaxy, such as the IR luminosity (<span class=\"simple-math\"><i>L</i><sub>IR</sub></span>), the extinction (<span class=\"simple-math\"><i>A</i><sub><i>V</i></sub></span>), SFR, <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>M</i><sub>&#8727;</sub></span>, and the age of the stellar population. We perform the fits by generating 1000 Monte Carlo realizations of the observed photometric data points, which are fit and used to determine the median values and the 68% confidence intervals of the various physical parameters. The latter are then corrected for lensing effects by applying the total B+C+D+E magnification factor (Sect. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#S10\">4.1</a>). </p>\n<p>We first model the dust-processed <i>Herschel </i>FIR SED using different empirical templates and the modified blackbody (MBB) function. The MBB provides the best fit to the FIR SED, with the PdBI 2 mm continuum detection giving a strong constraint on the <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#946;</i></span>-slope, which we fix at 2. The best empirical template reproducing the FIR SED is the one of <a name=\"InR101\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#R101\">Vega et al. (2008)</a>, which, however, fails to reproduce the 2 mm dust continuum emission because the required <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#946;</i></span>-slope is steeper than that of the template. The inferred respective total luminosities, <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>L</i><sub>IR</sub></span>, of the multiple images B, C, D, and E taken together are in very good agreement and only differ by <span class=\"simple-math\">0.01 dex</span>. </p>\n<p>To model the stellar SED from the optical regime covered by the HST filters up to the <i>Spitzer</i>/IRAC IR bands, we use the energy-conserving models presented in <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#R87\">Sklias et al. (2014)</a>. The rationale behind this approach is to decrease the number of free parameters of the usual SED fitting by fixing the attenuation using <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>L</i><sub>IR</sub></span> and assuming that it is due to obscuration of the SED between 0.912 <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#956;</i></span>m and 3 <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#956;</i></span>m. The observed <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>L</i><sub>IR</sub>/<i>L</i><sub>UV</sub></span> ratio is then converted into <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>A</i><sub><i>V</i></sub></span> using the calibration from <a name=\"InR81\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#R81\">Schaerer et al. (2013)</a>. This attenuation is entered into the updated version of the <i>Hyperz </i>photometric redshift code (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#R79\">Schaerer &amp; de Barros 2009</a>, <a name=\"InR80\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#R80\">2010</a>) to generate fits that conserve energy and alleviate the age-extinction degeneracy. Prior to this process, the stellar photometry is corrected for foreground extinction from the Galaxy, taken to be <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>E</i>(<i>B</i> &#8722; <i>V</i>) = 0.11</span> at the position of the galaxy cluster (<a name=\"InR83\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#R83\">Schlafly et al. 2011</a>). When modeling SEDs, we consider star formation histories (SFHs) with both delayed exponential SFR (<span class=\"simple-math\">&#8733;</span><span class=\"simple-math\"><i>t</i>exp( &#8722; <i>t</i>/<i>&#964;</i>)</span>) and constant SFR with a minimum age prior of <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>t</i><sub>min</sub> = 50 Myr</span>. Either approach yields equally good best-fit SEDs with similar <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#967;</i><sup>2</sup></span> values and comparable outputs (<span class=\"simple-math\"><i>M</i><sub>&#8727;</sub></span> and SFR) differing by about 10%. We also explore the subsolar and solar metallicities; we adopt the subsolar metallicity, since it provides the best-fit SED with a <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#967;</i><sup>2</sup></span> of 0.40 against 1.68 for the solar fit. </p>\n<p>The resulting best-fit FIR and stellar SEDs with a constant SFR SFH are shown in Fig. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#F4\">4</a>. The inferred physical parameters for MACSJ0032-arc are summarized in Table <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#T2\">2</a> and reveal a low-mass, luminous infrared galaxy (LIRG) with <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16-eq164.png\"></span>. We discover that <span class=\"simple-math\">~</span><span class=\"simple-math\">90</span>% of the total <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>SFR</i><sub>UV + IR</sub></span> of this high-redshift SFG is undetected at UV wavelengths, but is seen through the thermal FIR dust emission. We find our source to lie within about <span class=\"simple-math\">&#8722; 0.1</span> to <span class=\"simple-math\">+ 0.3 dex</span> of the main sequence at <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i> ~ 4</span>, meaning at most a factor of 2 above the MS depending on the adopted MS parametrization from <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#R96\">Tacconi et al. (2013)</a>, <a name=\"InR90\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#R90\">Speagle et al. (2014)</a>, or <a name=\"InR99\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#R99\">Tomczak et al. (2016)</a>. All these parametrizations still remain uncertain since the star formation main sequence and its scatter at <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i> ~ 4</span> are not well defined yet, especially at low stellar masses comparable to MACSJ0032-arc. </p>\n<p>\n          \n          <a name=\"F4\"></a><div class=\"inset\"><table>\n<tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/F4.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16-fig4_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/F4.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig. 4</span></a><p>Observed SED of MACSJ0032-arc at <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i><sub>CO</sub> = 3.6314</span>. Overlaid are the best-fit stellar SED (solid cyan line) obtained with the energy-conserving model and constant SFR SFH, as well as the best-fit FIR and mm SED obtained with the <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#R101\">Vega et al. (2008)</a> empirical template (solid red line) and the MBB with a <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#946;</i></span>-slope fixed at 2 (dashed black line).</p>\n</td>\n</tr>\n<tr><td colspan=\"2\"><a href=\"http://dexter.edpsciences.org/applet.php?pdf_id=4&amp;DOI=10.1051/0004-6361/201628513\" target=\"DEXTER\">Open with DEXTER</a></td></tr>\n</table></div>\n        </p>\n<p>Finally, the combination of the <i>Herschel </i>FIR photometry and the PdBI 2 mm continuum allows an estimate of the dust mass (<span class=\"simple-math\"><i>M</i><sub>dust</sub></span>) of MACSJ0032-arc to be obtained via the flux&#8211;<span class=\"simple-math\"><i>M</i><sub>dust</sub></span> calibration from <a name=\"InR45\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#R45\">Kruegel (2003)</a><a name=\"FD1\"></a><span class=\"img-equation\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16-eq171.png\"><span class=\"label-eq\">(1)</span></span>where <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>S</i><sub><i>&#957;</i></sub>(<i>&#955;</i><sub>obs</sub>)</span> is the flux at a given observed wavelength, <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>D</i><sub><i>L</i></sub></span> the luminosity distance, <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#954;</i>(<i>&#955;</i><sub>rest</sub>)</span> the dust grain opacity per unit of dust mass, and <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>B</i><sub><i>&#957;</i></sub>(<i>&#955;</i><sub>rest</sub>,<i>T</i><sub>dust</sub>)</span>  the Planck function at a given rest-frame wavelength and dust temperature. For the opacities, <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#954;</i>(<i>&#955;</i><sub>rest</sub>)</span>, we follow the <a name=\"InR50\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#R50\">Li &amp; Draine (2001)</a> calibration. We estimate <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>S</i><sub><i>&#957;</i></sub></span> from the best-fit MBB to the FIR and 2 mm data with the <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#946;</i></span>-slope fixed at 2 (see Fig. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#F4\">4</a>). The resulting values for <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>M</i><sub>dust</sub></span> and <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>T</i><sub>dust</sub></span> are given in Table <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#T2\">2</a>. We propagate the error of the 2 mm continuum flux, carefully set in Sect. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#S6\">3.3</a>, on <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>M</i><sub>dust</sub></span>. </p>\n<h3 class=\"sec2\">\n<a name=\"S12\"></a>4.3. CO spectral line energy distribution</h3>\n<p>At <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i><sub>CO</sub> = 3.6314</span> MACSJ0032-arc currently is the highest redshift typical LIRG with a measured CO(1&#8211;0) luminosity. The CO(1&#8211;0), CO(4&#8211;3), and CO(6&#8211;5) line detections within the arc offer the rare opportunity of characterizing the CO SLED and directly measure the CO luminosity correction factors, <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16-eq176.png\"></span>, for these high-<span class=\"simple-math\"><i>J</i></span> CO transitions in a normal SFG at such a high redshift. This is of particular importance since the estimate of the molecular gas mass is based on the luminosity of the fundamental CO(1&#8211;0) line, which is rarely accessible at high redshift. In its absence, luminosity corrections have to be applied to the more readily observable rotationally excited lines. </p>\n<p>In Fig. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#F5\">5</a> we show the CO SLED of MACSJ0032-arc that we have corrected for the cosmic microwave background (CMB) radiation, which is becoming non-negligible at <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i> ~ 3.6</span>, the redshift of the arc, with a temperature of <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>T</i><sub>CMB</sub> = 12.6 K</span>. <a name=\"InR17\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#R17\">da Cunha et al. (2013)</a> computed the ratios between the line fluxes observed against the CMB and the intrinsic line fluxes for different CO transitions and redshifts in the local thermal equilibrium (LTE) case and in the non-LTE case. For the kinetic temperature of the gas in MACSJ0032-arc of <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>T</i><sub>kin</sub> ~ <i>T</i><sub>dust</sub> = 43 &#177; 5 K</span> and the LTE case, the corresponding ratios are approximately 0.75 for CO(1&#8211;0), 0.85 for CO(4&#8211;3), and 0.9 for CO(6&#8211;5). Moreover, the total CO(6&#8211;5) line integrated flux (Table <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#T1\">1</a>) was first corrected for the flux excess observed in the counter-image E<sup><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#FN22\">3</a></sup>. This yields the CO(1&#8211;0), CO(4&#8211;3), and CO(6&#8211;5) luminosities corrected against CMB listed in Table <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#T2\">2</a>. </p>\n<p>\n          \n          <a name=\"F5\"></a><div class=\"inset\"><table>\n<tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/F5.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16-fig5_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/F5.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig. 5</span></a><p>CMB corrected CO SLED of MACSJ0032-arc at <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i><sub>CO</sub> = 3.6314</span> (red stars) compared to the average CO SLEDs of the Milky Way (black crosses), the local (U)LIRGs (green circles), the <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i> ~ 1 &#8722; 4</span> SMGs (blue squares), and the <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i> ~ 1.5</span> BzK galaxies (magenta triangles). All SLEDs are normalized to the CO(1&#8211;0) flux of the average SLED for BzK galaxies, except the Milky Way normalized using CO(2&#8211;1).</p>\n</td>\n</tr>\n<tr><td colspan=\"2\"><a href=\"http://dexter.edpsciences.org/applet.php?pdf_id=5&amp;DOI=10.1051/0004-6361/201628513\" target=\"DEXTER\">Open with DEXTER</a></td></tr>\n</table></div>\n        </p>\n<p>The resulting CO SLED of MACSJ0032-arc is then compared to the average CO SLED of <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i> ~ 1.5</span> BzK galaxies from <a name=\"InR20\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#R20\">Daddi et al. (2015)</a>, <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i> ~ 1 &#8722; 4</span> submm galaxies (SMGs) from <a name=\"InR9\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#R9\">Bothwell et al. (2013)</a>, local (ultra-)LIRGs from <a name=\"InR63\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#R63\">Papadopoulos et al. (2012)</a>, and the Milky Way inner disk from <a name=\"InR30\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#R30\">Fixsen et al. (1999)</a>. We find a clear CO SLED enhancement of MACSJ0032-arc over the Milky Way CO SLED and, more specifically, this galaxy demonstrates that high-<span class=\"simple-math\"><i>J</i></span> transitions up to CO(6&#8211;5) may remain excited at least in some high-redshift normal SFGs. In fact, the CO SLED of this <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i> ~ 3.6</span> galaxy appears to be similar to the SLED of high-redshift SMGs, with a turnover at <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>J</i>&gt; 4</span>, even though its IR luminosity, <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16-eq181.png\"></span>, is 10 times lower than typically observed in SMGs. Although at first glance this seems unexpected, it is still in line with the CO SLED predictions for high-redshift SFGs from theoretical modeling. Indeed, the <a name=\"InR8\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#R8\">Bournaud et al. (2015)</a> simulations predict a turnover at only <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>J</i> = 5</span> for both disk and merger galaxies, and <a name=\"InR61\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#R61\">Narayanan &amp; Krumholz (2014)</a> find that the overall CO excitation is regulated by the SFR surface density, which also implies a turnover at <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>J</i> = 5</span> for MACSJ0032-arc. In addition, <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#R63\">Papadopoulos et al. (2012)</a> propose a toy model with no turnover at <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>J</i>&lt; 6</span>. </p>\n<p>As a result, the CO(6&#8211;5) line detection in MACSJ0032-arc enables us to place a constraint on the CO SLED of high-redshift SFGs at a very high <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>J</i></span> rotational level. We derive the following CO luminosity correction factors: <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16-eq184.png\"></span> and <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16-eq185.png\"></span><sup><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#FN23\">4</a></sup> (Table <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#T2\">2</a>). These factors are comparable to those of high-redshift SMGs with <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>r</i><sub>4,1</sub> = 0.41 &#8722; 0.60</span> and <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>r</i><sub>6,5</sub> = 0.21 &#8722; 0.46</span>  (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#R9\">Bothwell et al. 2013</a>; <a name=\"InR91\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#R91\">Spilker et al. 2014</a>). They are slightly higher than those of BzK galaxies at <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i> ~ 1.5</span>, with average <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>r</i><sub>3,1</sub> = 0.42 &#177; 0.07</span> and <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>r</i><sub>5,1</sub> = 0.23 &#177; 0.04</span> (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#R20\">Daddi et al. 2015</a>), but formally still within the uncertainties. The trend for a somewhat more excited CO SLED in SFGs at higher redshift needs to be further confirmed. </p>\n<p>\n          \n          <a name=\"F6\"></a><div class=\"inset\"><table>\n<tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/F6.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16-fig6_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/F6.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig. 6</span></a><p>Comparison of the observed JVLA CO(1&#8211;0) line emission, PdBI CO(6&#8211;5) line emission, JVLA 5 GHz continuum, and PdBI 2 mm continuum contours, overlaid on the HST/ACS <i>F814W </i>multiple images B, C, D, and E of MACSJ0032-arc (<i>left panels</i>), with the respective simulated beam-convolved emission maps in the image plane (yellow contours in the <i>middle and right panels</i>) obtained for two different combinations of elliptical Gaussian light profiles in the source plane: one extended Gaussian component placed between the two HST UV-bright knots (yellow contours in the <i>top middle panel</i>) and two Gaussian components with locations and shapes following the two UV-bright knots (yellow contours in the <i>top right panel</i>). Noise realizations based on the data are added to the simulated maps, and the absolute flux scaling is obtained by matching the observed flux at the peak of the emission in the counter-image C in each of the CO(1&#8211;0), CO(6&#8211;5), 5 GHz, and 2 mm simulated maps. The critical line is in red. The size and orientation of the beams are indicated by the dashed green ellipses. Contour levels start at <span class=\"simple-math\">2<i>&#963;</i></span> and are spaced in steps of <span class=\"simple-math\">1<i>&#963;</i></span> (as in Fig. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#F2\">2</a>).</p>\n</td>\n</tr>\n<tr><td colspan=\"2\"><a href=\"http://dexter.edpsciences.org/applet.php?pdf_id=6&amp;DOI=10.1051/0004-6361/201628513\" target=\"DEXTER\">Open with DEXTER</a></td></tr>\n</table></div>\n        </p>\n<h3 class=\"sec2\">\n<a name=\"S13\"></a>4.4. CO spatial distribution and kinematics</h3>\n<p>The CO(6&#8211;5) emission is successfully detected in the four most strongly amplified multiple images (B, C, D, and E) of MACSJ0032-arc (see Sect. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#S6\">3.3</a>). As shown in Fig. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#F2\">2</a>, where we overlay the velocity-integrated CO(6&#8211;5) contours on the HST/ACS <i>F814W </i>image, each individual counter-image is well resolved in CO(6&#8211;5), with the exception of some faint emission bridging the images C and D. However, the two knots that, at a separation of <span class=\"simple-math\">~</span><span class=\"simple-math\">0.8&#8242;&#8242;</span> (<span class=\"simple-math\">1.14 &#177; 0.28 kpc</span> in the reconstructed source plane; see Sect. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#S10\">4.1</a>), are clearly resolved in the HST rest-frame UV data within each counter-image remain blended in the PdBI <span class=\"simple-math\">1.94&#8242;&#8242; &#215; 1.62&#8242;&#8242;</span> beam. They should be resolved in the JVLA CO(1&#8211;0) observations obtained with a beam size of <span class=\"simple-math\">0.90&#8242;&#8242; &#215; 0.79&#8242;&#8242;</span>. However, a closer look at Fig. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#F2\">2</a>, which also shows the velocity-integrated CO(1&#8211;0) contours overlaid on the HST/ACS <i>F814W </i>image, reveals that the peak of the CO(1&#8211;0) emission in the counter-image C falls between the two HST UV-bright knots. The JVLA radio continuum emission at 5 GHz, acquired at an even better angular resolution with a beam size of <span class=\"simple-math\">0.87&#8242;&#8242; &#215; 0.62&#8242;&#8242;</span>, also shown in Fig. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#F2\">2</a>, exhibits a very similar spatial distribution pattern to that suggested by the CO(1&#8211;0) emission: detected in images B, C, D, and E (see Sect. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#S7\">3.4</a>), it peaks between the two UV-bright knots, even in the most strongly amplified and stretched image C where it breaks into two centroids not co-spatial with the UV knots. Indeed, the observed centroid displacements between the UV and 5 GHz emissions is of <span class=\"simple-math\">~</span><span class=\"simple-math\">0.25&#8242;&#8242;</span> in image C, which cannot be accounted for either by the JVLA positional accuracy<sup><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#FN24\">5</a></sup> of <span class=\"simple-math\">~</span>35 mas at <span class=\"simple-math\">5<i>&#963;</i></span> or by the absolute HST positional error of <span class=\"simple-math\">~</span>45 mas (Sect. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#S4\">3.1</a>). </p>\n<p>To ascertain the spatial origin of the CO(1&#8211;0) and CO(6<span class=\"simple-math\">&#8722;</span>5) line emissions together with the 5 GHz and 2 mm continuum emissions with respect to the two UV-bright knots, we have searched for the best combination of elliptical Gaussian light profiles in the source plane that can reproduce all these emissions in the image plane. We are aware that forcing all the emissions to arise from exactly the same location in the source model is a strong assumption. Indeed, it is well known that the different CO lines of the rotational ladder require different physical conditions to be excited: higher density and temperature at higher <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>J</i></span>. It is therefore expected that the CO(6&#8211;5) and CO(1&#8211;0) emissions are not exactly co-spatial, as is frequently observed in the nearby galaxies such as M&#8201;82 (<a name=\"InR102\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#R102\">Ward et al. 2003</a>) or NGC&#8201;253 (<a name=\"InR44\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#R44\">Krips et al. 2016</a>). Also, the continuum requires the heating of the dust, and does not have the same excitation requirements as the lines, thus is likely not to be exactly co-spatial. However, modeling this complex origin of CO and continuum emissions is not possible, first because of the limited angular resolution and quality of the available CO(6&#8211;5) and 2 mm data, and second because one would quickly be hitting degeneracies in the model parameters. </p>\n<p>The free parameters used in our source plane simulations are the number of Gaussian light profiles, their locations, shapes, and relative fluxes. To provide more realistic simulations of our observations, we have also constructed noise realizations based on the data, where all pixel values above <span class=\"simple-math\">2.5<i>&#963;</i></span> were set to zero. We randomly attributed pixel values from these noise maps, convolved them with the corresponding beam, and scaled them to the same noise level as in the observations. We then follow the same procedure as in Sect. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#S10\">4.1</a> to model the source HST rest-frame UV emission using a grid of elliptical Gaussians. We first considered a grid of three Gaussians similar to the source plane reconstruction of the HST rest-frame UV emission, then a grid of two Gaussians coincident with the two HST UV-bright knots, and finally a grid of one single Gaussian. A global flux normalization of the simulated images was, in all explored combinations, adjusted to match the observed flux at the peak of the emission in the most strongly amplified counter-image C in each of the CO(1&#8211;0), CO(6&#8211;5), 5 GHz, and 2 mm maps once convolved by their respective beams. </p>\n<p>In Fig. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#F6\">6</a> we show the combination of one and two elliptical Gaussian light profiles in the source plane that best reproduces the observed CO/radio/mm emissions:</p>\n<p>\n          <ul style=\"list-style-type: none;\">\n            <li>\n              (i) \n              <p class=\"ligne\"><i>One extended Gaussian placed between the two HST </i><i>UV-bright</i><i> knots (middle panels of Fig. </i><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#F6\"><i>6</i></a><i>)</i>: a compact elliptical Gaussian (PSF-dominated) fails to give the correct shape and orientation of the CO(1&#8211;0), CO(6&#8211;5), 5 GHz, and 2 mm emissions in the image plane, while an extended Gaussian component positioned between the two HST UV-bright knots in the source plane yields the best agreement between the simulated beam-convolved and observed maps in the image plane both in terms of spatial distribution (shape and orientation) and respective detection levels from one counter-image to the other. </p>\n            </li>\n            <li>\n              (ii) \n              <p class=\"ligne\"><i>Two Gaussians with locations and shapes following the two HST UV-bright knots (right panels of Fig. </i><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#F6\"><i>6</i></a><i>)</i>: the corresponding simulated contours of the unresolved CO(6&#8211;5) and 2 mm emissions show one single blended emission in the image plane located between the two UV-bright knots, as is seen in the observations. However, the simulated contours of the 5 GHz continuum and the CO(1&#8211;0) emission in the most strongly amplified image C are resolved and show two distinct emission peaks in the image plane that fail to reproduce the observations. Bridging the two emission peaks is possible by extending the size of each Gaussian in the direction of the other UV-bright knot in the source plane, but then the simulated contours in the image plane become too extended. </p>\n            </li>\n          </ul>\n        </p>\n<p>In conclusion, the best simulated CO, 5 GHz, and 2 mm emissions are obtained with one extended Gaussian light profile placed between the HST UV-knots in the source plane, although some imperfections remain (see Fig. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#F6\">6</a>) such as the slight offset in the predicted locations, seen in particular in image B, which is due to the overall rms of the lens model (<span class=\"simple-math\">0.17&#8242;&#8242;</span>, see Sect. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#S10\">4.1</a>), the overestimated 2 mm continuum emission in images B and E that can result from our too optimistic noise realization (see also Sect. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#S6\">3.3</a>), and the poor prediction of the CO(6&#8211;5) emission in image E. For this source plane reconstruction, we estimate a total magnification factor of <span class=\"simple-math\">~</span>65 for the sum of the CO, 5 GHz, and 2 mm emissions over the multiple images B, C, D, and E. Having derived a very similar magnification factor of <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#956;</i> = 62 &#177; 6</span> for the total rest-frame UV emission of images B, C, D, and E (see Sect. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#S10\">4.1</a>), this indicates that differential magnification between the UV and CO/radio/mm emissions in MACSJ0032-arc is insignificant at the precision of our current measurements. </p>\n<p>\n          \n          <a name=\"F7\"></a><div class=\"inset\"><table>\n<tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/F7.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16-fig7_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/F7.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig. 7</span></a><p>Spectra of the CO(6&#8211;5), CO(4&#8211;3), and CO(1&#8211;0) emission lines detected in MACSJ0032-arc binned in steps of <span class=\"simple-math\">40.16 km s<sup>-1</sup></span>, expect for the CO(1&#8211;0) line where channels have a resolution of <span class=\"simple-math\">144.54 km s<sup>-1</sup></span>. The cyan-shaded regions indicate channels where positive emission is detected. These channels are used to derive the CO line integrated fluxes and the velocity-integrated and velocity-averaged maps shown in Figs. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#F2\">2</a> and <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#F8\">8</a>, respectively. The solid red lines show the single or double Gaussian profiles that best fit the observed CO line profiles. The zero velocity is set to <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i><sub>CO</sub> = 3.6314</span>.</p>\n</td>\n</tr>\n<tr><td colspan=\"2\"><a href=\"http://dexter.edpsciences.org/applet.php?pdf_id=7&amp;DOI=10.1051/0004-6361/201628513\" target=\"DEXTER\">Open with DEXTER</a></td></tr>\n</table></div>\n        </p>\n<p>Searching for kinematic signatures, we observe that the CO(6&#8211;5) line, extracted over all four multiple images B, C, D, and E, shows an asymmetric double-peaked emission line profile, which is similar to the CO(4&#8211;3) line, as shown in Fig. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#F7\">7</a>. Adopting a double Gaussian model for the description of the observed CO(6&#8211;5) and CO(4&#8211;3) line profiles leads to a best-fit solution that has the two velocity components separated by <span class=\"simple-math\">185 &#177; 15 km s<sup>-1</sup></span>, based on the nonlinear <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#967;</i><sup>2</sup></span> minimization and the Levenberg-Marquardt algorithm. In Fig. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#F8\">8</a> we plot, separately for the counter-images B, C+D, and E, the CO(6<span class=\"simple-math\">&#8722;</span>5) contours integrated over, respectively, the velocity channels that define the red component and the blue component of the double-peaked CO(6<span class=\"simple-math\">&#8722;</span>5) emission line profile. We find a clear spatial offset between the contours of the two velocity components in the counter-image C+D, while in images B and E only hints of some offset are observed. However, in all multiple images the red and blue contours follow the same inversions from one counter-image to the other as observed in the HST images and as expected from the lens model (see Figs. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#F1\">1</a> and <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#F3\">3</a>). Overall, this is suggestive of a possible signature of rotation. </p>\n<p>The CO(1&#8211;0) line shows a single velocity component that is centered at the velocity of the strong red component of the CO(6&#8211;5) and CO(4&#8211;3) lines (see Fig. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#F7\">7</a>). The non-detection of the blue, <span class=\"simple-math\">4  &#215;</span> fainter (in integrated flux) CO(1&#8211;0) component is easily explained by both the low S/N of the CO(1&#8211;0) detection and the low spectral resolution of the CO(1&#8211;0) line of <span class=\"simple-math\">144.54 km s<sup>-1</sup></span>, which implies that the blue component with <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>FWHM</i> = 83 &#177; 8</span> km s<span class=\"simple-math\"><sup>-1</sup></span>, as derived by the Gaussian best-fitting solution of the CO(6&#8211;5) and CO(4&#8211;3) line profiles, is detected over one single velocity channel. </p>\n<p>\n          \n          <a name=\"F8\"></a><div class=\"inset\"><table>\n<tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/F8.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16-fig8_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/F8.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig. 8</span></a><p>Velocity-averaged maps of the CO(6&#8211;5) emission of the counter-images E (<i>left panel</i>), C+D (<i>middle panel</i>), and B (<i>right panel</i>) of MACSJ0032-arc. Overlaid are the CO(6&#8211;5) contours integrated over, respectively, the channels that define the blue component (blue contours) and the red component (red contours) of the double-peaked CO(6&#8211;5) line profile shown in Fig. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#F7\">7</a>. The color-coding is in units of integrated flux <span class=\"simple-math\">Jy km s<sup>-1</sup></span> and starts at <span class=\"simple-math\">2<i>&#963;</i></span>. Contour levels also start at <span class=\"simple-math\">2<i>&#963;</i></span> and are spaced in steps of <span class=\"simple-math\">1<i>&#963;</i></span>. A clear spatial offset between the blue and red contours is observed.
