The corresponding PdBI beam size of <span class=\"simple-math\">1.94&#8242;&#8242; &#215; 1.62&#8242;&#8242;</span> is about the size of the individual counter-images themselves.</p>\n</td>\n</tr>\n<tr><td colspan=\"2\"><a href=\"http://dexter.edpsciences.org/applet.php?pdf_id=8&amp;DOI=10.1051/0004-6361/201628513\" target=\"DEXTER\">Open with DEXTER</a></td></tr>\n</table></div>\n        </p>\n<p>We conclude that the bulk of the molecular gas reservoir and cold dust seems, at the resolution of our data, to peak between the two UV-bright knots, while cold gas and dust still extend over the whole galaxy (see the top middle panel of Fig. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#F6\">6</a>). The fact that the radio continuum, which mostly traces the unobscured star formation through the synchrotron radiation from supernovae remnants, seems to arise from the same location indicates that most of the star formation is also taking place between the two UV-bright knots, a region which is dark at the HST rest-frame UV wavelength<sup><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#FN25\">6</a></sup> because it is too dusty. This is the location where <span class=\"simple-math\">~</span>90% of the star formation of MACSJ0032-arc occurs since <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>SFR</i><sub>UV</sub></span> represents only 10% of the total <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>SFR</i><sub>UV + IR</sub></span> of the galaxy (Sect. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#S11\">4.2</a>). This agrees with the lensing-corrected <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>SFR</i><sub>radio</sub>/<i>&#956;</i> = 58 &#177; 11 <i>M</i><sub>&#8857;</sub> yr<sup>-1</sup></span> (see Table <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#T2\">2</a>), as determined from the radio 5 GHz continuum flux and the SFR&#8211;1.4 GHz calibration from <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#R4\">Bell</a> (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#R4\">2003</a>; see also <a name=\"InR71\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#R71\">Rieke et al. 2009</a>). The 5 GHz flux was first corrected for the flux excess observed in the counter-image E (see Sect. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#S7\">3.4</a>) by propagating the 5 GHz&#8211;<i>F814W </i>color properly measured in images B, C, and D over the counter-image E. The spatial offset between UV clumps and the bulk of star formation has been found in many <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i> ~ 2</span> SFGs, with only 5&#8211;10% of the star formation emerging in the rest-frame UV (<a name=\"InR75\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#R75\">Rujopakarn et al. 2016</a>; <a name=\"InR26\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#R26\">Dunlop et al. 2017</a>). </p>\n<h3 class=\"sec2\">\n<a name=\"S14\"></a>4.5. Morphology: single galaxy versus merger</h3>\n<p>Gathering all information available on MACSJ0032-arc, we now attempt to arrive at a self-consistent interpretation of its observed morphological properties summarized in the following. The arc is shown to be a fairly low-mass, normal SFG with a physical size of <span class=\"simple-math\">~</span>2.5 kpc or smaller, comparable to the MS galaxy population at <span class=\"simple-math\">3 &lt;<i>z</i>&lt; 4</span>. It is composed of two very compact rest-frame UV-bright knots with sizes <span class=\"simple-math\">&lt;</span><span class=\"simple-math\">500 pc</span> and separated by <span class=\"simple-math\">1.14 &#177; 0.28</span> kpc in the source plane (Sect. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#S10\">4.1</a>). The bulk of the molecular gas, dust content, and star formation, found to be dust obscured, is spatially offset from the rest-frame UV emission and is located between these two UV-emission regions (Sect. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#S13\">4.4</a>). Neither the CO(1&#8211;0) emission nor the radio continuum at 5 GHz is fully resolved in the JVLA observations and may hence originate from a region with a physical size as large as the separation between the UV-bright knots or smaller (<span class=\"simple-math\">&#8818;</span><span class=\"simple-math\">1.14 kpc</span>). Our gravitational lens model suggests an extended rather than a compact CO, dust, and radio emission (Fig. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#F6\">6</a>). </p>\n<p>Two scenarios may explain these observational facts. First, the two UV-bright knots may be two separate entities in the process of merging, creating a compression zone in their middle where most of the molecular gas mass is found, and triggering new, still dust obscured, star-bursting regions, similar to what is observed in some local galaxies (e.g., the Antennae, <a name=\"InR105\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#R105\">Whitmore et al. 1999</a>; and NGC&#8201;6240, <a name=\"InR70\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#R70\">Rieke et al. 1985</a>). This scenario would most easily explain the more diffuse tail seen extending from one of the UV-bright knots. On the other hand, the two very small knots with sub-kpc sizes may be two star-forming regions, or clumps, within a single gravitationally bound galaxy, whose molecular gas and star formation resides and occurs primarily in its center, similarly to the numerous high-redshift clumpy galaxies observed in HST images (e.g., <a name=\"InR28\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#R28\">Elmegreen et al. 2005</a>; <a name=\"InR38\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#R38\">Guo et al. 2015</a>). This scenario is supported by the arc&#8217;s main sequence and LIRG nature, and could explain both the observed double-peaked CO(4&#8211;3) and CO(6&#8211;5) emission line profiles (Fig. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#F7\">7</a>) and the spatial offset between the red and blue velocity components in the CO(6&#8211;5) velocity-averaged map (Fig. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#F8\">8</a>) as signatures of rotation. The measured velocity separation of <span class=\"simple-math\">185 km s<sup>-1</sup></span> between the red and the blue velocity components is also compatible with this scenario. </p>\n<p>Given the observed excited state of the CO molecular gas in MACSJ0032-arc, comparable to that of high-redshift SMGs (Sect. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#S12\">4.3</a> and Fig. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#F5\">5</a>), we might be tempted to favor the merging scenario. However, this high excitation is more fundamentally related to the compactness of the object, irrespective of its origin (merger or not). Indeed, a compact object will, on average, have a higher molecular gas density that will lead to more excitation of CO by collisions with H<span class=\"simple-math\"><sub>2</sub></span>  (see <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#R89\">Solomon et al. 1997</a>; <a name=\"InR103\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#R103\">Weiss et al. 2005</a>, <a name=\"InR104\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#R104\">2007</a>). This compactness could reflect the general fact that galaxies are more compact at higher redshifts (<span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i> &#8819; 3.5</span>) because of their smaller sizes (e.g., <a name=\"InR10\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#R10\">Buitrago et al. 2008</a>; <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#R86\">Shibuya et al. 2015</a>). Therefore, we interpret this system as a single galaxy with two UV-bright star-forming regions, but this configuration may still be the result of a recent merger or accretion event, albeit not one big enough to completely disrupt the kinematic state of the galaxy. </p>\n<h2 class=\"sec\">\n<a name=\"S15\"></a>5. Discussion</h2>\n<p>In this section, we make use of the wealth of data we have on MACSJ0032-arc to explore the CO-to-H<span class=\"simple-math\"><sub>2</sub></span> conversion factor in this galaxy. We then add our new CO(1&#8211;0) measure to the small sample of five prior CO detections in SFGs at <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i>&gt; 2.5</span> (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#R69\">Riechers et al. 2010</a>; <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#R42\">Johansson et al. 2012</a>; <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#R97\">Tan et al. 2013</a>; <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#R77\">Saintonge et al. 2013</a>)<sup><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#FN26\">7</a></sup> to study the cosmic evolution of the molecular gas depletion timescale and that of the molecular gas fraction. To place our object in the general context, we consider the compilation by <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#R24\">Dessauges-Zavadsky et al. (2015, and references therein)</a> of local spirals and main sequence SFGs at both <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i>&lt; 0.4</span> and <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i>&gt; 1</span> with CO measurements from the literature. </p>\n<h3 class=\"sec2\">\n<a name=\"S16\"></a>5.1. CO-to-H<span class=\"simple-math\"><sub>2</sub></span> conversion factor</h3>\n<p>A major difficulty in measuring the molecular gas mass (<span class=\"simple-math\"><i>M</i><sub>molgas</sub></span>) of individual galaxies is to determine the CO-to-H<span class=\"simple-math\"><sub>2</sub></span> conversion factor (<span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#945;</i><sub>CO</sub></span>) that relates <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>M</i><sub>molgas</sub></span> to the CO(1&#8211;0) luminosity as <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16-eq207.png\"></span>, shown to vary with physical conditions (metallicity, temperature, density, dynamical state of the galaxy, etc.). There is a growing consensus that <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#945;</i><sub>CO</sub></span> and metallicity are inversely correlated for galaxies with metallicities from <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>Z</i> ~ 0.2 <i>Z</i><sub>&#8857;</sub></span> to <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>Z</i> ~ 2 <i>Z</i><sub>&#8857;</sub></span>, because of the increasing fraction of CO that is photo-dissociated at low metallicity due to the underabundance of dust that yields more intense radiation fields, resulting in molecular gas that is deficient (dark) in CO (<a name=\"InR57\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#R57\">Maloney &amp; Black 1988</a>; <a name=\"InR106\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#R106\">Wilson et al. 1995</a>; <a name=\"InR41\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#R41\">Israel et al. 2000</a>; <a name=\"InR107\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#R107\">Wolfire et al. 2010</a>; <a name=\"InR49\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#R49\">Leroy et al. 2011</a>; <a name=\"InR6\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#R6\">Bolatto et al. 2013</a>; <a name=\"InR92\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#R92\">Sternberg et al. 2014</a>). </p>\n<p>Following <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#R37\">Genzel et al. (2015, see their Eqs. (7),&#8201;(8),&#8201;(12a) and their respective justifications)</a>, we consider in what follows the metallicity-dependent CO-to-H<span class=\"simple-math\"><sub>2</sub></span> conversion function and the mass-metallicity relation calibrated to the <a name=\"InR65\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#R65\">Pettini &amp; Pagel (2004, PP04)</a> metallicity scale given by <a name=\"FD2\"></a><span class=\"img-equation\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16-eq210.png\"><span class=\"label-eq\">(2)</span></span>with <a name=\"FD3\"></a><span class=\"img-equation\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16-eq211.png\"><span class=\"label-eq\">(3)</span></span>and <a name=\"FD4\"></a><span class=\"img-equation\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16-eq212.png\"><span class=\"label-eq\">(4)</span></span>where <a name=\"\"></a><span class=\"img-equation\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16-eq213.png\"></span>We assume the Milky Way CO-to-H<span class=\"simple-math\"><sub>2</sub></span> conversion factor to be <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#945;</i><sub>CO,MW</sub> = 4.36 <i>M</i><sub>&#8857;</sub>/ (K km s<sup>-1</sup> pc<sup>2</sup>)</span><sup><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#FN27\">8</a></sup>, which includes a correction factor of 1.36 for helium (<a name=\"InR93\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#R93\">Strong &amp; Mattox 1996</a>), and the solar abundance of <span class=\"simple-math\">12 + log&#8201;(O / H)<sub>&#8857;</sub> = 8.67</span> from <a name=\"InR2\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#R2\">Asplund et al. (2004)</a>. The resulting metallicity-dependent CO-to-H<span class=\"simple-math\"><sub>2</sub></span> conversion function is essentially a function of two physical parameters, <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>M</i><sub>&#8727;</sub></span> and redshift, as illustrated in Fig. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#F9\">9</a> by the iso-redshift curves. The uncertainties typically are <span class=\"simple-math\">&#177; 0.25</span> dex on the inferred <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16-eq217.png\"></span>, which is basically the scatter of the mass-metallicity relation, and <span class=\"simple-math\">&#177; 0.15</span> dex on the stellar masses. The value of <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16-eq219.png\"></span> increases with redshift for any given <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>M</i><sub>&#8727;</sub></span>, and at any given redshift increases with decreasing <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>M</i><sub>&#8727;</sub></span>. Adopting these prescriptions, we find most of the CO-detected MS SFGs from our literature compilation (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#R24\">Dessauges-Zavadsky et al. 2015</a>) to feature <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16-eq217.png\"></span> values comparable to <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#945;</i><sub>CO,MW</sub></span>, with <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16-eq221.png\"></span>, owing to their high stellar masses (small circles in Fig. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#F9\">9</a>). </p>\n<p>\n          \n          <a name=\"F9\"></a><div class=\"inset\"><table>\n<tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/F9.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16-fig9_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/F9.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig. 9</span></a><p>Dependence of the metallicity-dependent CO-to-H<span class=\"simple-math\"><sub>2</sub></span> conversion function, computed from Eqs. (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#FD2\">2</a>)&#8211;(<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#FD4\">4</a>), on stellar mass and redshift. The lines are the iso-redshift curves, color-coded as a function of redshift, for <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i> = 0.5</span> to <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i> = 3.5</span> in steps of <span class=\"simple-math\">&#916;<i>z</i> = 0.5</span>: the solid sections correspond to <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16-eq225.png\"></span>, the dashed segments to <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16-eq226.png\"></span>, and the dotted portions to <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16-eq227.png\"></span>. The horizontal black line marks the Milky Way CO-to-H<span class=\"simple-math\"><sub>2</sub></span> conversion factor. Small symbols represent the computed <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16-eq217.png\"></span> values for MACSJ0032-arc (red star) as well as the compilation of MS SFGs with CO measurements from the literature (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#R24\">Dessauges-Zavadsky et al. 2015</a>). Large symbols correspond to the few MS SFGs for which gas-phase metallicities have been measured from rest-frame optical nebular lines. The symbols are color-coded according to galaxy redshift and their shapes indicate <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16-eq228.png\"></span> ratios (<span class=\"simple-math\">&lt;</span>1.5: circles, 1.5<span class=\"simple-math\">&#8722;</span>2: triangles, and <span class=\"simple-math\">&gt;</span>2: squares and star).</p>\n</td>\n</tr>\n<tr><td colspan=\"2\"><a href=\"http://dexter.edpsciences.org/applet.php?pdf_id=9&amp;DOI=10.1051/0004-6361/201628513\" target=\"DEXTER\">Open with DEXTER</a></td></tr>\n</table></div>\n        </p>\n<p>Using the derived <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>M</i><sub>&#8727;</sub></span> (Table <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#T2\">2</a>), <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i><sub>CO</sub> = 3.6314</span>, and <span class=\"simple-math\">12 + log&#8201;(O / H)<sub>PP04</sub> = 8.0 &#177; 0.2</span>  (<span class=\"simple-math\"><i>Z</i> = 0.21 <i>Z</i><sub>&#8857;</sub></span>) estimated from Eq. (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#FD4\">4</a>), we obtain a high value of <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16-eq232.png\"></span>  for MACSJ0032-arc, as expected for a high-redshift galaxy with a low stellar mass (star in Fig. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#F9\">9</a>). Such a high <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16-eq217.png\"></span> value translates into a very important gas mass of <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>M</i><sub>molgas</sub>/<i>&#956;</i> = (7.6 &#177; 3.0) &#215; 10<sup>10</sup><i>M</i><sub>&#8857;</sub></span> (lensing-corrected). Since most of this molecular gas is concentrated within a <span class=\"simple-math\">1 &#8722; 2 kpc</span> region (see Sect. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#S13\">4.4</a>), this also implies a very high H<span class=\"simple-math\"><sub>2</sub></span> surface density of <span class=\"simple-math\">&#931;<sub>H<sub>2</sub></sub>/<i>&#956;</i> &#8819; 2.4 &#215; 10<sup>4</sup><i>M</i><sub>&#8857;</sub> pc<sup>-2</sup></span>, which is about two orders of magnitude higher than the typical value of <span class=\"simple-math\">~</span><span class=\"simple-math\">200 <i>M</i><sub>&#8857;</sub> pc<sup>-2</sup></span> found for giant molecular clouds (GMCs) in the Milky Way, and even higher than that of GMCs in local ULIRGs of <span class=\"simple-math\">~</span><span class=\"simple-math\">10<sup>4</sup><i>M</i><sub>&#8857;</sub> pc<sup>-2</sup></span> (<a name=\"InR25\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#R25\">Downes &amp; Solomon 1998</a>). In ULIRGs, however, the CO-to-H<span class=\"simple-math\"><sub>2</sub></span> conversion factor is significantly lower, typically <span class=\"simple-math\">0.8 <i>M</i><sub>&#8857;</sub>/ (K km s<sup>-1</sup> pc<sup>2</sup>)</span> (see below). Although there is evidence for <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16-eq239.png\"></span> values of <span class=\"simple-math\">20 &#8722; 100 <i>M</i><sub>&#8857;</sub>/ (K km s<sup>-1</sup> pc<sup>2</sup>)</span> in dwarf galaxies like the Magellanic Clouds (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#R49\">Leroy et al. 2011</a>), we argue against such a high CO-to-H<span class=\"simple-math\"><sub>2</sub></span> conversion factor for MACSJ0032-arc based on the fact that its morphology, star formation rate, and CO SLED, among other factors, represent compelling evidence of a much denser and more active environment than found in local dwarf galaxies. </p>\n<p>The metallicity-dependent CO-to-H<span class=\"simple-math\"><sub>2</sub></span> conversion function strongly relies on the adopted mass-metallicity calibration, which has known caveats, in particular for objects at <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i>&gt; 2.5</span> and with low stellar masses. With the mass-metallicity relation specifically calibrated for SFGs at <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i> ~ 3 &#8722; 5</span> and valid for galaxies with <span class=\"simple-math\">log&#8201;(<i>M</i><sub>&#8727;</sub>/<i>M</i><sub>&#8857;</sub>) = 9 &#8722; 11</span> (<a name=\"InR100\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#R100\">Troncoso et al. 2014</a>), we find a similarly low metallicity for MACSJ0032-arc. On the other hand, the fundamental metallicity relation (FMR) calibrated for low-<span class=\"simple-math\"><i>M</i><sub>&#8727;</sub></span> galaxies (<a name=\"InR58\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#R58\">Mannucci et al. 2010</a>, <a name=\"InR59\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#R59\">2011</a>; <a name=\"InR13\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#R13\">Christensen et al. 2012</a>), characterized by <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#956;</i><sub>0.32</sub> = log&#8201;(<i>M</i><sub>&#8727;</sub>) &#8722; 0.32log&#8201;(<i>SFR</i>) &lt; 9.5</span> (a criterion satisfied by MACSJ0032-arc with <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#956;</i><sub>0.32</sub> = 9.1</span>), yields a higher metallicity of <span class=\"simple-math\">12 + log&#8201;(O / H)<sub>FMR</sub> = 8.5 &#177; 0.2</span> (<span class=\"simple-math\"><i>Z</i> = 0.68 <i>Z</i><sub>&#8857;</sub></span>). This higher metallicity is also supported by the low <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>R</i>3 = </span>[O&#8201;<span class=\"smallcaps\">iii</span>]&#8201;<span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#955;</i></span>5007/H<span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#946;</i></span> line flux ratio of <span class=\"simple-math\">0.63 &#177; 0.07</span>, measured in our recently acquired near-IR LBT/LUCI spectrum of MACSJ0032-arc (Walth et al., in prep.). According to the latest <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>R</i>3</span>&#8211;metallicity calibration from <a name=\"InR16\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#R16\">Curti et al. (2017)</a><sup><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#FN28\">9</a></sup>, although known to be very approximative, this ratio points to a metallicity of <span class=\"simple-math\">12 + log&#8201;(O / H)<sub>neb</sub> = 8.6 &#8722; 8.7</span>. At this higher metallicity, we obtain a much smaller <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16-eq217.png\"></span> value of <span class=\"simple-math\">7.1 &#177; 2.2 <i>M</i><sub>&#8857;</sub>/ (K km s<sup>-1</sup> pc<sup>2</sup>)</span>. Thus, the uncertainty of the metallicity of MACSJ0032-arc induces an error of at least a factor of 4 into the <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16-eq217.png\"></span> determination. </p>\n<p>Similar problems are encountered for the few MS galaxies at high redshift for which direct measurements of their gas-phase metallicities (large symbols in Fig. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#F9\">9</a>) have been obtained from the [N&#8201;<span class=\"smallcaps\">ii</span>]&#8201;<span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#955;</i>6583</span>/H<span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#945;</i></span>&#8201;<span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#955;</i>6563</span> line flux ratio and the PP04 metallicity calibration<sup><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#FN29\">10</a></sup> (<a name=\"InR98\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#R98\">Teplitz et al. 2000</a>; <a name=\"InR39\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#R39\">Hainline et al. 2009</a>; <a name=\"InR48\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#R48\">Law et al. 2009</a>; <a name=\"InR68\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#R68\">Richard et al. 2011</a>; <a name=\"InR23\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#R23\">Dessauges-Zavadsky et al. 2011</a>; <a name=\"InR36\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#R36\">Genzel et al. 2013</a>). For most of these systems, the <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16-eq217.png\"></span> values computed from their measured metallicities, which are higher than the metallicities estimated from Eq. (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#FD4\">4</a>), fall significantly below the iso-redshift curves at their <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>M</i><sub>&#8727;</sub></span> and <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i></span> values (as illustrated in Fig. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#F9\">9</a> by a redshift color-code that does not match that of the corresponding iso-redshift curve). </p>\n<p><a name=\"InR54\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#R54\">Magdis et al. (2011)</a> proposed another way of determining the CO-to-H<span class=\"simple-math\"><sub>2</sub></span> conversion factor at high redshift by using the dust mass and the CO(1<span class=\"simple-math\">&#8722;</span>0) luminosity through the relation <a name=\"FD6\"></a><span class=\"img-equation\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16-eq255.png\"><span class=\"label-eq\">(5)</span></span>This method requires the knowledge of another physical parameter that is the dust-to-gas mass ratio, defined as <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#948;</i><sub>DGR</sub> = <i>M</i><sub>dust</sub>/<i>M</i><sub>molgas</sub></span><sup><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#FN30\">11</a></sup>. The value of <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#948;</i><sub>DGR</sub></span> is assumed to vary with metallicity, following the prescription derived by <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#R49\">Leroy et al. (2011)</a> for local galaxies <a name=\"FD7\"></a><span class=\"img-equation\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16-eq258.png\"><span class=\"label-eq\">(6)</span></span>From the <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>M</i><sub>dust</sub></span> and <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16-eq131.png\"></span> values listed in Table <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#T2\">2</a> and the metallicity estimate of <span class=\"simple-math\">12 + log&#8201;(O / H)<sub>PP04</sub> = 8.0 &#177; 0.2</span> computed using Eq. (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#FD4\">4</a>), we find <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16-eq259.png\"></span> for MACSJ0032-arc. This in turn yields much more reasonable <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>M</i><sub>molgas</sub></span> and H<span class=\"simple-math\"><sub>2</sub></span> surface density. </p>\n<p>This <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16-eq260.png\"></span> value, however, differs by a factor of 11 from the value <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16-eq232.png\"></span>  computed before from Eqs. (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#FD2\">2</a>),&#8201;(<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#FD3\">3</a>), while the two derivations of the CO-to-H<span class=\"simple-math\"><sub>2</sub></span> conversion factor, if correct, should yield the same result for any given galaxy. The cause of the discrepancy does not lie in erroneous determinations of either <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16-eq131.png\"></span> or <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>M</i><sub>dust</sub></span> (Table <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#T2\">2</a>), which both enter in Eq. (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#FD6\">5</a>). Indeed, we detect the CO(1&#8211;0) emission, and therefore know the <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16-eq131.png\"></span> within the given uncertainty. Accounting for the CMB radiation leads to a higher intrinsic <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16-eq131.png\"></span> by approximately 25% (Sect. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#S12\">4.3</a>). The value of <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>M</i><sub>dust</sub></span> is notoriously more difficult to determine (Eq. (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#FD1\">1</a>)), and a factor of 2 uncertainty in the dust mass is commonly accepted. An underestimation of the 2 mm continuum emission could, in addition, increase the <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>M</i><sub>dust</sub></span> estimate, but by no more than another factor of 1.4 according to the data (see Sect. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#S6\">3.3</a>) and given the good agreement with the constant dust-to-stellar mass ratio of <span class=\"simple-math\">log&#8201;(<i>M</i><sub>dust</sub>/<i>M</i><sub>&#8727;</sub>) &#8776;  &#8722; 2.6</span>  (<a name=\"InR78\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#R78\">Santini et al. 2010</a>; <a name=\"InR88\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#R88\">Smith et al. 2012</a>; <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#R87\">Sklias et al. 2014</a>). The value of <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#948;</i><sub>DGR</sub></span> could also vary by a factor 2 given the dispersion in the <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#948;</i><sub>DGR</sub></span>&#8211;metallicity relation. However, we are still far from the factor 11. The situation is less dire if we assume the higher metallicity for MACSJ0032-arc (at <span class=\"simple-math\">12 + log&#8201;(O / H)<sub>FMR</sub> = 8.5 &#177; 0.2</span> the discrepancy falls to a factor of 7), but we are nevertheless left, in fine, with the realization that Eqs. (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#FD2\">2</a>),&#8201;(<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#FD3\">3</a>) and Eqs. (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#FD6\">5</a>),&#8201;(<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#FD7\">6</a>) cannot produce consistent results for <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16-eq217.png\"></span> and <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16-eq260.png\"></span>. </p>\n<p>There is another fundamental physical parameter that should be taken into account in the estimation of the CO-to-H<span class=\"simple-math\"><sub>2</sub></span> conversion factor, namely the gas excitation state, which depends on the galaxy temperature and density. The CO SLED analysis presented in Sect. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#S12\">4.3</a> shows that the CO excitation in MACSJ0032-arc is much higher than that of the Milky Way, and is in fact comparable to that of high-redshift SMGs. Given this similarity in the excitation state of their molecular gas, it appears appropriate to replace, for MACSJ0032-arc, <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#945;</i><sub>CO,MW</sub></span> in Eq. (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#FD2\">2</a>) by <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#945;</i><sub>CO,ULIRG</sub> &#8771; 0.8 <i>M</i><sub>&#8857;</sub>/ (K km s<sup>-1</sup> pc<sup>2</sup>)</span>  as observed in local ULIRGs (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#R89\">Solomon et al. 1997</a>; <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#R6\">Bolatto et al. 2013</a>; <a name=\"InR11\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#R11\">Carilli &amp; Walter 2013</a>). It follows that our target&#8217;s <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16-eq217.png\"></span> value is likely to be about <span class=\"simple-math\">5 &#215;</span> lower. With this alternative <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16-eq217.png\"></span> of reference, it becomes possible to reconcile <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16-eq217.png\"></span> with <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16-eq260.png\"></span> for MACSJ0032-arc down to a small factor between 1.3 and 2 depending on the adopted metallicity (<span class=\"simple-math\">12 + log&#8201;(O / H)<sub>FMR</sub> = 8.5 &#177; 0.2</span> and <span class=\"simple-math\">12 + log&#8201;(O / H)<sub>PP04</sub> = 8.0 &#177; 0.2</span>, respectively). </p>\n<p>Since we have, at present, no way to constrain the CO-to-H<span class=\"simple-math\"><sub>2</sub></span> conversion factor more tightly in MACSJ0032-arc (and in general), in the following we consider the two extreme but still reasonable <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#945;</i><sub>CO</sub></span> values for the arc (see Table <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#T2\">2</a>):</p>\n<p>\n          <ul class=\"dash\">\n            <li>\n               \n              <p><span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16-eq264.png\"></span>, corresponding to an <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16-eq217.png\"></span>  along with a metallicity of <span class=\"simple-math\">12 + log&#8201;(O / H)<sub>FMR</sub> = 8.5 &#177; 0.2</span>  computed using the FMR calibrated for low-<span class=\"simple-math\"><i>M</i><sub>&#8727;</sub></span> galaxies; </p>\n            </li>\n            <li>\n               \n              <p><span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16-eq265.png\"></span>, corresponding to an <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16-eq266.png\"></span> along with a metallicity of <span class=\"simple-math\">12 + log&#8201;(O / H)<sub>PP04</sub> = 8.0 &#177; 0.2</span> derived from Eq. (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#FD4\">4</a>). </p>\n            </li>\n          </ul>\n        </p>\n<p>These two <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#945;</i><sub>CO</sub></span> values yield a range of lensing-corrected molecular gas masses in MACSJ0032-arc of <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>M</i><sub>molgas</sub>/<i>&#956;</i> = (7.1 &#8722; 18) &#215; 10<sup>9</sup><i>M</i><sub>&#8857;</sub></span> (see Table <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#T2\">2</a>) and lensing-corrected H<span class=\"simple-math\"><sub>2</sub></span> surfaces densities of <span class=\"simple-math\">&#931;<sub>H<sub>2</sub></sub>/<i>&#956;</i> &#8819; 2200 &#8722; 5800 <i>M</i><sub>&#8857;</sub> pc<sup>2</sup></span>. </p>\n<p>Although it is clearly ill-constrained, we note that this range of <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#945;</i><sub>CO</sub></span> values for MACSJ0032-arc is consistent with results from studies of <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i> ~ 1 &#8722; 2</span> BzK and MS SFGs in which <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#945;</i><sub>CO</sub></span> was found to vary between 2 and <span class=\"simple-math\">20 <i>M</i><sub>&#8857;</sub>/ (K km s<sup>-1</sup> pc<sup>2</sup>)</span>. Indeed, <a name=\"InR55\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#R55\">Magdis et al. (2012)</a> obtained an average <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16-eq271.png\"></span> computed for 6 BzK galaxies at <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i> ~ 1.5</span> using the same Eqs. (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#FD6\">5</a>),&#8201;(<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#FD7\">6</a>), whereas for the same BzK galaxy sample <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#R19\">Daddi et al. (2010)</a> argued for <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16-eq272.png\"></span> in a work based on the dynamical masses. <a name=\"InR56\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#R56\">Magnelli et al. (2012)</a> obtained, on average, a much higher value of <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16-eq273.png\"></span> for seven MS SFGs at <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i> ~ 1</span>. In another study, <a name=\"InR35\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#R35\">Genzel et al. (2012)</a> used the Kennicutt-Schmidt (KS) relation in reverse to estimate <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>M</i><sub>molgas</sub></span> from the SFR and reported, for 44 SFGs at two median redshifts of <span class=\"simple-math\">&#10216; <i>z</i> &#10217;  = 1.2</span> and <span class=\"simple-math\">&#10216; <i>z</i> &#10217;  = 2.2</span>, a range of <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16-eq277.png\"></span> values of <span class=\"simple-math\">2 &#8722; 20 <i>M</i><sub>&#8857;</sub>/ (K km s<sup>-1</sup> pc<sup>2</sup>)</span> at metallicities from <span class=\"simple-math\">12 + log&#8201;(O / H) = 8.4</span> to 8.9. Finally, our adopted <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#945;</i><sub>CO</sub></span> values do not agree as closely with those of <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16-eq280.png\"></span> estimated for dusty starburst galaxies at <span class=\"simple-math\">2.5 &lt;<i>z</i>&lt; 5.7</span> by <a name=\"InR1\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#R1\">Aravena et al. (2016)</a> using a constant <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#948;</i><sub>DGR</sub></span>. </p>\n<p>For our compilation of CO-detected MS SFGs from the literature (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#R24\">Dessauges-Zavadsky et al. 2015</a>), in the following we adopt <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16-eq217.png\"></span>, as computed from Eqs. (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#FD2\">2</a>)&#8211;(<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#FD4\">4</a>) and, when available, we consider the measured gas phase metallicities. Special attention was paid to galaxies at <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i>&gt; 2.5</span> and/or with   <span class=\"simple-math\">log&#8201;(<i>M</i><sub>&#8727;</sub>/<i>M</i><sub>&#8857;</sub>) &lt; 10</span> because of the expected larger uncertainty in their metallicities when derived from the assumed mass-metallicity relation (Eq. (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#FD4\">4</a>)). We therefore retain these galaxies only when direct measurements of their gas phase metallicities are available (two galaxies at <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i> = 1.5859</span> and <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i> = 2.7793</span>, respectively, were thus removed from our compilation). </p>\n<p>\n          \n          <a name=\"F10\"></a><div class=\"inset\"><table>\n<tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/F10.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16-fig10_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/F10.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig. 10</span></a><p>Molecular gas depletion timescale as a function of redshift for our compilation of CO-detected MS SFGs from the literature (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#R24\">Dessauges-Zavadsky et al. 2015</a>) and MACSJ0032-arc at <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i><sub>CO</sub> = 3.6314</span> (star). The encircled data points correspond to MS SFGs with measured gas-phase metallicities. Five redshift bins are considered: <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i> ~ 0</span>, <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i> =  [ 0.055,0.4 ]</span>, <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i> =  [ 1,1.6 ]</span>, <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i> =  [ 2,2.5 ]</span>, and <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i> =  [ 2.7,3.6 ]</span>. The corresponding mean values of <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>t</i><sub>depl</sub></span> are shown as large black crosses with the associated <span class=\"simple-math\">1<i>&#963;</i></span> dispersion as standard deviation. Magenta crosses represent <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>t</i><sub>depl</sub></span> values from <a name=\"InR5\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#R5\">B&#233;thermin et al. (2015)</a> derived from the FIR dust continuum and by adopting the same mass-metallicity relation (Eq. (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#FD4\">4</a>)). The observed evolution of <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>t</i><sub>depl</sub></span> with redshift is parametrized by a power law; the best fit, <span class=\"simple-math\">1.15(1 + <i>z</i>)<sup>-0.85</sup></span>, is shown as a solid line.</p>\n</td>\n</tr>\n<tr><td colspan=\"2\"><a href=\"http://dexter.edpsciences.org/applet.php?pdf_id=10&amp;DOI=10.1051/0004-6361/201628513\" target=\"DEXTER\">Open with DEXTER</a></td></tr>\n</table></div>\n        </p>\n<h3 class=\"sec2\">\n<a name=\"S17\"></a>5.2. Molecular gas depletion timescale</h3>\n<p>The depletion timescale, defined as <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>t</i><sub>depl</sub> = <i>M</i><sub>molgas</sub>/<i>SFR</i></span>, describes how long each galaxy could sustain star formation at the current rate before running out of fuel, assuming that the gas reservoir is not replenished. Models predict the depletion of the molecular gas in galaxies over cosmic time (e.g., <a name=\"InR21\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#R21\">Dav&#233; et al. 2011</a>, <a name=\"InR22\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#R22\">2012</a>). More precisely, <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>t</i><sub>depl</sub></span> has been shown to scale as <span class=\"simple-math\">(1 + <i>z</i>)<sup>-1.5</sup></span> for the canonical disk model (<a name=\"InR60\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#R60\">Mo et al. 1998</a>; <a name=\"InR7\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#R7\">Bouch&#233; et al. 2010</a>; <a name=\"InR33\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#R33\">Genel et al. 2010</a>). The decrease in <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>t</i><sub>depl</sub></span> with redshift is amply supported by CO observations of SFGs (e.g., <a name=\"InR14\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#R14\">Combes et al. 2013</a>; <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#R96\">Tacconi et al. 2013</a>; <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#R77\">Saintonge et al. 2013</a>), but with growing evidence of a more modest redshift evolution of <span class=\"simple-math\">(1 + <i>z</i>)<sup><i>&#947;</i></sup></span>, with <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#947;</i></span> possibly as low as <span class=\"simple-math\">&#8722; 0.16</span> (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#R37\">Genzel et al. 2015</a>). <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#R37\">Genzel et al. (2015)</a>, <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#R5\">B&#233;thermin et al. (2015)</a>, and <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#R82\">Schinnerer et al. (2016)</a> also find <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>t</i><sub>depl</sub>(<i>z</i>)</span> to be only slowly evolving when estimating <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>t</i><sub>depl</sub></span> from the FIR dust continuum. </p>\n<p>In Fig. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#F10\">10</a> we show <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>t</i><sub>depl</sub></span> as a function of redshift for MACSJ0032-arc, and for our compilation of CO-detected galaxies from the literature (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#R24\">Dessauges-Zavadsky et al. 2015</a>), which we restrict to SFGs lying within the accepted thickness of the MS (<span class=\"simple-math\">0.3 &lt;<i>sSFR</i>/<i>sSFR</i><sub>MS</sub>&lt; 3</span>), a condition also satisfied by MACSJ0032-arc (see Sect. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#S11\">4.2</a>). The underlying CO-to-H<span class=\"simple-math\"><sub>2</sub></span> conversion factors are uniformly derived for the sample of SFGs as explained in Sect. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#S16\">5.1</a>. We extend the redshift range explored by <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#R37\">Genzel et al. (2015)</a> by adding the measured depletion times from CO of 5 MS SFGs in the <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i> =  [ 2.7,3.6 ]</span> bin to the analysis, including that of MACSJ0032-arc. The new best-fit power law description of <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>t</i><sub>depl</sub>(<i>z</i>)</span> is then given by the <span class=\"simple-math\">(1 + <i>z</i>)<sup>-0.85</sup></span> scaling and is on average steeper than that determined by <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#R37\">Genzel et al. (2015)</a> only for galaxies at <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i> &#8818; 2.5</span>. With <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>t</i><sub>depl</sub></span>  declining from <span class=\"simple-math\">~</span><span class=\"simple-math\">1.0 Gyr</span> at <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i> ~ 0</span> to <span class=\"simple-math\">~</span><span class=\"simple-math\">270 Myr</span> at <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i> ~ 3.2</span>, the observed <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>t</i><sub>depl</sub></span> evolution is very similar to that inferred from the FIR dust continuum, which yields only moderate redshift evolution up to <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i> ~ 2.5</span> followed by more rapid evolution at higher redshift (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#R5\">B&#233;thermin et al. 2015</a>). We almost invoke a two-step power law for the redshift evolution of <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>t</i><sub>depl</sub></span>, with a turnover around <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i> ~ 2.8</span>, but this still needs to be confirmed with more <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>t</i><sub>depl</sub></span> measurements at <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i>&gt; 2.5</span>. </p>\n<p>Overall, <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>t</i><sub>depl</sub></span> shows a more modest redshift evolution than predicted by galaxy evolution models. This may be partly due to the metallicity-dependent CO-to-H<span class=\"simple-math\"><sub>2</sub></span> conversion function we have adopted (<span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16-eq217.png\"></span> computed using Eqs. (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#FD2\">2</a>)&#8211;(<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#FD4\">4</a>)). As discussed in Sect. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#S16\">5.1</a> and shown in Fig. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#F9\">9</a>, <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16-eq217.png\"></span> increases with redshift for all <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>M</i><sub>&#8727;</sub></span>. Adopting this <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16-eq219.png\"></span> may thus artificially flatten the redshift evolution of <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>t</i><sub>depl</sub></span>. A steeper evolution is indeed observed when a simple <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#945;</i><sub>CO,MW</sub></span> conversion factor is applied to MS SFGs. In this case, the power law index <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#947;</i></span> is found to vary between <span class=\"simple-math\">&#8722; 1.5</span> and <span class=\"simple-math\">&#8722; 1</span> (see <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#R96\">Tacconi et al. 2013</a>; <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#R24\">Dessauges-Zavadsky et al. 2015</a>). In any event, the lower <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>t</i><sub>depl</sub></span> average observed at the highest redshifts, i.e., in the <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i> =  [ 2.7,3.6 ]</span> bin, as well as the resulting evolution of <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>t</i><sub>depl</sub></span> with cosmic time only become the more solid results. </p>\n<h3 class=\"sec2\">\n<a name=\"S18\"></a>5.3. Molecular gas fraction</h3>\n<p>The molecular gas fraction is defined as <a name=\"FD8\"></a><span class=\"img-equation\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16-eq305.png\"><span class=\"label-eq\">(7)</span></span>Here, <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>f</i><sub>molgas</sub></span> depends on both sSFR and <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>t</i><sub>depl</sub></span>. The monotonic rise of sSFR with redshift, commonly parametrized as <span class=\"simple-math\">(1 + <i>z</i>)<sup><i>&#947;</i></sup></span>, where <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#947;</i> = 1.5 &#8722; 3</span>, is now well established observationally and theoretically (e.g., <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#R79\">Schaerer &amp; de Barros 2009</a>; <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#R84\">Schreiber et al. 2015</a>; <a name=\"InR94\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#R94\">Tacchella et al. 2016</a>; <a name=\"InR29\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#R29\">Faisst et al. 2016</a>). Combined with the modest redshift evolution of <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>t</i><sub>depl</sub></span> discussed in Sect. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#S17\">5.2</a>, an increase in <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>f</i><sub>molgas</sub></span> with redshift is similarly expected. This <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>f</i><sub>molgas</sub></span> evolution with cosmic time is in line with various model predictions (e.g., <a name=\"InR62\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#R62\">Obreschkow &amp; Rawlings 2009</a>; <a name=\"InR46\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#R46\">Lagos et al. 2011</a>, <a name=\"InR47\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#R47\">2014</a>), and could partly be at the origin of the steep decline in the star formation rate density after the peak of activity around <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i> = 1.5 &#8722; 2</span> (<a name=\"InR53\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#R53\">Madau et al. 1998</a>; <a name=\"InR40\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#R40\">Hopkins &amp; Beacom 2006</a>) as the molecular gas is the fuel for star formation. </p>\n<p>In Fig. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#F11\">11</a> we show <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>f</i><sub>molgas</sub></span> as a function of redshift for MACSJ0032-arc, and for our compilation of CO-detected galaxies from the literature (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#R24\">Dessauges-Zavadsky et al. 2015</a>), the latter having again been restricted to SFGs lying within the accepted thickness of the MS. We assume for the SFGs from the literature the same underlying CO-to-H<span class=\"simple-math\"><sub>2</sub></span> conversion factors as for <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>t</i><sub>depl</sub></span> measurements (see Sect. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#S16\">5.1</a>). Extending the compilation of CO measurements to higher redshifts, the observed evolution of <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>f</i><sub>molgas</sub></span> with redshift is well reproduced by the scaling law <span class=\"simple-math\">1 / (1 + (0.12(1 + <i>z</i>)<sup>2.8</sup> &#215; (1 + <i>z</i>)<sup>-0.85</sup>)<sup>-1</sup>)</span> (Eq. (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#FD8\">7</a>)), composed of the <span class=\"simple-math\">(1 + <i>z</i>)<sup><i>&#947;</i></sup></span> best-fit descriptions of, respectively, <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>sSFR</i>(<i>z</i>)</span> (e.g., <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#R96\">Tacconi et al. 2013</a>) and <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>t</i><sub>depl</sub>(<i>z</i>)</span> (Sect. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#S17\">5.2</a>). This scaling law predicts an increase of <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>f</i><sub>molgas</sub></span> with redshift, which is at odds with the flattening of <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>f</i><sub>molgas</sub>(<i>z</i>)</span> beyond <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i> &#8819; 2</span> previously claimed for CO-detected MS SFGs  (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#R77\">Saintonge et al. 2013</a>; <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#R24\">Dessauges-Zavadsky et al. 2015</a>), and for FIR dust continuum <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>f</i><sub>molgas</sub></span> estimates (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#R100\">Troncoso et al. 2014</a>; <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#R5\">B&#233;thermin et al. 2015</a>; <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#R82\">Schinnerer et al. 2016</a>). Nevertheless, currently, taking the few available CO measurements at <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i> &#8819; 2</span> at face value, we cannot exclude either the increase in or the flattening of <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>f</i><sub>molgas</sub></span> at high redshifts, since the two molecular gas fraction means, <span class=\"simple-math\">&#10216; <i>f</i><sub>molgas</sub> &#10217;  = 0.44 &#177; 0.08</span> at <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i> =  [ 2,2.5 ]</span>  and <span class=\"simple-math\">&#10216; <i>f</i><sub>molgas</sub> &#10217;  = 0.61 &#177; 0.22</span> at <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i> =  [ 2.7,3.6 ]</span>, agree within their <span class=\"simple-math\">1<i>&#963;</i></span> errors defined as the standard deviation of the respective <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>f</i><sub>molgas</sub></span> dispersions. </p>\n<p>\n          \n          <a name=\"F11\"></a><div class=\"inset\"><table>\n<tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/F11.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16-fig11_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/F11.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig. 11</span></a><p>Same as Fig. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#F10\">10</a>, but for the molecular gas fraction. A clear evolution of <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>f</i><sub>molgas</sub></span> with redshift is observed, in good agreement with <span class=\"simple-math\">1 / (1 + (0.12(1 + <i>z</i>)<sup>1.95</sup>)<sup>-1</sup>)</span> (solid line).</p>\n</td>\n</tr>\n<tr><td colspan=\"2\"><a href=\"http://dexter.edpsciences.org/applet.php?pdf_id=11&amp;DOI=10.1051/0004-6361/201628513\" target=\"DEXTER\">Open with DEXTER</a></td></tr>\n</table></div>\n        </p>\n<p>Moreover, the adopted metallicity-dependent <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16-eq217.png\"></span> function may artificially boost the redshift evolution of <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>f</i><sub>molgas</sub></span> for the same reasons that it may lessen the redshift evolution of <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>t</i><sub>depl</sub></span> (see Fig. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#F9\">9</a>). Indeed, the aforementioned plateau in <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>f</i><sub>molgas</sub></span>  at <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i> &#8819; 2</span> is more clearly observed when instead a simple <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#945;</i><sub>CO,MW</sub></span> conversion factor is applied to MS SFGs (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#R24\">Dessauges-Zavadsky et al. 2015</a>). We can eliminate, in our estimate of <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16-eq217.png\"></span>, at least the uncertainty in the mass-metallicity relation (Eq. (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#FD4\">4</a>)) by considering only the few objects with direct gas-phase metallicity measurements (encircled data points in Fig. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#F11\">11</a>). Nevertheless, the mean <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>f</i><sub>molgas</sub></span> at <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i> =  [ 2.7,3.6 ]</span>, in that case, still remains above that of the <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i> =  [ 1,1.6 ]</span> and <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i> =  [ 2,2.5 ]</span> bins, but with the same large standard deviation. Interestingly, the new <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>f</i><sub>molgas</sub></span> measurement as high as 60&#8211;79% obtained in MACSJ0032-arc, which is the highest redshift object with a CO measure, favors a steady increase in <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>f</i><sub>molgas</sub></span> with redshift irrespective of the <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#945;</i><sub>CO</sub></span> employed. </p>\n<p>Finally, we would like to note that all the CO measurements at <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i>&gt; 2.5</span> (except one, the non-encircled triangle in Fig. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#F11\">11</a>) come from lensed galaxies with low stellar masses (<span class=\"simple-math\">log&#8201;(<i>M</i><sub>&#8727;</sub>/<i>M</i><sub>&#8857;</sub>) &lt; 10.4</span>), whereas CO is most commonly measured in massive galaxies at <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i>&lt; 2.5</span>. Similarly, all the molecular gas mass estimates from the FIR dust continuum are derived for massive galaxies. Given the expected increase in <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>f</i><sub>molgas</sub></span> with decreasing <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>M</i><sub>&#8727;</sub></span>  (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#R7\">Bouch&#233; et al. 2010</a>; <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#R21\">Dav&#233; et al. 2011</a>), the possible trend for an increase in <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>f</i><sub>molgas</sub></span> beyond <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i> ~ 2.5</span> may reflect the higher <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>f</i><sub>molgas</sub></span>  expected to be found in low-mass galaxies (see <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#R24\">Dessauges-Zavadsky et al. 2015</a>) if the mass dependence of <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>f</i><sub>molgas</sub></span> is stronger than its dependence on redshift. </p>\n<h2 class=\"sec\">\n<a name=\"S19\"></a>6. Summary and conclusions</h2>\n<p>For the first time, we can simultaneously characterize the stellar, dust, and molecular gas properties in a normal star-forming galaxy at a redshift as high as <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i><sub>CO</sub> = 3.6314</span>. MACSJ0032-arc has a fairly low stellar mass <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16-eq164.png\"></span> and a star formation rate <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16-eq315.png\"></span> when corrected for the lensing magnification <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#956;</i> = 62 &#177; 6</span>, placing it relatively close to the main sequence at <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i> ~ 4</span> with an offset <span class=\"simple-math\">&#8818;</span><span class=\"simple-math\">+ 0.3 dex</span> depending on the MS definition (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#R96\">Tacconi et al. 2013</a>; <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#R90\">Speagle et al. 2014</a>; <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#R99\">Tomczak et al. 2016</a>). Moreover, it follows the tight correlation between IR and CO(1&#8211;0) luminosities (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#R24\">Dessauges-Zavadsky et al. 2015</a>; <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#R85\">Scoville et al. 2016</a>). MACSJ0032-arc shows no weakening of its <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16-eq131.png\"></span> (see <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#R97\">Tan et al. 2013</a>) compared to the expectations based on the <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>L</i><sub>IR</sub></span>&#8211;<span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16-eq131.png\"></span>  relation satisfied by MS SFGs at <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i> &#8818; 2.5</span>. Our findings for MACSJ0032-arc can be summarized as follows: </p>\n<p>\n        <ul style=\"list-style-type: none;\">\n          <li>\n            1. \n            <p class=\"ligne\"> About 90% of the total<span class=\"simple-math\"><i>SFR</i><sub>UV + IR</sub></span> of MACSJ0032-arc is inaccessible at rest-frame UV wavelengths, but is detected through thermal dust emission in the FIR regime. </p>\n          </li>\n          <li>\n            2. \n            <p class=\"ligne\"> In HST images, MACSJ0032-arc is resolved into two UV-bright knots, separated by <span class=\"simple-math\">1.14 &#177; 0.28 kpc</span>. The bulk of the molecular gas mass and star formation of the lensed galaxy is, however, decoupled from the rest-frame UV emission and comes from between these two UV knots, i.e., from a region too dusty to be detected at rest-frame UV wavelengths, shown to also host the 2 mm cold dust emission. </p>\n          </li>\n          <li>\n            3. \n            <p class=\"ligne\"> With the detection of the CO(1&#8211;0), CO(4&#8211;3), and CO(6&#8211;5) emission lines, whose fluxes have been corrected against the CMB, we can constrain the CO luminosity correction factors for the high <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>J</i> = 4</span> and <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>J</i> = 6</span> CO transitions in a normal SFG at <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i> ~ 3.6</span>. The derived values of <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>r</i><sub>4,1</sub> = 0.60 &#177; 0.17</span> and <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>r</i><sub>6,1</sub> = 0.28 &#177; 0.08</span> describe a CO SLED featuring a slightly more highly excited CO than found in lower-redshift SFGs, but in line with CO excitation levels observed in high-redshift SMGs even though the IR luminosity, <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16-eq181.png\"></span>, of MACSJ0032-arc is 10 times lower than typically observed in SMGs. The high CO excitation is likely due to the compactness of MACSJ0032-arc, that could result from the general fact that galaxies are more compact at higher redshifts because of their smaller sizes. These results are of particular interest in the context of high-redshift normal star-forming galaxies and their molecular gas mass estimates as only high CO rotational transitions (<span class=\"simple-math\"><i>J</i> &#8805; 4</span>) are accessible beyond <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i> ~ 4</span>  with the NOrthern Extended Millimeter Array (NOEMA) and ALMA. </p>\n          </li>\n          <li>\n            4. \n            <p class=\"ligne\"> We interpret the morphology of MACSJ0032-arc as indicative of it being a single system whose molecular gas and intense dusty star formation resides and occurs primarily in its center, surrounded by two UV-bright star-forming regions, possibly in rotation. This configuration may also be the result of a recent merger or accretion event, albeit not one big enough to completely disrupt the kinematic state of the galaxy, as we still observe double-peaked CO(4&#8211;3) and CO(6&#8211;5) line profiles. </p>\n          </li>\n          <li>\n            5. \n            <p class=\"ligne\"> Measurements of both the dust mass and the CO(1&#8211;0) luminosity of MACSJ0032-arc enable us to estimate its CO-to-H<span class=\"simple-math\"><sub>2</sub></span> conversion factor, <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#945;</i><sub>CO</sub></span>, using several independent methods. First, we consider the redshift-dependent mass-metallicity relation and metallicity-dependent <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16-eq217.png\"></span> function adopted by <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#R37\">Genzel et al. (2015)</a>. This method yields a metallicity of <span class=\"simple-math\">12 + log&#8201;(O / H)<sub>PP04</sub> = 8.0 &#177; 0.2</span> and a value of <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16-eq232.png\"></span>. Alternatively, assuming the metallicity-dependent dust-to-gas mass ratio from <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#R49\">Leroy et al. (2011)</a>, we obtain the markedly different value of <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16-eq259.png\"></span>. Part of the discrepancy may be due to the uncertainty on the metallicity &#8211; we get a metallicity as high as <span class=\"simple-math\">12 + log&#8201;(O / H)<sub>FMR</sub> = 8.5 &#177; 0.2</span>  when using the FMR calibrated for low-<span class=\"simple-math\"><i>M</i><sub>&#8727;</sub></span> galaxies &#8211; and/or the high CO excitation observed in the arc, which may imply an additional correction factor to <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16-eq217.png\"></span> on the order of <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#945;</i><sub>CO,MW</sub>/<i>&#945;</i><sub>CO,ULIRG</sub> ~ 5</span>. When this high CO excitation state is accounted for, the discrepancy between <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16-eq217.png\"></span> and <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16-eq260.png\"></span> falls to a factor between 1.3 and 2 depending on the adopted metallicity. We thus assume the CO-to-H<span class=\"simple-math\"><sub>2</sub></span> conversion factor for MACSJ0032-arc to lie between <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16-eq265.png\"></span> along with the <span class=\"simple-math\">12 + log&#8201;(O / H)<sub>PP04</sub></span> metallicity and <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16-eq264.png\"></span> along with the <span class=\"simple-math\">12 + log&#8201;(O / H)<sub>FMR</sub></span> metallicity. </p>\n          </li>\n          <li>\n            6. \n            <p class=\"ligne\"> Adopting the above <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#945;</i><sub>CO</sub></span> interval, we derive a depletion time for the molecular gas in this <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i> ~ 3.6</span> star-forming galaxy of <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>t</i><sub>depl</sub> = 0.14 &#8722; 0.35 Gyr</span>. Along with that of other high-redshift MS SFGs, generally limited to <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i> &#8818; 2.5</span> because of the scarce number of CO measurements existing beyond this redshift, our analysis confirms the decrease in <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>t</i><sub>depl</sub></span> with cosmic time, although to a lesser degree than predicted by galaxy evolution models. </p>\n          </li>\n          <li>\n            7. \n            <p class=\"ligne\"> For the same <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#945;</i><sub>CO</sub></span> interval, we find the molecular gas fraction of MACSJ0032-arc to lie in the range <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>f</i><sub>molgas</sub> = 0.60 &#8722; 0.79</span>. When combined with the results obtained previously for the few <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i> &#8819; 2.7</span> MS SFGs with available CO measurements, the corresponding <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>f</i><sub>molgas</sub></span> mean supports the continued increase in <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>f</i><sub>molgas</sub></span> with redshift; however, its large standard deviation does not enable us to exclude the possible flattening of <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>f</i><sub>molgas</sub></span> beyond <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i> ~ 2</span>. More CO measurements in MS SFGs at <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i>&gt; 2.5</span> are clearly needed to confirm the redshift evolution of <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>f</i><sub>molgas</sub></span>. </p>\n          </li>\n        </ul>\n      </p>\n    <hr width=\"30%\" align=\"left\">\n<div><div>\n<a name=\"FN20\"></a><sup>1</sup> <p class=\"ligne\"> The <i>Herschel </i>beam varies in size from <span class=\"simple-math\">18&#8242;&#8242;</span> at 250 <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#956;</i></span>m to <span class=\"simple-math\">37&#8242;&#8242;</span> at 500 <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#956;</i></span>m.</p>\n</div></div>\n<div><div>\n<a name=\"FN21\"></a><sup>2</sup> <p class=\"ligne\">\n          <a href=\"http://herschel.esac.esa.int/hcss-doc-16.0/load/spire_drg/html/ch06s09.html\" target=\"_blank\">http://herschel.esac.esa.int/hcss-doc-16.0/load/spire_drg/html/ch06s09.html</a>\n        </p>\n</div></div>\n<div><div>\n<a name=\"FN22\"></a><sup>3</sup> <p class=\"ligne\"> This correction, derived by propagating the CO(6&#8211;5)&#8211;<i>F814W </i>color properly measured in image C over the counter-image E, represents a total CO(6&#8211;5) line integrated flux decrease of 10%.</p>\n</div></div>\n<div><div>\n<a name=\"FN23\"></a><sup>4</sup> <p class=\"ligne\"> We find a slightly lower <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>r</i><sub>6,1</sub> = 0.25</span>, but still within the <span class=\"simple-math\">1<i>&#963;</i></span> uncertainty, when using the robust CO(1&#8211;0) and CO(6&#8211;5) line detections of the counter-image C alone (see Fig. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#F2\">2</a>).</p>\n</div></div>\n<div><div>\n<a name=\"FN24\"></a><sup>5</sup> <p class=\"ligne\"> Defined as <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#963;</i><sub>position</sub> &#8776; beam<sub>FWHM</sub>/ (2 &#215; <i>S</i>/<i>N</i>)</span> with the beam full width half maximum (<span class=\"simple-math\">beam<sub>FWHM</sub></span>) in arcseconds and the signal-to-noise ratio (S/N) of the detection (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#R15\">Condon 1997</a>).</p>\n</div></div>\n<div><div>\n<a name=\"FN25\"></a><sup>6</sup> <p class=\"ligne\"> Not detected down to the <span class=\"simple-math\">5<i>&#963;</i></span> magnitude limit of 27.4 as measured in a <span class=\"simple-math\">0.2&#8242;&#8242;</span> diameter aperture in the HST/ACS <i>F814W </i>filter.</p>\n</div></div>\n<div><div>\n<a name=\"FN26\"></a><sup>7</sup> <p class=\"ligne\"> We do not include the very tentative CO measurement from <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#R52\">Livermore et al. (2012)</a> obtained in a strongly lensed galaxy at <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i> ~ 4.9</span>.</p>\n</div></div>\n<div><div>\n<a name=\"FN27\"></a><sup>8</sup> <p class=\"ligne\"> Equivalent to <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>X</i><sub>CO,MW</sub> = 2 &#215; 10<sup>20</sup> cm<sup>-2</sup>/ (K km s<sup>-1</sup>)</span>.</p>\n</div></div>\n<div><div>\n<a name=\"FN28\"></a><sup>9</sup> <p class=\"ligne\">\n          <a href=\"http://www.arcetri.astro.it/metallicity/calibrazioni.pl\" target=\"_blank\">http://www.arcetri.astro.it/metallicity/calibrazioni.pl</a>\n        </p>\n</div></div>\n<div><div>\n<a name=\"FN29\"></a><sup>10</sup> <p class=\"ligne\"> Except for the Cosmic Eye at <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i> = 3.074</span>, where the gas-phase metallicity is determined from the <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>R</i>23</span> metallicity calibration.</p>\n</div></div>\n<div><div>\n<a name=\"FN30\"></a><sup>11</sup> <p class=\"ligne\"> At high redshift, it is generally assumed that <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>M</i><sub>H<sub>2</sub></sub> &#8811; <i>M</i><sub>H I</sub></span>, or equivalently <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>M</i><sub>H<sub>2</sub> + H I</sub> &#8771; <i>M</i><sub>molgas</sub> = <i>M</i><sub>dust</sub>/<i>&#948;</i><sub>DGR</sub></span>.</p>\n</div></div>\n    <h2 class=\"sec\">\n<a name=\"ack\"></a>Acknowledgments</h2>\n<p>We thank the IRAM staff of both the Plateau de Bure Interferometer and the 30 m telescope for the high-quality data acquired and for their support during observations and data reduction. We are, in particular, grateful to M&#233;lanie Krips, Jan Martin Winters, and Nicolas Billot. This work was supported by the Swiss National Science Foundation. </p>\n    <h2 class=\"sec\">\n<a name=\"ref\"></a>References</h2>\n    <div id=\"content\">\n        <ol class=\"references\">\n                    <li>\n                <a name=\"R1\"></a>Aravena, M., Spilker, J.                \n                \n                 <span class=\"Z3988\" title=\"\">\n                                    </span>\n\n                \n                            </li>\n                    <li>\n                <a name=\"R7\"></a>Bouch\u00e9, N., Dekel, A., Genzel, R., et al. 2010, ApJ, 718, 1001\n\n                \n                                                            <a
