target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Table 1</span></a><p>From optical to radio photometry and CO line integrated fluxes of MACSJ0032-arc.</p>\n<div class=\"in-txt\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#T1\">In the text</a></div>\n</div></div>\n<div class=\"inset\"><div class=\"ligne\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/T2.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Table 2</span></a><p>Physical properties of MACSJ0032-arc.</p>\n<div class=\"in-txt\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#T2\">In the text</a></div>\n</div></div>\n<h2 class=\"sec\">\n<a name=\"figs\"></a>All Figures</h2>\n<div class=\"inset\"><table>\n<tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/F1.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16-fig1_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/F1.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig. 1</span></a><p>Color-composite image of MACSJ0032-arc obtained using the HST/ACS <i>F606W </i>and <i>F814W </i>filters (<i>left panel</i>). The studied galaxy at <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i><sub>CO</sub> = 3.6314</span>, strongly lensed by the galaxy cluster MACS&#8201;J0032.1+1808, is composed of six multiple images well resolved in the HST image, labeled A, B, C, D, E, and F and encircled in white. They form a giant arc extending over <span class=\"simple-math\">42.4&#8242;&#8242;</span>. The <i>right panels </i>show, respectively, the zoom-in color-composite image obtained using the <i>Spitzer</i>/IRAC 3.6 and <span class=\"simple-math\">4.5 <i>&#956;</i></span>m bands over the multiple images B, C, D, E, and F (<i>top</i>) and the zoom-out color-composite image obtained using the <i>Herschel</i>/SPIRE 250, 350, and <span class=\"simple-math\">500 <i>&#956;</i></span>m bands; the white box represents a <span class=\"simple-math\">40&#8242;&#8242; &#215; 40&#8242;&#8242;</span> area.</p>\n</td>\n</tr>\n<tr><td colspan=\"2\"><a href=\"http://dexter.edpsciences.org/applet.php?pdf_id=1&amp;DOI=10.1051/0004-6361/201628513\" target=\"DEXTER\">Open with DEXTER</a></td></tr>\n<tr><td colspan=\"2\" class=\"in-txt\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#F1\">In the text</a></td></tr>\n</table></div>\n<div class=\"inset\"><table>\n<tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/F2.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16-fig2_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/F2.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig. 2</span></a><p><i>Herschel</i>/SPIRE <span class=\"simple-math\">250 <i>&#956;</i></span>m, <i>Spitzer</i>/IRAC <span class=\"simple-math\">3.6 <i>&#956;</i></span>m, PdBI 2 mm continuum, JVLA 5 GHz continuum, PdBI CO(6&#8211;5) line emission, and JVLA CO(1&#8211;0) line emission contours (in red) overlaid, <i>from left to right and from top to bottom</i>, on the HST/ACS <i>F814W </i>multiple images B, C, D, and E of MACSJ0032-arc. The contribution of the counter-image F is negligible. X refers to a galaxy member of the lensing cluster. Contour levels start at <span class=\"simple-math\">2<i>&#963;</i></span> and are spaced in steps of <span class=\"simple-math\">1<i>&#963;</i></span>, expect for IRAC <span class=\"simple-math\">3.6 <i>&#956;</i></span>m where the contours are in steps of 9, 16, 25, 36, <span class=\"simple-math\">49<i>&#963;</i></span>, etc. The SPIRE detection extends beyond the multiple images B, C, D, and E, as shown in Fig. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#F1\">1</a>, but peaks at <span class=\"simple-math\">4<i>&#963;</i></span> over B, C, D, and E. The rms levels of the 2 mm, 5 GHz, CO(6&#8211;5), and CO(1&#8211;0) data are 57 <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#956;</i></span>Jy, 1.7 <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#956;</i></span>Jy, 93 <span class=\"simple-math\">mJy km s<sup>-1</sup></span>, and 6.2 <span class=\"simple-math\">mJy km s<sup>-1</sup></span>, respectively. The size and orientation of the beam are indicated by the dotted (PdBI) or filled (JVLA) red ellipse in the bottom right corner. </p>\n</td>\n</tr>\n<tr><td colspan=\"2\"><a href=\"http://dexter.edpsciences.org/applet.php?pdf_id=2&amp;DOI=10.1051/0004-6361/201628513\" target=\"DEXTER\">Open with DEXTER</a></td></tr>\n<tr><td colspan=\"2\" class=\"in-txt\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#F2\">In the text</a></td></tr>\n</table></div>\n<div class=\"inset\"><table>\n<tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/F3.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16-fig3_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/F3.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig. 3</span></a><p>Observed HST/ACS <i>F814W </i>optical image of the multiple images B, C, D, E, and F of MACSJ0032-arc with the critical line in red (<i>left panel</i>); simulated observation of MACSJ0032-arc resulting from the best lens model when accounting for the PSF of the HST image (<i>middle panel</i>); and source plane reconstruction of MACSJ0032-arc obtained by simulating the morphology of the source as the combination of three elliptical Gaussian light profiles (<i>right panel</i>). The two bright knots, resolved in the HST rest-frame UV images, are separated by <span class=\"simple-math\">1.14 &#177; 0.28 kpc</span> in the source plane. The simulated HST observation includes a constant Gaussian noise background matched to the <i>F814W </i>noise level.</p>\n</td>\n</tr>\n<tr><td colspan=\"2\"><a href=\"http://dexter.edpsciences.org/applet.php?pdf_id=3&amp;DOI=10.1051/0004-6361/201628513\" target=\"DEXTER\">Open with DEXTER</a></td></tr>\n<tr><td colspan=\"2\" class=\"in-txt\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#F3\">In the text</a></td></tr>\n</table></div>\n<div class=\"inset\"><table>\n<tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/F4.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16-fig4_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/F4.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig. 4</span></a><p>Observed SED of MACSJ0032-arc at <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i><sub>CO</sub> = 3.6314</span>. Overlaid are the best-fit stellar SED (solid cyan line) obtained with the energy-conserving model and constant SFR SFH, as well as the best-fit FIR and mm SED obtained with the <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#R101\">Vega et al. (2008)</a> empirical template (solid red line) and the MBB with a <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#946;</i></span>-slope fixed at 2 (dashed black line).</p>\n</td>\n</tr>\n<tr><td colspan=\"2\"><a href=\"http://dexter.edpsciences.org/applet.php?pdf_id=4&amp;DOI=10.1051/0004-6361/201628513\" target=\"DEXTER\">Open with DEXTER</a></td></tr>\n<tr><td colspan=\"2\" class=\"in-txt\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#F4\">In the text</a></td></tr>\n</table></div>\n<div class=\"inset\"><table>\n<tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/F5.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16-fig5_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/F5.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig. 5</span></a><p>CMB corrected CO SLED of MACSJ0032-arc at <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i><sub>CO</sub> = 3.6314</span> (red stars) compared to the average CO SLEDs of the Milky Way (black crosses), the local (U)LIRGs (green circles), the <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i> ~ 1 &#8722; 4</span> SMGs (blue squares), and the <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i> ~ 1.5</span> BzK galaxies (magenta triangles). All SLEDs are normalized to the CO(1&#8211;0) flux of the average SLED for BzK galaxies, except the Milky Way normalized using CO(2&#8211;1).</p>\n</td>\n</tr>\n<tr><td colspan=\"2\"><a href=\"http://dexter.edpsciences.org/applet.php?pdf_id=5&amp;DOI=10.1051/0004-6361/201628513\" target=\"DEXTER\">Open with DEXTER</a></td></tr>\n<tr><td colspan=\"2\" class=\"in-txt\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#F5\">In the text</a></td></tr>\n</table></div>\n<div class=\"inset\"><table>\n<tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/F6.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16-fig6_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/F6.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig. 6</span></a><p>Comparison of the observed JVLA CO(1&#8211;0) line emission, PdBI CO(6&#8211;5) line emission, JVLA 5 GHz continuum, and PdBI 2 mm continuum contours, overlaid on the HST/ACS <i>F814W </i>multiple images B, C, D, and E of MACSJ0032-arc (<i>left panels</i>), with the respective simulated beam-convolved emission maps in the image plane (yellow contours in the <i>middle and right panels</i>) obtained for two different combinations of elliptical Gaussian light profiles in the source plane: one extended Gaussian component placed between the two HST UV-bright knots (yellow contours in the <i>top middle panel</i>) and two Gaussian components with locations and shapes following the two UV-bright knots (yellow contours in the <i>top right panel</i>). Noise realizations based on the data are added to the simulated maps, and the absolute flux scaling is obtained by matching the observed flux at the peak of the emission in the counter-image C in each of the CO(1&#8211;0), CO(6&#8211;5), 5 GHz, and 2 mm simulated maps. The critical line is in red. The size and orientation of the beams are indicated by the dashed green ellipses. Contour levels start at <span class=\"simple-math\">2<i>&#963;</i></span> and are spaced in steps of <span class=\"simple-math\">1<i>&#963;</i></span> (as in Fig. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#F2\">2</a>).</p>\n</td>\n</tr>\n<tr><td colspan=\"2\"><a href=\"http://dexter.edpsciences.org/applet.php?pdf_id=6&amp;DOI=10.1051/0004-6361/201628513\" target=\"DEXTER\">Open with DEXTER</a></td></tr>\n<tr><td colspan=\"2\" class=\"in-txt\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#F6\">In the text</a></td></tr>\n</table></div>\n<div class=\"inset\"><table>\n<tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/F7.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16-fig7_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/F7.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig. 7</span></a><p>Spectra of the CO(6&#8211;5), CO(4&#8211;3), and CO(1&#8211;0) emission lines detected in MACSJ0032-arc binned in steps of <span class=\"simple-math\">40.16 km s<sup>-1</sup></span>, expect for the CO(1&#8211;0) line where channels have a resolution of <span class=\"simple-math\">144.54 km s<sup>-1</sup></span>. The cyan-shaded regions indicate channels where positive emission is detected. These channels are used to derive the CO line integrated fluxes and the velocity-integrated and velocity-averaged maps shown in Figs. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#F2\">2</a> and <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#F8\">8</a>, respectively. The solid red lines show the single or double Gaussian profiles that best fit the observed CO line profiles. The zero velocity is set to <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i><sub>CO</sub> = 3.6314</span>.</p>\n</td>\n</tr>\n<tr><td colspan=\"2\"><a href=\"http://dexter.edpsciences.org/applet.php?pdf_id=7&amp;DOI=10.1051/0004-6361/201628513\" target=\"DEXTER\">Open with DEXTER</a></td></tr>\n<tr><td colspan=\"2\" class=\"in-txt\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#F7\">In the text</a></td></tr>\n</table></div>\n<div class=\"inset\"><table>\n<tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/F8.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16-fig8_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/F8.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig. 8</span></a><p>Velocity-averaged maps of the CO(6&#8211;5) emission of the counter-images E (<i>left panel</i>), C+D (<i>middle panel</i>), and B (<i>right panel</i>) of MACSJ0032-arc. Overlaid are the CO(6&#8211;5) contours integrated over, respectively, the channels that define the blue component (blue contours) and the red component (red contours) of the double-peaked CO(6&#8211;5) line profile shown in Fig. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#F7\">7</a>. The color-coding is in units of integrated flux <span class=\"simple-math\">Jy km s<sup>-1</sup></span> and starts at <span class=\"simple-math\">2<i>&#963;</i></span>. Contour levels also start at <span class=\"simple-math\">2<i>&#963;</i></span> and are spaced in steps of <span class=\"simple-math\">1<i>&#963;</i></span>. A clear spatial offset between the blue and red contours is observed. The corresponding PdBI beam size of <span class=\"simple-math\">1.94&#8242;&#8242; &#215; 1.62&#8242;&#8242;</span> is about the size of the individual counter-images themselves.</p>\n</td>\n</tr>\n<tr><td colspan=\"2\"><a href=\"http://dexter.edpsciences.org/applet.php?pdf_id=8&amp;DOI=10.1051/0004-6361/201628513\" target=\"DEXTER\">Open with DEXTER</a></td></tr>\n<tr><td colspan=\"2\" class=\"in-txt\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#F8\">In the text</a></td></tr>\n</table></div>\n<div class=\"inset\"><table>\n<tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/F9.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16-fig9_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/F9.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig. 9</span></a><p>Dependence of the metallicity-dependent CO-to-H<span class=\"simple-math\"><sub>2</sub></span> conversion function, computed from Eqs. (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#FD2\">2</a>)&#8211;(<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#FD4\">4</a>), on stellar mass and redshift. The lines are the iso-redshift curves, color-coded as a function of redshift, for <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i> = 0.5</span> to <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i> = 3.5</span> in steps of <span class=\"simple-math\">&#916;<i>z</i> = 0.5</span>: the solid sections correspond to <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16-eq225.png\"></span>, the dashed segments to <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16-eq226.png\"></span>, and the dotted portions to <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16-eq227.png\"></span>. The horizontal black line marks the Milky Way CO-to-H<span class=\"simple-math\"><sub>2</sub></span> conversion factor. Small symbols represent the computed <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16-eq217.png\"></span> values for MACSJ0032-arc (red star) as well as the compilation of MS SFGs with CO measurements from the literature (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#R24\">Dessauges-Zavadsky et al. 2015</a>). Large symbols correspond to the few MS SFGs for which gas-phase metallicities have been measured from rest-frame optical nebular lines. The symbols are color-coded according to galaxy redshift and their shapes indicate <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16-eq228.png\"></span> ratios (<span class=\"simple-math\">&lt;</span>1.5: circles, 1.5<span class=\"simple-math\">&#8722;</span>2: triangles, and <span class=\"simple-math\">&gt;</span>2: squares and star).</p>\n</td>\n</tr>\n<tr><td colspan=\"2\"><a href=\"http://dexter.edpsciences.org/applet.php?pdf_id=9&amp;DOI=10.1051/0004-6361/201628513\" target=\"DEXTER\">Open with DEXTER</a></td></tr>\n<tr><td colspan=\"2\" class=\"in-txt\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#F9\">In the text</a></td></tr>\n</table></div>\n<div class=\"inset\"><table>\n<tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/F10.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16-fig10_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/F10.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig. 10</span></a><p>Molecular gas depletion timescale as a function of redshift for our compilation of CO-detected MS SFGs from the literature (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#R24\">Dessauges-Zavadsky et al. 2015</a>) and MACSJ0032-arc at <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i><sub>CO</sub> = 3.6314</span> (star). The encircled data points correspond to MS SFGs with measured gas-phase metallicities. Five redshift bins are considered: <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i> ~ 0</span>, <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i> =  [ 0.055,0.4 ]</span>, <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i> =  [ 1,1.6 ]</span>, <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i> =  [ 2,2.5 ]</span>, and <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i> =  [ 2.7,3.6 ]</span>. The corresponding mean values of <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>t</i><sub>depl</sub></span> are shown as large black crosses with the associated <span class=\"simple-math\">1<i>&#963;</i></span> dispersion as standard deviation. Magenta crosses represent <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>t</i><sub>depl</sub></span> values from <a name=\"InR5\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#R5\">B&#233;thermin et al. (2015)</a> derived from the FIR dust continuum and by adopting the same mass-metallicity relation (Eq. (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#FD4\">4</a>)). The observed evolution of <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>t</i><sub>depl</sub></span> with redshift is parametrized by a power law; the best fit, <span class=\"simple-math\">1.15(1 + <i>z</i>)<sup>-0.85</sup></span>, is shown as a solid line.</p>\n</td>\n</tr>\n<tr><td colspan=\"2\"><a href=\"http://dexter.edpsciences.org/applet.php?pdf_id=10&amp;DOI=10.1051/0004-6361/201628513\" target=\"DEXTER\">Open with DEXTER</a></td></tr>\n<tr><td colspan=\"2\" class=\"in-txt\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#F10\">In the text</a></td></tr>\n</table></div>\n<div class=\"inset\"><table>\n<tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/F11.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16-fig11_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/F11.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig. 11</span></a><p>Same as Fig. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#F10\">10</a>, but for the molecular gas fraction. A clear evolution of <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>f</i><sub>molgas</sub></span> with redshift is observed, in good agreement with <span class=\"simple-math\">1 / (1 + (0.12(1 + <i>z</i>)<sup>1.95</sup>)<sup>-1</sup>)</span> (solid line).</p>\n</td>\n</tr>\n<tr><td colspan=\"2\"><a href=\"http://dexter.edpsciences.org/applet.php?pdf_id=11&amp;DOI=10.1051/0004-6361/201628513\" target=\"DEXTER\">Open with DEXTER</a></td></tr>\n<tr><td colspan=\"2\" class=\"in-txt\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2017/09/aa28513-16/aa28513-16.html#F11\">In the text</a></td></tr>\n</table></div>\n</div>\n\n\r\n</div>\r\n\r\n    <div id=\"metrics-tabs\" data-doi=\"10.1051/0004-6361/201628513\" data-edps_ref=\"aa28513-16\">\n<nav class=\"toolbar\">\n\t<button class=\"toolbar-item\" id=\"metrics-siq\">Current usage metrics</button>\n\t<button class=\"toolbar-item\" id=\"info\">About article metrics</button>\n    \n\t\n\t<button class=\"toolbar-item\" id=\"return\">Return to article</button>\n</nav>\n\n<div class=\"panel\" data-for=\"metrics-siq\">\n</div>\n\n<div class=\"panel\" data-for=\"metrics-alm\"></div>\n\n<div class=\"panel\" data-for=\"info\">\n\t\n\n\t<p>Current usage metrics show cumulative count of Article Views (full-text article views including HTML views, PDF and ePub downloads, according to the available data)  and Abstracts Views on Vision4Press platform.</p>\n\n\t<p>Data correspond to usage on the plateform after 2015. D.", "Combes, F.", "Ebeling, H.", "Rawle, T. D.", "Egami, E.", "Boone, F.", "Cl\u00e9ment, B.", "Kneib, J. -P.", "Nyland, K.", "Walth, G."], "journal_name": "Astronomy and Astrophysics", "type_of_reference": "JOUR", "abstract": "We report on the galaxy MACSJ0032-arc at z<SUB>CO</SUB> = 3.6314 discovered during the Herschel Lensing snapshot Survey of massive galaxy clusters, and strongly lensed by the cluster MACS J0032.1+1808. The successful detections of its rest-frame ultraviolet (UV), optical, far-infrared (FIR), millimeter, and radio continua, and of its CO emission enable us to characterize, for the first time at such a high redshift, the stellar, dust, and molecular gas properties of a compact star-forming galaxy with a size smaller than 2.5 kpc, a fairly low stellar mass of 4.8<SUP>+ 0.5</SUP><SUB>-1.0</SUB> \u00d7 10<SUP>9</SUP>M<SUB>\u2609</SUB>, and a moderate IR luminosity of 4.8<SUP>+ 1.2</SUP><SUB>-0.6</SUB> \u00d7 10<SUP>11</SUP>L<SUB>\u2609</SUB>. By combining the stretching effect of the lens with the high angular resolution imaging of the CO(1-0) line emission and the radio continuum at 5 GHz, we find that the bulk of the molecular gas mass and star formation seems to be spatially decoupled from the rest-frame UV emission. About 90% of the total star formation rate is undetected at rest-frame UV wavelengths because of severe obscuration by dust, but is seen through the thermal FIR dust emission and the radio synchrotron radiation. The observed CO(4-3) and CO(6-5) lines demonstrate that high-J transitions, at least up to J = 6, remain excited in this galaxy, whose CO spectral line energy distribution resembles that of high-redshift submm galaxies, even though the IR luminosity of MACSJ0032-arc is ten times lower. This high CO excitation is possibly due to the compactness of the galaxy. We find evidence that this high CO excitation has to be considered in the balance when estimating the CO-to-H<SUB>2</SUB> conversion factor. Indeed, the respective CO-to-H<SUB>2</SUB> conversion factors as derived from the correlation with metallicity and the FIR dust continuum can only be reconciled if excitation is accounted for. The inferred depletion time of the molecular gas in MACSJ0032-arc supports the decrease in the gas depletion timescale of galaxies with redshift, although to a lesser degree than predicted by galaxy evolution models. Instead, the measured molecular gas fraction as high as 60-79% in MACSJ0032-arc favors the continued increase in the gas fraction of galaxies with redshift as expected, despite the plateau observed between z 1.5 and z 2.5. <P />Based on observations carried out with the IRAM Plateau de Bure Interferometer, the IRAM 30 m telescope, and the NRAO Karl G. Jansky Very Large Array. The Institut de Radioastronomie Millim\u00e9trique (IRAM) is supported by CNRS/INSU (France), the MPG (Germany), and the IGN (Spain). Belin, 31400, Toulouse, France), AL(Universit\u00e9 Lyon, Universit\u00e9 Lyon 1, ENS de Lyon, CNRS, Centre de Recherche Astrophysique de Lyon UMR 5574, 69230, Saint-Genis-Laval, France), AM(Laboratoire d'Astrophysique, \u00c9cole Polytechnique F\u00e9d\u00e9rale de Lausanne (EPFL), 1290, Versoix, Switzerland; Aix Marseille Universit\u00e9, CNRS, LAM, UMR 7326, 13388, Marseille, France), AN(National Radio Astronomy Observatory, 520 Edgemont Rd, Charlottesville, VA, 22903, USA), AO(University of California, Center for Astrophysics and Space Sciences, 9500 Gilman Drive, San Diego, CA, 92093, USA)"], "keywords": ["cosmology: observations", "gravitational lensing: strong", "galaxies: high-redshift", "ISM: molecules", "galaxies: evolution", "Astrophysics - Astrophysics of Galaxies"], "url": "https://ui.adsabs.harvard.edu/abs/2017A&A...605A..81D", "volume": "605", "Title": "Molecular gas properties of a lensed star-forming galaxy at z   3.6: a case study", "issn": "0004-6361"}}
